Africa’s power generating capacity has "},{"type":"link","url":"https://qz.com/africa/1084847/sub-saharan-africa-is-still-in-the-dark-but-north-africa-will-soon-be-selling-power-to-europe/","children":[{"text":"slowly improved "}]},{"text":"over the years, but rationing, rolling shortages, and blackouts continue to hinder many countries' development — "},{"type":"link","url":"https://qz.com/411384/nigeria-is-shutting-down-for-business-thanks-to-its-worst-ever-fuel-shortages/","children":[{"text":"including economic giants"}]},{"text":" like South Africa and Nigeria. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While Sub-Saharan Africa stays largely in the dark, the power of the sun in North Africa is being harnessed, with billions being invested into large solar plants. Once operational, projects like the TuNur solar project in Tunisia, will open a new, "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.nurenergie.com/tunur/index.php/english/project/overview","children":[{"text":"intercontinental energy corridor"}]},{"text":" between North Africa and Europe. They will be delivering power to homes in Italy and France. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is an incredible technological advancement. But we should be asking questions about Africa providing the Global North with the energy it needs to facilitate further consumption, before meeting the basic energy, efficiency and stability demands of its own citizens."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The issues outlined above suggest a kind of ‘lifeboat ethics’, where we in the Global North use temporary sustainability to save ourselves – at the cost of the poor. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"It is important to note that the Green New Deal itself does not incite colonialism. Far from it. It is that the changes it calls for could lay the foundations (or act as an excuse for) for colonial agendas and behaviours."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, there is a more insidious threat to consider. One aspect of the ‘renewable industry’ that is often glazed over is the sourcing (mining) of materials. To build the machinery, factories, power stations and technology that produce renewable energy, we need materials like cobalt, lithium, silver and copper. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/green-new-deal-alexandria-ocasio-cortez-corbyn-colonialism-climate-change-a8899876.html","children":[{"text":"Behind each tonne extracted is a story"}]},{"text":" of water contamination and depletion, habitat destruction, deforestation, land poisoning, health impact and environmental conflict – primarily for those in the Global South. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Take cobalt, for example, which is used in rechargeable batteries. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/green-new-deal-alexandria-ocasio-cortez-corbyn-colonialism-climate-change-a8899876.html","children":[{"text":"58% is mined in the DRC"}]},{"text":". Its mining has contributed to a conflict that has blighted innumerable lives, caused air, water and soil contamination, and left the mining area as one of the top ten most polluted places in the world. With global demand for cobalt set to increase by as much as 423% by 2050, the future of those in the DRC, including child labourers, looks increasingly bleak. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These are only a few ways in which what some might call ‘sustainability’ can contribute to climate colonialism, and there are many more. But there is also definitely hope. It is important to note that the Green New Deal itself does not incite colonialism. Far from it. It is that the changes it calls for could lay the foundations (or act as an excuse for) for colonial agendas and behaviours. The Green New Deal has the potential to be an instrumental tool in our green transition. The politicians, human rights activists and conscious scientists, academics and legislators behind it can and should ensure that policies put in place to transition the West to a more sustainable infrastructure also provide a brighter future for everyone on Earth. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Joycelyn Longdon is a soon-to-be Climate Researcher embarking on a 4-year MRes + PhD at Cambridge University. She studies the application of artificial intelligence to climate change, and has a particular interest in empowering and supporting indigenous and ‘developing’ communities. She founded ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/climateincolour/","children":[{"text":"Climate In Colour","italic":true}]},{"text":" on Instagram as a space to document her journey and to make conversations around climate change more inclusive, accessible and interesting. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592511689/Screen_Shot_2020-06-18_at_21.21.10_tufwz0.png","children":[{"text":""}]}]
values.title: What has the Green New Deal got to do with colonialism?

values.subtitle: More than 50,000 buildings are demolished every year. What happens next?
values.author: Florence Wildblood
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We’ve all seen buildings smashed to pieces behind billboards promising blue skies and state-of-the-art apartments. We’ve seen once-towering conglomerates of glass, metal and stone become pits of rubble by the side of the road. Buildings are built; we sleep, work and play in them; they get old or fall out of use and get demolished; new buildings are built. Unfortunately, there are some hefty gaps in this architectural circle of life. To patch them up, we need to ask where construction debris goes next – and to apply principles of reuse, rather than production, to the built environment."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Of the 200 million tonnes of waste generated in Britain annually, 63% is - according to Defra - construction debris. We lose tens of thousands of buildings to demolition each year and, to quote "},{"text":"The Architect’s Journal","italic":true},{"text":", ‘while more than 90% of the resulting waste material is recovered, much of this is recycled into a less valuable product or material, rather than being reused.’ Due to the sheer scale of building waste and the corporations that emit it, the difference between ‘downcycling’ and reuse is actually huge.   "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The construction industry is an insatiable consumer. Like other goods-based industries, it operates in line with a linear economic model – ‘take-make-use-waste’. Every building has something like the supply chain we more generally associate with supermarkets and clothes shops. And as it stands, each step in this chain entails its own negative environmental effects. At the start, when building materials are sourced, we see resource depletion, deforestation, and loss of biodiversity. At the end – wherever disused and demolished buildings end up – we see pollution of land, rivers and oceans."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Architects, designers and construction professionals should see the materials they use as part of a wider store of resources, rather than as one-off constituents of one-off projects."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It might seem counterintuitive, but we can learn a lot about how to fix this by looking to the past. We should be refurbishing and repurposing our buildings rather than knocking them down, and putting their core materials to good use if we do end up going forward with demolition. Working with reclaimed buildings and materials is a centuries-old practice; exemplary methods of building deconstruction and reuse crop up all throughout history. Before the Industrial Revolution – which brought mass production and machines to efficiently dispose of our waste – things were a little different."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Circumstances may have changed, but a new generation of architects and designers are preparing to embrace pre-industrial principles as they look towards a climate-conscious future. Charlotte Perkins – who decided to forge her own path after struggling to reconcile her environmentalism with her career choice – is one of them. I spoke to Charlotte about how architects, designers and construction companies can best face up to the realities of the linear economic model, and about her new venture, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.anotherworks.co.uk/","children":[{"text":"another"}]},{"text":"."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592991958/491290_ba093f96_f3f0nl.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Demolition of flats in Croxteth, Liverpool. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Architects and designers might seem a million miles away from the tonnes of waste at the other end of a building’s life cycle, but according to Charlotte, they “play a huge part in controlling the materials that are consumed”. The more architects and designers express an appetite to work with reclaimed materials, the “more support and investment there will be in the reuse market”. “If salvage companies are unable to sell materials and elements, they are unlikely to buy them from demolition contractors”."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This appetite isn’t yet revealing itself on a big enough scale. There a lot of hurdles, many of which Charlotte experienced first-hand while in practice. “Short-term profit-motivated budgets, clients’ and design teams’ negative perception of reclaimed materials, and the difficulty of buying in bulk on the second-hand market” all stand in the way of a more sustainable architecture."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“"},{"text":"The Architects Journal ","italic":true},{"text":"are currently running a campaign called "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/news/introducing-retrofirst-a-new-aj-campaign-championing-reuse-in-the-built-environment/10044359.article?blocktitle=intro&contentID=24810","children":[{"text":"Retrofirst"}]},{"text":", and one of their demands relates to VAT. We pay 20% VAT on most forms of refurbishment and renovation and typically between 0 and 5% on embodied carbon-heavy new builds. This incentivises rebuilding as opposed to renovation”, Charlotte tells me. “From a developer’s perspective it is much faster and cheaper to demolish and crush a building and where possible feed into recycling streams, than it is to carefully dismantle a building and its components keeping materials in a state for in situ reuse or sale elsewhere.” The result: materials are devalued, often crushed to produce hard core."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But building techniques can, and indeed must, change. Charlotte cites digital material passports, “a method of tracking a material’s life and use, which will help with issues related to structural performance”, and spaces dedicated to storing materials in anticipation of reuse, as developments to look out for."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In terms of change-making enterprises, we can look to Belgium-based "},{"type":"link","url":"http://rotordb.org/en","children":[{"text":"Rotor"}]},{"text":", who have “their own deconstruction and salvage company, as well as a design studio” and Feilden Fowles who designed London’s "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.feildenfowles.co.uk/waterloo-city-farm/","children":[{"text":"Waterloo City Farm"}]},{"text":" for disassembly. Just the other day, the BBC reported on"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feed","children":[{"text":" a first for Australian architecture"}]},{"text":": two skyscrapers that, instead of being knocked down in lieu of one bigger building, were stitched into one. 11,000 tonnes of carbon have been saved, say the architects. Thanks to government stimulus for green projects, a lot of money has been saved too."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592992376/Screen_Shot_2020-06-24_at_10.52.25_tsn88u.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Waterloo City Farm. Image courtesy of Feilden Fowles. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Now to another, Charlotte’s own smaller-scale project, where she’s fusing her expertise in architecture and interiors in a new and eco-conscious way. One pioneering design company might feel like a drop in the ocean up against the tonnes of construction debris we need to sift through, but another sets an example to be followed."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I wanted to work at a scale where I could stay true to my values”, says Charlotte, “I believe that influencing an industry that you know and understand from the inside to become more environmentally responsible can be as effective as being a front line activist - although this is important too!”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"another is a design company centred on the principle of reuse. “Wherever possible projects work with reclaimed buildings, elements and materials, and where this is not possible we design with a circular economy in mind. The aim of another is to inspire positive change, to help create an environmentally conscious and responsible construction industry.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A recent project provides a great example of how another’s principles work in action. Charlotte was recently commissioned to make a bathroom vanity unit, using a specific piece of reclaimed slate. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592992470/IMG_0078_y5yfli.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"another's vanity unit.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In order to work with the slate’s size and uneven nature, a bespoke base was needed. “A big part of designing in the way we do is acknowledging that some reclaimed materials will require bespoke elements to incorporate them into projects”, says Charlotte."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Even though the oak used was new, Charlotte ensured it was responsibly sourced (FSC certified, European, and “cut to size to avoid unnecessary waste) and the vanity unit was designed with an afterlife in mind. “The unit was assembled using screws to allow for future disassembly, repair and reuse.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Clearly, decisions made at the very beginning of the design process set the scene for what happens at the end of a structure’s life cycle – whether it be a bathroom vanity unit or a skyscraper. Architects, designers and construction professionals should see the materials they use as part of a wider store of resources, rather than as one-off constituents of one-off projects."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"What does the circular economy mean to you?\", I ask Charlotte."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“In the context of another it means avoiding waste and understanding that everything created comes with an impact. It means working in a way that considers the before and after life of materials and spaces, avoiding unnecessary demolition and prioritising retention, reuse, and deconstruction instead.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Follow another on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/another_works/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Designing for a Circular Economy

values.subtitle: A conversation with Britain’s leading urban forester about street trees and green equity.
values.author: Alex Diggins
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"John Parker is keen not to come across as “too much of a tree hugger”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nonetheless he says: “When you’re in front of a 2000-year-old Yew tree, it’s like nothing else. It’s the equivalent of standing beside the ocean, or looking up at a mountain – except, for most people, a tree is a just short stroll from your front door.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"John has had more chances than most to get up close and personal with trees. He recently took up a senior role at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.trees.org.uk/","children":[{"text":"the Arboricultural Association"}]},{"text":", a charity and member organisation which represents people working with trees. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But before that he spent ten years with Transport for London (TfL) looking after the city’s more than 24,000 street trees – many of which line ‘red routes’, the capital’s busiest arterial roads. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593256545/JohnParker_miesxi.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"John Parker, Senior Technical Officer at the Arboricultural Association. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Despite the thousands of trees in their care, TfL’s tree team is small and closely knit – only three people in an organisation of more than 20,000 employees who usually work to ensure the city’s Tube and bus network runs on time.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“It was quite niche,” John admits. But working alongside the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ltoa.org.uk/","children":[{"text":"London Tree Officers Association "}]},{"text":"– who represent the city’s arboricultural workers – “a real sense of community” was built. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Though John is now well-known as an advocate for urban forests – his TED talk, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sYzaDCZHvR8&feature=emb_title","children":[{"text":"‘Why Trees Are Better Than People’"}]},{"text":", has been viewed nearly 4,000 times, and he has a lively following on "},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/johntree1981","children":[{"text":"Twitter"}]},{"text":" – his journey into arboriculture wasn’t straightforward.   "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"He started a law degree at Cardiff University, but dropped out to manage pubs. It was the suggestion of a friend, though, that led him to taking a diploma in arboriculture – and his job at TfL. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"\"There’s been a whole chain of people who’ve looked after those trees since the mid-1800s. We’ll never know their names – but there’s a sense of being part of something larger.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I was slightly feral as a child, always hanging around in the woods,” he says. “But I never realised it was possible to make a career out of trees until my mid-20s. It’s something we’re trying to address as an industry now – making young people realise they can make good money from climbing trees and hanging around in parks.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Urban trees are far from “ornamental”, though. In fact, they bring innumerable benefits to cities. A dense tree canopy provides an ‘urban cooling’ effect, helping to reduce the intense heat trapped by concrete and glass cityscapes; and trees filter the air, mitigating pollution. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But perhaps most remarkably, well-maintained street trees have been proven to foster “a sense of community”. This communal spirit drives down deprivation and petty crime which, in turn, makes the area a more pleasant place to live. It’s a virtuous cycle sometimes referred to as the ‘broken windows’ theory. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But John cautions: “We need to look more closely at who is receiving the benefits trees bring. Are they distributed evenly throughout society?” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Covid-19 pandemic has undoubtedly shown the advantages of living in close proximity to green space. But equally evident is the fact that those advantages are not inclusive and accessible to all. They can be gradated depressingly easily on the grounds of class, ethnicity and economic outcome."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Tackling this green inequality will be crucial to ensuring the UK’s arboricultural industry continues to thrive, John believes. But it will also be vital to combatting larger, systemic problems like the climate crisis. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593256545/738af578-5cac-4179-bb40-82a7a534a9b2_crbix8.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"John in action at the Stonehouse Community Climate Action Forum Day at the end of last year. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We’ve got a fantastic industry of diverse people passionate about trees. And I think it’s incredibly inspiring to see the work of a younger generation, and I hope their enthusiasm filters through. But we need more outreach – let kids know it’s a viable career.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“There’s a real disconnect between people and nature.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Despite these challenges, John is hopeful the sublime magic of urban trees will continue to grip imaginations – as they have his. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"He remembers caring for the plane trees on London’s Embankment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Tree officers are the custodians. There’s been a whole chain of people who’ve looked after those trees since the mid-1800s. We’ll never know their names – but there’s a sense of being part of something larger. And that’s a wonderful privilege.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Arboricultural Association has a selection of free ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://trees.org.uk/Training-Events/Online-Learning","children":[{"text":"online learning resources","italic":true}]},{"text":", and regularly broadcasts talks and lectures from leading tree experts. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Alex Diggins is a writer and critic based in London. He contributes regularly to The Economist, The Times Literary Supplement and The Spectator, and is currently working on a book about holy islands and the climate crisis. Follow him on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/AHABDiggins","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Are trees better than people?

values.subtitle: Without respect for human rights, the clean energy industry risks the entire fight to avert the climate crisis.
values.author: Harriet Wood
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We have known for years about the long-pending and now-very-present climate crisis. The targets and figures are well-trodden ground: the Paris Agreement determined that global warming must be limited to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ec.europa.eu/clima/policies/international/negotiations/paris_en","children":[{"text":"‘well below’ 2°C"}]},{"text":", which will require a move to net-zero carbon emissions by many of the world’s biggest producers by 2050. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.climatechangenews.com/2019/06/14/countries-net-zero-climate-goal/","children":[{"text":"An increasing number of governments "}]},{"text":"have turned this agreement into national and regional strategy, committing to carbon neutrality through policies like the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ec.europa.eu/info/strategy/priorities-2019-2024/european-green-deal_en","children":[{"text":"European Green Deal"}]},{"text":", but "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/10/ipcc-climate-change-report-paris-climate-accord-181009134051255.html","children":[{"text":"concerns"}]},{"text":" over whether these targets will even be sufficient to avert the impacts of climate change are ever-growing."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The COVID-19 pandemic has, unexpectedly, illuminated a fork in the road - we have seen the potential for rapid and effective change in action. How we choose to rebuild global economies in the wake of the crisis will determine how our planet and society function for many years to come, and with fast action, we can seize the opportunity to build new economic systems which address the other environmental and humanitarian crises we face."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"New research indicates that none of the 16 largest renewable energy companies"},{"type":"link","url":"https://bit.ly/3cVd3wi","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":" fully meet their basic human rights responsibilities. All 16 score a flat zero on respect for land rights."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The renewable energy industry is absolutely crucial to the fight to stop the climate crisis: without it, we stand no chance of reaching net-zero carbon targets. But the sector, like any other, is susceptible to exploitation. Irresponsible business practices by major companies spearheading the"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-52906551","children":[{"text":" ‘green industrial revolution’ "}]},{"text":"worryingly echo the history of the fossil fuel industries, which have historically abused workers, displaced communities and polluted the environment on a dizzying scale. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593415106/Photo_2_bjgfcr.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Yucatán forest. Image courtesy of Pablo Cabezos. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In Muna, a municipality in the Mexican state of Yucatán, a legal battle is underway over local opposition to a solar energy megaproject looking to clear 603 hectares of forest in order to install 183,000 solar panels. It’s a move local organisations say may put native plant and animal species at risk, as well as impacting the area’s vulnerability to hurricane damage, disrupting pollination processes and contributing to water scarcity. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://files.constantcontact.com/83b41ac7001/80c0c036-82fb-4166-9b19-6f9d64887b28.pdf","children":[{"text":"The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights determined"}]},{"text":" that the consultation process carried out in the village of San José Tipceh - "},{"type":"link","url":"https://en.mexico.pueblosamerica.com/i/san-jose-tipceh/","children":[{"text":"where 70% of the population is indigenous"}]},{"text":", and 35% speak a Maya dialect - for the project by US-based company Sunpower did not comply with international standards. These standards require such projects to have the ‘free, prior and informed consent’ of the indigenous communities they affect. The UN report pointed to irregular payments, conflicts of interest, and ‘culturally inadequate’ attempts to inform local residents of plans; aside from failing to provide translated materials, Sunpower had sent out its technical documents over email, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.cemda.org.mx/consulta-indigena-para-mega-parque-solar-en-muna-yucatan-incumple-estandares-internacionales/","children":[{"text":"inaccessible to members of the community without an internet connection"}]},{"text":". A case brought against the company by Mexican environmental organisation CEMDA is still under litigation. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"With plans underway for "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.business-humanrights.org/es/m%C3%A9xico-20-proyectos-de-energ%C3%ADa-renovable-en-proceso-de-consulta-en-la-pen%C3%ADnsula-de-yucat%C3%A1n","children":[{"text":"dozens of renewable energy projects"}]},{"text":" in this area of Mexico alone, local organisations are rightly concerned over shoddy consultation processes opening the door for the potential destruction of swathes of tropical deciduous forest, with local knowledge and understanding of the region’s finely balanced ecosystem taking a backseat to corporate interests."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Beyond the Yucatán peninsula, a pattern of environmental and human rights risks linked to new ‘green’ industries is playing out all over the world as efforts to turn the tide on the climate crisis are ramping up. In Kenya, significant investments in renewable energy production, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.iwgia.org/images/publications//0725_REPORT21.pdf","children":[{"text":"encouraged"}]},{"text":" as part of the country’s sustainable development efforts, have been beset with allegations of human rights abuses. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Lake Turkana Wind Power project is Kenya’s biggest ever private investment ("},{"type":"link","url":"https://old.danwatch.dk/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Danwatch_report_A-PEOPLE-IN-THE-WAY-OF-PROGRESS-2016_web.pdf","children":[{"text":"valued at approximately 620 million euros"}]},{"text":"), with electricity generated from turbines reportedly set to increase national energy output by between 15-20%. Since applying for land leases in 2006, the company behind the development claim to have carried out ‘"},{"type":"link","url":"https://old.danwatch.dk/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Danwatch_report_A-PEOPLE-IN-THE-WAY-OF-PROGRESS-2016_web.pdf","children":[{"text":"numerous consultations and stakeholder meetings"}]},{"text":"’. However, local communities - including the inhabitants of Sarima village, relocated to a fenced-off enclosure within the project site to make way for 365 turbines produced by Danish manufacturer Vestas - dispute these claims, as documented in a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://old.danwatch.dk/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Danwatch_report_A-PEOPLE-IN-THE-WAY-OF-PROGRESS-2016_web.pdf","children":[{"text":"2016 report by Danwatch"}]},{"text":". In a particularly concerning debate, Lake Turkana Wind Power have posited that several of the affected communities cannot be identified as indigenous, and are thus exempt from the usual "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.un.org/development/desa/indigenouspeoples/declaration-on-the-rights-of-indigenous-peoples.html","children":[{"text":"internationally accepted standards "}]},{"text":"on indigenous rights. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593415244/Photo_3_ufj94f.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lake Turkana. Image courtesy of aocrane.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Human rights organisation "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.business-humanrights.org/","children":[{"text":"Business & Human Rights Resource Centre"}]},{"text":" has recorded nearly 200 allegations of abuses related to renewable energy companies all over the world, including killings, threats, land grabs, dangerous working conditions and harm to indigenous peoples’ lives and livelihoods. New research by the organisation indicates that "},{"type":"link","url":"https://bit.ly/3cVd3wi","children":[{"text":"none of the 16 largest renewable energy companies"}]},{"text":" fully meet their basic human rights responsibilities. All 16 score a flat zero on respect for land rights."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Faced with land grabs, intimidation, and abusive working conditions, local communities - who often know first-hand the devastating effects of climate change - are left with no choice but to stand in opposition, sometimes using lawsuits to delay and suspend projects. Kenya’s Lake Turkana project has been "},{"type":"link","url":"https://issafrica.org/iss-today/kenyas-ambitious-wind-turbines-battle-community-land-crosswinds","children":[{"text":"delayed by litigation"}]},{"text":" brought by local communities, but as the Sarima Indigenous People’s Land Forum state in their "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:7b2be4e3-ddf4-4066-987b-6867c8fcab54/download_file?file_format=pdf&safe_filename=FINAL%2BChanging%2BValue%2BLand.pdf&type_of_work=Journal+article","children":[{"text":"declaration"}]},{"text":": "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"'We are not against establishing a wind power project. We know the power of the wind in our ancestral lands, and we want it to contribute to the sustainable development of our communities, the Marsabit County and Kenya as a whole. We are determined to make this happen on the basis of our communities’ ownership and leadership.'","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By undermining the rights and knowledge of the communities who have defended their land and protected the environment for centuries or longer, unscrupulous companies and irresponsible governments put the entire fight to halt the climate crisis at risk. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The answer - as is so often the case - lies in local-led, equity-driven solutions built on meaningful stakeholder engagement. Surrounding communities should be able to reap the benefits of the projects affecting their lives and environments, rather than being choked out by exploitative corporate practices. There are examples of this: in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ejatlas.org/conflict/communal-members-of-ixtepec-contending-to-develop-a-wind-farm-cooperative","children":[{"text":"Oaxaca, Mexico"}]},{"text":", a local wind power project sees 50% of profits reinvested in Ixtepec community projects. In Canada, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://indigenouscleanenergy.com/ice-projects/","children":[{"text":"over 152 renewable energy projects are underway "}]},{"text":"with significant involvement from indigenous stakeholders. But with Business & Human Rights Resource Centre’s new research indicating that only half of the biggest renewable energy companies make any reference at all to the rights of indigenous peoples in their policy statements, there is evidently a long way to go before a future built upon renewable energy becomes truly just and sustainable."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593415328/Photo_4_egqy0e.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ixtepec wind farm cooperative. Image courtesy of Environmental Justice Atlas. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The battle of the climate movement, similar to the work of progressive activists across many spheres, has long been one of fighting to put out the fires of the past. Sustainability extends far beyond measures of carbon emissions and degrees of global warming, and human rights must be at the centre of any path forward which aims to be truly sustainable. Without purposeful action by companies working alongside - rather than against - civil society on climate solutions, supported by pre-emptive and meaningful government regulation, the clean energy industry’s contribution to the climate change battle will only serve to light new fires. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Harriet Wood works as a writer and in digital communications at Business & Human Rights Resource Centre. She writes news, features and the occasional diatribe on social media with a focus on sustainability and human rights. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Renewable energy: the hidden human cost

values.subtitle: A conversation with People and Planet, who pushed the University of Manchester to divest from fossil fuels.
values.author: Nicole Wootton-Cane
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Across the world, students are at the heart of the climate justice movement. Both inside and outside of the classroom they are writing, protesting, boycotting, and occupying, attempting to bring about real, meaningful change – and many are starting with their own university campuses as battlegrounds. The idea of facing up to big companies and institutions and demanding change can be daunting. But students are at the core of any university, and through dedicated, organised campaigns, some are beginning to significantly influence shifts in policy at their institutions."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Last November, a group of students from the University of Manchester’s branch of climate campaign network "},{"type":"link","url":"https://peopleandplanet.org/","children":[{"text":"People and Planet"}]},{"text":" hit national news after staging a week-long occupation of a campus administration building, demanding that the university commit to full divestment from fossil fuels. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Six months later their appeal was met with the university’s announcement that they would fully divest from fossil fuel companies by 2022 – a hard won fight for People and Planet, who had been running this campaign at the University for almost nine years."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"\"The power of divestment lies less in the financial impact it has on the fossil fuel industry, which is small, but more in removing its social license to operate.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Why is divestment important?  In People and Planet's "},{"type":"link","url":"https://peopleandplanet.org/fossil-free","children":[{"text":"own words"}]},{"text":", it is 'one way we can help to weaken the fossil fuel industry further to support frontline communities in their fight to keep fossil fuels in the ground.' It's about solidarity with those in the Global South whose livelihoods are routinely wrecked by extraction and the effects of climate change. Fossil fuel companies hold five times more carbon in their reserves than we can safely afford to burn to stop runaway climate change, yet are still spending billions searching for more. Our universities are at the forefront of environmental research; this hard work is diminished when the institutions behind it are directly contributing to the problem. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The protest at the University of Manchester appeared straightforward; the students simply refused to leave the building until university senior leadership agreed to meet their seven demands, which as well as divestment included opening up a dialogue with students on the issue, giving regular and public updates on their progress, and a commitment to engaging with issues surrounding climate justice and decolonisation. But similar protests had been tried with little success in the past, and the occupiers knew that intense preparation was required in order to be able to remain in the building for long enough to make the kind of impact they hoped to."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593700738/89278370_2668251666738812_1781182182430081024_o_vpmzhz.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Protestors at UoM. Image courtesy of Fossil Free Manchester. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“The occupation was a mammoth task to plan,” Kate Benson, one of the occupiers, said. “It involved scouting suitable locations (with an accessible toilet!), recruiting enough people to make it viable, making banners and signs and lots of writing: our demands, press releases, an open letter, a legal briefing…”."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kayleigh Crawford, who was responsible for much of the planning, recalled even getting into the building as the hardest part: “18 students trying to inconspicuously enter an off-limits building is never an easy task. We came up with four backup plans in case our original didn’t work, and we ended up using our third backup plan, so being prepared definitely paid off!”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After seven days inside the building, university leadership agreed to come together with the students and discuss their demands. The meeting resulted in an agreement to bring forward a review of the university’s investment portfolio, which at the time had around £12 million worth of shares tied up in fossil fuel reserve and extraction companies. Crucially - thanks to the occupation - during this review, students from People and Planet had a seat at the table."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the new year, a consultation was launched into the future of the University’s investments which received nearly 600 responses from staff, students, and alumni."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“It’s also important because it shows that grassroots student campaigns can work, and helps pave the way for the success of other vital campaigns on campus.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Following this consultation, the University of Manchester recently announced that they will be fully divesting from fossil fuels by 2022. The news means that the University will redistribute the shares they currently have in fossil fuel companies to more sustainable alternatives, and was welcomed as a “huge victory” for People and Planet."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“A divestment win at Manchester, particularly as the largest university in the UK, is important because it piles the pressure on other institutions to follow suit”, Kate told me."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“It’s also important because it shows that grassroots student campaigns can work, and helps pave the way for the success of other vital campaigns on campus.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Daniel Johnson, another occupier, said the significance of the decision was twofold. “Firstly, the power of divestment lies less in the financial impact it has on the fossil fuel industry, which is small, but more in removing its social license to operate.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“The second reason for its importance is that the university is finally listening to its students on the climate crisis. People and Planet hope that this will mark a new beginning in which the university can work with its students to reduce its contribution to the climate crisis, cut the last remaining ties with the fossil fuel industry, and further valuable research.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"So far 82 UK and 2 Irish universities have committed to divest from fossil fuels in some form. These commitment cover endowment wealth of over £11bn. Has yours? Find out ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://peopleandplanet.org/fossil-free-scorecards","children":[{"text":"here","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nicole Wootton-Cane is a recent graduate from the University of Manchester, who has covered student activism for the Guardian and the Mancunion. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Featured image courtesy of Fossil Free UCL. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Divestment: what's the deal?

values.subtitle: Green recovery, anyone?
values.author: Florence Wildblood
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Isle of Wight was listed as a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve this time last year because of its ‘strong tradition of environmental action’ and ecotourism, and its pioneering testing of ‘new measures for climate change mitigation and adaptation’. The island - of which "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.visitisleofwight.co.uk/explore/biosphere-reserve","children":[{"text":"half is"}]},{"text":" an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty - has long been a hub for positive environmental attitudes and action. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Drilling for oil on a self-declared ‘eco-island’ was always bound to cause upset – and is hardly in the spirit of the green recovery we’ve all been looking forward to post-lockdown. Nevertheless, UK Oil and Gas (UKOG) has submitted a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://publicaccess.iow.gov.uk/online-applications/applicationDetails.do?activeTab=summary&keyVal=Q7DSVFIQ07V00","children":[{"text":"planning application"}]},{"text":" to the Isle of Wight County Council, hoping to begin a three-year exploratory onshore oil drilling venture at site called ‘Arreton-3-site’, and then to move the drilling to another site in Godshill. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Both Arreton and Godshill are tourist sites; the future of surrounding businesses, and of the Isle of Wight’s tourism industry in general, would be massively threatened by the venture. Expected  environmental impact includes air pollution from diesel-fuelled generators; strain on the island’s already-limited water supply; and the destruction of rural and agricultural land, causing damage to biodiverse ecosystems. In general, the plans demonstrate a cavalier attitude regarding the future of the global climate. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"UKOG says the project will have ‘little to no environmental impact’ and will "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-52682041","children":[{"text":"benefit the local economy"}]},{"text":". However, this is disputed by Bea Stark, a lifelong resident of the Isle of Wight who is campaigning to stop the plans from going ahead. Bea is 18 and set up the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/iowprotection/","children":[{"text":"Isle of Wight Protection Group "}]},{"text":"as a means of channeling the discontent of younger island citizens into tangible activism. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593794550/Screen_Shot_2020-07-03_at_17.42.12_ghcxdg.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The IoW Protection Group in action. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As the rules stand, planning permission can only be objected to on technical grounds. But for Bea and the #DontDrillTheWight team, this is about far more than technicalities. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“This proposal, if accepted, will change the island irreversibly, damage tourism, devalue house prices. But most importantly this is an ethical issue. Should we be allowing new onshore oil drilling licenses when we are in a climate emergency?”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“This proposal will determine if our government and councillors actually are seriously committed to their words and pledges to combat climate change and natural resource exploitation,” she says.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Bea and her older sister Isabel, who is also campaigning, are optimistic about their efforts - citing previous successes of grassroots activists against the oil and gas industry, such as in the case of UKOG’s application for onshore oil drilling at Markswell Wood, West Sussex. Due to over 2,000 objections from individuals and organisations, UKOG withdrew their planning application just before it was to be debated by the South Downs National Park Authority in May 2017. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"Grassroots activists, generally, have a fierce love and loyalty to their home environment. No one knows the surrounding environment and history like locals,\" say the sisters. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"By harnessing both local level knowledge and their drive to protect the environment we truly believe grass roots activism  has the energy and force to stop  oil companies who often overlook local environmental and cultural nuances.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At the moment, there’s a real lack of public awareness about the drilling proposal, so much so that Isle of Wight Councillor John Medland has labelled it contrary to the principles of democracy. “Forcing such a critical consultation into an exclusively virtual sphere, with no public meetings or documents to handle, is an attack on our very democracy”, he said. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nevertheless, Bea and the team at Don’t Drill the Wight are making progress. They're urging people to submit objections to UKOG’s application, and aiming to get to 2,000 by 24th July. This would match the number of complaints received regarding drilling at Markswell Wood, and would - Bea hopes - constitute a step towards the success seen in Sussex. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Do you want to write an objection? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Click ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://publicaccess.iow.gov.uk/online-applications/search.do?action=simple&searchType=Application","children":[{"text":"here","italic":true}]},{"text":" to go to the Isle of Wight Council planning application search page. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. Type the reference number into the search bar: 20/00513/FUL. This will take you to the planning application proposal.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"3. Click the ‘Comments’ section, which will show you the Objection and Supporting comments that have already been made. To make a comment, you have to follow the relevant links to register for an account. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Comments can be any length but need to be ","italic":true},{"text":"as specific as possible","italic":true,"bold":true},{"text":". Tips on what to write ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/iowprotection/","children":[{"text":"here","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Images courtesy of Isle of Wight Protection Group. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: There are plans to drill for oil on the Isle of Wight

values.subtitle: Residents of Chicago are feeling the effects of extreme weather as global heating impacts the USA.
values.author: Elisa Shoenberger
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Chicago has always had a reputation for its hot summers and freezing winters, with temperatures sometimes swinging over 100 degrees Fahrenheit in a single year. However, Chicago is not typically part of the conversation when it comes to climate change. Melting sea ice, crumbling glaciers, and uncontrollable wildfires occupy the headlines. But trends over the past few decades suggest that climate change has come to Chicago."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“You see a lot of things that scientists have been warning about manifesting, things like increased flooding... changes in ice freeze, warming winters, hotter summers,” explains Rachel Licker, Senior Climate Scientist for the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ucsusa.org/about/people/rachel-licker","children":[{"text":"Union of Concerned Scientists"}]},{"text":".“We’re seeing the thumbprint of human-caused climate change on the extreme events that have been occurring here.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Chicago and the Midwest tend to be absent in national climate discussions because they have not seen hurricanes and wildfires, like those unfolding in other parts of the United States. As Douglas Stotz, senior conservation ecologist at the Field Museum of Chicago, points out “we are affected by the Great Lakes, so continental-wide things tend to be less obvious around Chicago than elsewhere”. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593863844/gettyimages-818701204_2000_vp39ey.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"California wildfires. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, temperatures are warmer than they used to be. Even though Chicago and the Midwest are not facing natural disasters, their changing climate will have repercussions for the entire country. The Midwest as a whole, Rachel says, is “home to a really important agricultural system, producing a lot of the country’s food.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Extreme heat is a real threat – and a reality Chicago is already facing. Rachel, who worked on the Union of Concerned Scientists’ 2019 report "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/killer-heat-united-states-0","children":[{"text":"Killer Heat in the United States"}]},{"text":", points out that while Chicago historically has seen a few days over 100℉ (just under 38℃), it’s “happening more often.” Night-time temperature trends are warmer, thanks to heat absorbed by asphalt, released from engines and then radiated out, which Rachel points out “exacerbates the problem.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While it’s important not to conflate weather and climate, Rachel says, “it’s important to step back to look at the trend, where they have been headed.” If no action is taken by midcentury, the 2019 report predicts that there may be as many as 30 days a year over 100℉ or 53 days by late century. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This extreme heat will adversely impact people living in Chicago and the region, but not proportionally,  since some groups— like the elderly, small children, and under-resourced communities— will face higher risks. Chicago saw how deadly hot summers can be in 1995 when "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-chicago-heat-wave-20-years-later-met-20150715-story.html","children":[{"text":"over 700 people"}]},{"text":" died from a brutal heat wave. While the city has definitely improved its infrastructure and procedures to handle these events, month-long heat waves will put a strain on resources and  “fundamentally change what we could enjoy in the Midwest,” Rachel says."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"The past three Mays have set records for highest rainfall ever "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.weather.gov/lot/May_Precip_Rankings_Chicago","children":[{"text":" "}]},{"text":"for the city; each year successively breaks the record. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Extreme heat also increases ozone concentration in cities, which is another significant health risk, the 2019 report explains. “Heat contributes to [ozone] creation”, Rachel explains. Breathing ground-level ozone can result in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.epa.gov/ozone-pollution-and-your-patients-health/health-effects-ozone-general-population","children":[{"text":"damage to respiratory health"}]},{"text":", especially in people who have asthma or similar problems."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But extreme heat isn’t the only change that Chicagoans are currently facing. Winters are becoming warmer and wetter. Rich Kisseloff and Rick Richter, founders of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/Windy-City-Mushers-370560473046323/","children":[{"text":"Windy City Mushers"}]},{"text":", a Chicagoland dog sport group, noted that the past few years are seeing less and less snowfall, impacting dog winter sports. In terms of longer term trends, Rachel sees these observations in line with projections that there will be “more precipitation and less snowfall.”"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593863942/14479695_802562929846073_5266811239856358682_n_azyzwg.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Winter sports are being affected. Image courtesy of Windy City Mushers. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Precipitation in particular is a salient issue, with scientists predicting and seeing greater storms overall. The 2008"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.chicago.gov/content/dam/city/progs/env/CCAP/CCAP.pdf","children":[{"text":" Chicago Climate Action Plan"}]},{"text":" forecasted that ‘heavy rains and snows could become more frequent in winter and spring.’"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"‘Increased intensity of downpours will make travel more dangerous, flood basements, pollute bodies of water, damage crops, stress the city’s infrastructure and disrupt transportation’, says the plan. ‘During summer, rains may fall more heavily but less frequently, translating to more dry spells as well.’ Rachel suggests that these predictions were, unfortunately, on point. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Chicago is seeing “bigger and stronger storms,” Douglas highlights. “The average precipitation has gone up [several] inches since the 1980s.” The past three Mays have set records for "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.weather.gov/lot/May_Precip_Rankings_Chicago","children":[{"text":"highest rainfall ever "}]},{"text":"for the city; each year successively breaks the record. However, he says, “precipitation is more of a zero sum game, if it’s wetter in one place, it’s drier someplace else.” June, he points out, has been "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.weather.gov/lot/June_Precip_Rankings_Chicago","children":[{"text":"drier as a trend"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These warmer winters and springs are also affecting wildlife. Douglas points out that there is a mistiming with birds and when plants start to sprout leaves. Because of the warmer springs, some seasons plants will “leaf out” earlier than the migratory birds may arrive in Chicago. “There is more insect damage to the plants because you don’t have birds eating the insects that are attacking the plants, and the birds don’t forage as much because there is not as much food when they arrive,” he explains. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593864139/320770754_d57f531c8d_z_lai8gy.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A snowstorm hits Chicago. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While this mismatch of timing may not be a big deal in a single year, if it becomes a pattern, it spells a lot of problems for the ecosystem. For birds in particular, “when they arrive on their breeding grounds, they are not as not in as good condition,” Douglas explains, “they tend not to do as well breeding.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Douglas also points out that scientists “expect to see changes in distributions of southern species moving into this area,” including invasive species, which can impact farming and quality of life. This year, in particular, is supposed to be a bad year for ticks in the area, he says, “because it didn’t really get cold to knock back the tick population across the winter.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"All of this is very daunting, but Rachel remains hopeful. “There are things we can do right now,” she says. “We can work on reducing greenhouse emissions and make investments in clean energy and infrastructure while improving the energy efficiency of our fleets and home appliances.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We also need to make critical adaptations in our lives to help protect ourselves, and notably the most vulnerable, from events like wildfires, mudslides, and hurricanes. “We need to make sure to build infrastructure that can withstand climate change,” such as improving our energy grids to handle heat waves or building streets and railways to handle these events, Rachel says. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ultimately, “we always have hope that we can come out stronger in the end, it’s going to take perseverance and effort but we need to stick with it all.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Elisa Shoenberger is a writer and journalist living in Chicago. She recently produced ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.stitcher.com/podcast/in-this-climate/e/69098990","children":[{"text":"an audio piece ","italic":true}]},{"text":"on dogsledding and climate change for Indiana University's In This Climate podcast. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Climate change is happening where we least expect it

values.subtitle: Urban forestry is thriving in the country’s biggest city
values.author: Anmol Irfan
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Over the last year, Fridays for Future has gained traction, with founder Greta Thunberg even getting an opportunity to speak at the UN. While the campaign does address the climate crisis on a global scale, we cannot expect or ask countries at different stages of economic and social development to react with boundless enthusiasm to its ambitious goals. Nevertheless, many people are working tirelessly in these countries to combat climate change – and focusing only on solutions seen in Western countries gives little visibility to actions being taken in other regions. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Pakistan is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.un.org.pk/environment-day/","children":[{"text":"one of the six countries"}]},{"text":" that will be most affected by global warming. Despite Imran Khan’s success in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2018/07/pakistan-s-billion-tree-tsunami-is-astonishing/","children":[{"text":"planting one billion trees"}]},{"text":", there remains much more to be done if the country aims to move towards an environmentally sustainable future. Lack of action by government bodies, particularly those in charge of parks and public spaces, has seen ordinary residents take a stand. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594132091/66286229_10157169930095867_7964935954722979840_n_oy8ikw.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Karim bai Mosque's Urban Forest (Karachi)","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One initiative that really stands out is "},{"type":"link","url":"http://urbanforest.pk/","children":[{"text":"Urban Forest"}]},{"text":", an NGO that uses the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://forestcreators.com/miyawaki-method/","children":[{"text":"Miyawaki method"}]},{"text":" to plant groupings of native trees in small areas. The Miyawaki method involves planting different species of trees in a small pit, thus allowing them to grow at a pace ten times faster than normal. Urban Forest was brought to life in Karachi after "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-33358705","children":[{"text":"more than 1000 citizens"}]},{"text":" in the city lost their lives in the 2015 heatwave. The organisation aims to restore some of the natural wildlife of the city and prevent future heat waves by planting forests that can eventually become self-sustainable. Even if the organisation manages to form just 25 urban forests in the city,"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" it would be able to get rid of the urban heat island (UHI) effect that is formed in urban areas when human activity causes an unnatural rise in the surrounding temperature."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I spoke to founder Shahzad Qureshi about his thoughts on what needs to be done about the climate crisis in Pakistan. Where the problem lies, Shahzad emphasises, is in thinking that our responsibility ends with using one less straw or planting one sapling. “I am fond of improving the environment as an individual, whereas my services [ie. urban forestry] are available for anyone if they need my assistance”, he adds."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594131993/20934057_10155441538890867_1974841269053003257_o_nekl4p.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The community come together to be a part of the planting effort (Lahore)  ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Trees must be integrated into urban planning, Shahzad feels, but not just as pretty greenery. The kind of planting and growth we need is about understanding native species, and the benefits they can offer us - and each other - when given the right environment. Our gardens and parks contain self-sustaining ecosystems; we can’t just get rid of the plants within them when they become ‘unsightly’. Spacing trees far apart for aesthetic purposes greatly limits the environmental benefits they can bring. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Though the benefit of trees, particularly those planted using the Miyawaki method, in urban settings is undeniable - according to the organisation, ‘these forests can capture more carbon and address the urgency to restore ecosystems that encourage biodiversity’ - Urban Forest has certainly faced a few obstacles. It has been difficult to garner the support of local people, and also to work with government organisations. Despite the fact that the organisation currently has "},{"type":"link","url":"http://urbanforest.pk/projects/","children":[{"text":"seven active projects"}]},{"text":", many still do not understand what is needed to support forest growth. For example - Shahzad articulates - Urban Forest felt the need to adopt one park and work on it in a private capacity so as to achieve what they wanted to with the space. The team found that most people were wary of investing in this project since they felt they weren’t getting enough recognition out of it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, slowly but surely people are understanding and supporting the cause. The organisation has now expanded and created similar forests in housing areas in Lahore, and Shahzad says that an increasing number of people have started reaching out and asking to join. Following in the footsteps of Indian ‘eco-preneur’ "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ted.com/speakers/shubhendu_sharma","children":[{"text":"Shubhendu Sharma"}]},{"text":", who has used the same principles to plant small-scale, maintenance-free and biodiverse forests all over India with Urban Forest’s partner Afforest, Shahzad’s trees and tree-planters could signal big things for Pakistan and its boiling hot cities. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594132279/20988150_10155441535670867_6787756606321939924_o_gjeo8z.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Shubhendu Sharma at Lahore's first Urban Forest, Dream Gardens. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Anmol Irfan is the founder and editor of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/theperspectivemag/","children":[{"text":"Perspective Magazine","italic":true}]},{"text":", an online magazine and community platform that explores South Asian society through a lens of feminism and empowerment.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Images courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/groups/urbanforestpakistan/","children":[{"text":"Urban Forest","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

values.subtitle: A food hub in Portland is solving the business and logistical challenges of local food – and helping small farmers become a big deal.
values.author: Hannah Wallace
values.content: [{     "type":"paragraph",     "children":[         {             "text":"This article was originally published by ",             "italic": true         },         {             "type":"link",             "url":"https://sojoexchange.squarespace.com/home/how-portland-makes-local-food-work-for-everyone",             "children":[                 {                     "text":"the Solutions Journalism Exchange",                     "italic": true                 }             ]         },         {             "text":" and ",             "italic": true         },         {             "type":"link",             "url":"https://reasonstobecheerful.world/the-redd-portland-local-food-hub-small-farms/",             "children":[                 {                     "text":"Reasons to be Cheerful",                     "italic": true                 }             ]         },         {             "text":".",             "italic": true         }     ] },{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It’s Friday afternoon, and people on bikes and in cars are pulling up to an enormous red-brick warehouse in Portland’s Central Eastside to pick up their “Greater Good” boxes. Packed with local food, the $50 boxes are organized by local grocery chain New Seasons and wholesaler "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.hannahmwallace.com/hannahs_clips/2014/07/an-interview-with-david-lively-at-organically-grown-co.html","children":[{"text":"Organically Grown Co"}]},{"text":". A similar pick-up parade occurs on Wednesdays, when people cart away \""},{"type":"link","url":"https://localdockbox.com/","children":[{"text":"Dock Boxes"}]},{"text":"\" of fish, shrimp and crab from popular Oregon Coast seafood restaurant Local Ocean. And on Monday evenings, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.farmpunksalads.com/","children":[{"text":"Farm Punk"}]},{"text":", a farm in nearby Gresham, drops off its 50 community-supported agriculture (CSA) shares here, to be delivered the next day to eaters’ front porches via electric-assist trikes. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is the “new normal” at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ecotrust.org/project/the-redd-on-salmon-street/","children":[{"text":"the Redd on Salmon"}]},{"text":", an enterprise that’s optimizing Portland’s local food system and helping farmers, ranchers and fisherfolk adapt to a post-Covid reality. Even in the before times, the Redd on Salmon served as a solution to the infrastructure dilemma for small and mid-size farmers, who face all kinds of logistical challenges as they try to get food to consumers. Without the production volume to justify large-scale storage and transport systems, small farmers often spend a full day on the road each week, burning precious time and money driving to restaurants and supermarkets, dropping off their wares one at a time. They also need to market and often sell their own goods — skills many farmers don’t know the first thing about. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Redd solves all these problems in one fell swoop, acting as a distribution hub, an affordable storage space and a shared industrial kitchen. Ecotrust, the environmental think tank behind the Redd, also hosts a business accelerator, helping small farmers to scale up. Currently, the Redd supports more than 150 small to mid-size food-related businesses. From 2018 to 2019, the facility’s core tenants saw a 45 percent increase in job creation and a 12 percent increase in jobs at or above the living wage. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Medium-sizing small farms","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Covid-19 pandemic has exposed the failures of the industrial food system. Grocery stores have run short of pasta, canned beans, flour, yeast and meat. Farmers, unable to sell to school cafeterias and chain restaurants, are "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/11/business/coronavirus-destroying-food.html","children":[{"text":"dumping their milk and plowing under their onions"}]},{"text":". When "},{"type":"link","url":"https://thefern.org/2020/05/the-workers-are-being-sacrificed-as-cases-mounted-meatpacker-jbs-kept-people-on-crowded-factory-floors/?fbclid=IwAR2ukJWE8eU_ZBBjwB03EgyWdTXf_PdHaoxxqoFW9iX0O7gwhTpSwGPMpHk","children":[{"text":"20 gargantuan meat processing plants "}]},{"text":"were shuttered by coronavirus outbreaks, farmers were left with no choice but to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/14/business/coronavirus-farmers-killing-pigs.html","children":[{"text":"euthanize hundreds of thousands of pigs and millions of chickens"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As Michael Pollan noted in his "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2020/06/11/covid-19-sickness-food-supply/?utm_source=FERN+Newsletter+Service&utm_campaign=35fddf6479-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2019_07_09_08_03_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_c95f7f9b8b-35fddf6479-120474065","children":[{"text":"recent piece in "},{"text":"the New York Review of Books","italic":true}]},{"text":", our industrial food chain is broken, but local food systems, like the one championed and supported by the Redd on Salmon, are proving to be more resilient. “The advantages of local food systems have never been more obvious, and their rapid growth during the past two decades has at least partly insulated many communities from the shocks to the broader food economy,” Pollan writes."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Redd on Salmon is an integral part of this system. It is what is known as a food hub, a centrally located space that facilitates the aggregation, storage, processing, distribution and/or marketing of regionally produced food products. Not only does the block-long space provide farmers a 2,000-square-foot cold storage facility (half freezer, half refrigeration), it has offices and “dry storage” space so local companies like Ground Up PDX (nut butters) and Hoss Sauce (hot sauce) can stash boxes and product at a central location closer to their customers. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Redd solves the transport conundrum, too, with its main tenant, B-Line. A short-haul service with a fleet of electric-assist trikes, B-Line executes “last-mile” delivery without spewing carbon dioxide or jamming up the roads at delivery sites. Trike drivers load up their insulated trailers with up to 600 pounds of product and drop off food at restaurants, grocery stores and corporate cafeterias like AirBnB and Google. (B-Line also has one truck for deliveries that are further than three miles away. Founder and CEO Franklin Jones is saving up for an electric one.)  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By providing an all-in-one distribution hub to farmers who could never afford one on their own, the Redd was conceived as a way to support what food systems experts call “the agriculture of the middle.” Ag of the middle producers are larger than those who sell via local farmers’ markets or CSAs, but smaller than those supplying globalized commodity markets. With logistical and marketing support from the Redd, these producers can scale up and eventually serve institutional outlets like schools, hospitals, grocery stores and corporate offices."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"And lest you think this is a quirky boutique solution unique to Portlandia, know that there are over 350 food hubs around the country—from Durham, North Carolina to "},{"type":"link","url":"http://cherrycapitalfoods.com/","children":[{"text":"Traverse City, Michigan"}]},{"text":". A "},{"type":"link","url":"https://civileats.com/2016/06/20/want-to-launch-the-next-food-hub-heres-what-you-need-to-know/","children":[{"text":"traditional food hub "}]},{"text":"offers aggregation, marketing and often distribution for agricultural products. It might also serve as an incubator for micro-businesses. But the Redd takes it a step further, offering shared kitchens, a co-working space and even (across the street in the Redd East) an 8,000-square-foot event space with a state-of-the-art kitchen. Jim Barham, an agricultural economist at the USDA, calls the Redd a food hub on steroids."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Founded by Ecotrust, which has long been a champion of ag of the middle producers, the Redd runs a two-year "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ecotrust.org/project/ag-of-the-middle/","children":[{"text":"Ag of the Middle Accelerator Program"}]},{"text":" that helps smaller-scale farmers, ranchers and fisherfolk learn the basics of marketing, accounting, taxation and business structure — as well as helping them apply for "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.rd.usda.gov/programs-services/value-added-producer-grants","children":[{"text":"USDA value-added producer grants"}]},{"text":". As part of their orientation, participants in the accelerator tour the Redd’s facilities; graduates often end up using the space in some way. Over 70 producers have either graduated from the accelerator program or are in it right now. The current cohort of 17 businesses increased their sales by $1.5 million, collectively, after one year in the program. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Keeping it local","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Pre-pandemic, 30 to 40 percent of B-Line’s deliveries were to restaurants, corporate cafeterias or downtown businesses like Office Depot. Now that most of those are closed, the company has had to pivot, doing more frequent deliveries to New Seasons’ 18 area grocery stores, as well as serving as a physical hub for new direct-to-consumer services like the DockBox and Greater Good boxes. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“When the pandemic hit, there was a flurry of ‘panic buying,’” says B-Line founder and CEO Franklin Jones. As it did at many supermarket chains, demand skyrocketed at New Seasons, causing a backlog with mainline distributors like KeHE, UNFI and Supervalu. As a result, says director of brand development at New Seasons Chris Tjersland, these distributors limited the amount of product that could be shipped to each store, leaving them with empty shelves. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But because B-Line has pre-existing relationships with local farmers and producers, Jones was able to funnel products straight from these vendors through the Redd and into the aisles at New Seasons. Working with B-Line also allowed Tjersland and Jones to work directly with the producers of New Seasons’s private label line at a moment when traditional distribution channels were breaking down. While industrial farms were dumping perfectly good fruit and milk, B-Line was storing and delivering thousands of cases of Shepherd’s Grain flour, 800 cases of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.rallentipasta.com/about-1","children":[{"text":"Rallenti Pasta "}]},{"text":"and over 400 cases of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://scenicfruit.com/","children":[{"text":"Scenic Fruit"}]},{"text":" frozen berries. Tjersland even worked with local companies Brew Dr Kombucha and Straightaway Cocktails to make "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.brewdrkombucha.com/uncategorized/how-were-transforming-a-byproduct-of-kombucha-into-hand-sanitizer/","children":[{"text":"New Seasons hand sanitizer"}]},{"text":", which was stored at the Redd and delivered via B-Line. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The pandemic prompted other positive developments at the Redd. Redd Campus Manager Emma Sharer was tasked with how to optimize the Redd East event space, normally booked with weddings, natural wine fairs and food-focused conferences. In late March, she was doing an ab workout on the waterfront when she ran into Jacobsen Valentine, founder of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://civileats.com/2020/02/10/feed-the-mass-aims-to-bring-affordable-cooking-classes-to-everyone/","children":[{"text":"Feed the Mass"}]},{"text":", an affordable cooking school that teaches people how to make healthy meals from scratch."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The two struck up a conversation. “He was like, ‘My nonprofit is really struggling and I have this idea: how can we make meals for people who are missing access to them? Who are forced to buy fast food or packaged food?” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"They cooked up a collaborative plan. Ecotrust would donate its Redd East kitchen to Valentine two days a week, and he would cook meals for unhoused and food insecure folks around town.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://ecotrust.org/feeding-communities-during-a-crisis/","children":[{"text":"The FED Project "}]},{"text":"was born.
