For the past month, Valentine and a handful of volunteers have been cooking two meals a week at the Redd’s kitchen; each meal can feed 200 people. The meals are packed up individually and delivered to folks around town who need them. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ecotrust gave Valentine a small food budget and stipend. Plus, Sharer scored a huge food donation from Airbnb when the company’s Portland offices, including its cafeteria, closed in March. Since the company had been sourcing via the Redd, much of the food was high-quality and local. “There was cheese, sour cream, Camas Country flour, a lot of spices, chicken from "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.marionacres.com/","children":[{"text":"Marion Acres"}]},{"text":", pork products from "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.campfirefarms.com/","children":[{"text":"Campfire Farm"}]},{"text":", confit garlic, frozen berries,” says Airbnb’s food program manager Abby Fammartino, who estimates that the donation was worth $10,000 in total. Jacobsen and his crew made mac and cheese the first week and channa masala the next. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sharer and Valentine hope that this particular project will live on even after the pandemic is over. “If we were to get more funding, could some of that go towards paying BIPOC (Black, Indigenous and People of Color) farmers to purchase more product, supportive of the sourcing side of farming?” asks Sharer. “That’s our next step.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One thing is clear: the Redd campus — and its robust local food community — helped keep flour and hand sanitizer on New Seasons shelves while mainline distributors couldn’t keep up with the spike in demand. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“What it [the pandemic] made me realize is that the supply chain infrastructure is broken,” Tjersland from New Seasons says. Jones, who hasn’t had to lay off anyone at B-Line as a result of his increased business with New Seasons, agrees. “The whole pandemic really shone a spotlight on how resilient the local supply chain could be.” "}]}]
values.title: Making local food work for everyone

values.subtitle: Carbon offsetting has become a get-out-of-jail free card.
values.author: Esmé Audland
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In recent years it has been hailed as "},{"text":"the","italic":true},{"text":" thing to do, but the commercialisation of carbon offsetting has unsurprisingly become a get-out-of-jail free card for the rich. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Marketing campaigns sell it as a ‘quick-fix’, a trade-off for yet another holiday this year, a way to excuse immodest lifestyles. The "},{"text":"click here to offset your carbon emissions ","italic":true,"bold":true},{"text":"box is the most dangerous marketing tool of all. Responsibility immediately shifts off of the shoulders of the consumer. Thousands are forked out, and then you're given a gold star for donating the price of lunch at the local deli on top. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But how many people actually know how their carbon is offset? Before ticking that box, who actually takes the time to calculate how long it will be before said scheme can compensate for your flight?"}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Simply put, we need to increase the number of schemes to offset carbon, but more importantly we need to reduce our global carbon emissions by 45% by 2030 - as per the UN Environmental Programme. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carbon offset schemes were born out of the need to balance the emissions equation, allowing the largest polluters to compensate for their actions. Undoubtedly these schemes are necessary if we are to even have a shot at fixing the climate crisis. However, while a useful tool for industries making the transition to alternative energy and new technology, carbon offsetting is not the answer to the climate crisis. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For the wealthy, carbon offsetting is affordable. At "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.goldstandard.org/take-action/offset-your-emissions","children":[{"text":"Gold Standard"}]},{"text":", for example, forest regeneration projects average €13 per tonne CO². For those who have everything, this cost won’t make a dent. This transaction is as impactful as the loss of Monopoly money, and the consumer is removed from responsibility by a degree of separation. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594402814/marcin-jozwiak-NdMcz5d74Ak-unsplash_kk4vtt.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We need to stop creating emissions in the first place. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://landlifecompany.com","children":[{"text":"Land Life Company"}]},{"text":" carry out successful carbon offsetting programmes, including the reforestation of 50 hectares of degraded land in Northern Spain. This specific scheme invests 65% of total investment into local procurement and will capture 8,328 tonnes of carbon over 30 years. But to understand why carbon offsetting cannot be the answer we need to put these numbers in perspective:"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Globally we emit (at least) 36 billion tonnes of CO² per year "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. For argument’s sake, let’s say every project sequesters 8,328 tonnes of carbon over 30 years. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"3. To combat one year of carbon emissions we would need 4,322,767 more of these projects."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"4. And it would still take those projects 30 years to capture all the carbon produced in one year. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"5. Ultimately, trees that are planted today cannot grow fast enough. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read that again. Let that sink in. ","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On top of this, carbon offsetting - if carried out irresponsibly - can cause immediate "},{"text":"damage","italic":true},{"text":". "},{"text":"Ours to Save","italic":true},{"text":" "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feature?id=ckbl9gi8m005b0712nijhqv53","children":[{"text":"recently reported"}]},{"text":" on the effect of carbon offsetting by several Norway-based companies; they bought and ‘conserved’ forest in East Africa, but at the cost of forced eviction and food scarcity for thousands of local people. Countries that have barely contributed to the climate crisis are already bearing the brunt of it; we need to ensure this pattern does not recur with carbon offsetting. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By no means should carbon offsetting be stopped. The replantation of forests, peat bogs, marshes and other habitats is essential work, and so important in reestablishing ecosystems. Simply put, we need to increase the number of schemes to offset carbon, but more importantly we need to reduce our global carbon emissions by 45% by 2030 (according to the UN Environmental Programme). "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We need to shift our perceptions of carbon. Emissions may not be a tangible concept to those that live a sheltered existence in the financial capitals of the world, but to the millions of climate refugees displaced each year it is very real. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We live in a global society where travel is normalised. It is unrealistic to assume the world will stop flying tomorrow, but attitudes do need to change. Carbon offsetting is slowing this process down; the option to feel better about our behaviour is preventing us from changing it for good. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Esmé Audland is an English student at UCL. Passionate about environmental sustainability and plant-based eating, she works in marketing for the new vegan restaurant directory ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sayplants.com/","children":[{"text":"SayPlants! ","italic":true}]},{"text":"and promotes delicious, low-impact cuisine at ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://deliciouslyella.com/","children":[{"text":"Deliciously Ella","italic":true}]},{"text":".","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594402465/eric-muhr-W0Yp5uk2UnQ-unsplash_lynuqv.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Monopoly money for the rich

values.subtitle: Private sector capital is vital in the fight against climate change.
values.author: Jack Isaacs
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The fight against climate change has been one of few things to have benefited from the COVID-19 lockdown. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.globalcarbonproject.org/news/TemporaryReductionInCO2EmissionsDuringCOVID-19.html","children":[{"text":"The Global Carbon Project"}]},{"text":" has shown that carbon emissions may see an overall reduction of 7% in 2020 and, in certain countries, were down by an average of 26% during the peak of the pandemic. These are good statistics but Rome wasn’t built in a day and climate change won’t be conquered in 2020. The cumulative cost of repairing the environmental damage committed in the last century will be far more than whatever global governments have left in their coffers in the aftermath of a global lockdown. In a world where nothing comes for free and the public sector is running low on cash, impact investors are waiting patiently on the side lines."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://thegiin.org/impact-investing/need-to-know/#what-is-impact-investing","children":[{"text":"The Global Impact Investing Network"}]},{"text":" defines impact investments as, ‘investments made with the intention to generate positive, measurable social or environmental impact alongside a financial return.’ In simpler terms, whilst traditional investors focus solely on maximising profits, impact investors apply the same criteria to their investments but with the added objective of solving a social or environmental issue. Before delving into how impact investing can help in the climate crisis, we must first consider where it fits amongst the conglomerate of other technical terms thrown around by the financial sector to demonstrate its commitment to a fairer and cleaner planet earth. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bridgesfundmanagement.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Bridges-Spectrum-of-Capital-screen.pdf","children":[{"text":"The Bridges Spectrum of Capital"}]},{"text":", developed by one of the UK’s leading impact fund managers, conveys this better than most:"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594630170/jack_isaacs_ctclfg.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" Figure 1: The Bridges Spectrum of Capital. Image courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bridgesfundmanagement.com/","children":[{"text":"Bridges Fund Management","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On the far left of the table above we have those who focus solely on maximising profits, with no regard for the social or environmental impact of their investment decisions. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sustainable/responsible investors are those who’ve realised that investing in organisations that perpetuate environmental and social degradation may not be great for business or their reputation. They use Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) factors to reduce the likelihood of making unethical investment decisions and to ensure that they maintain a fair working environment within their own ranks. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Finally, we have impact investing, which has a spectrum all to itself. This ranges from ‘financial first investors’, who seek to make at least a market-rate of return alongside creating a social or environmental impact, to ‘impact first investors’, who are willing to make some financial sacrifice in order to address a societal challenge. My expectation and hope is that with time and the correct motivation, investors and businesses alike will continue to shift right across this table, to a point where impact investors are the only constituents."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How does all this equate to fighting climate change? The most important players when it comes to making a positive environmental impact are not the investors themselves, rather their investees. For example, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://boweryfarming.com/","children":[{"text":"Bowery Farming"}]},{"text":" raised "},{"type":"link","url":"https://boweryfarming.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/360049977434-Who-is-invested-in-Bowery-","children":[{"text":"more than $172.5 million"}]},{"text":" from several investors for their smart, indoor farms that save water, reduce pesticides and improve access to locally grown produce. Organisations such as these have the potential to generate large-scale returns, whilst providing an alternative to the existing unsustainable behaviours within the agriculture industry. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594630717/Crispy_Leaf_Lettuces_jwcoll.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Bowery is the modern indoor farming company growing food for a better future. Image courtesy of Bowery. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Additionally, impact-first investors such as "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.socialandsustainable.com/","children":[{"text":"Social and Sustainable Capital"}]},{"text":" have demonstrated the potential for creating positive environmental impact at a more local level. An "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.socialandsustainable.com/cases/plymouth-energy-community","children":[{"text":"investment in the Plymouth Energy Community "}]},{"text":"allowed for a community owned solar farm to be built on local derelict brownfield land. Not only has this generated enough renewable energy for 1000 homes annually but the rental payments will help to support regeneration activities in the local area. High impact organisations would be severely limited in their ability to operate sustainably without investments such as these. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Climate change has numerous causes and presents an abundance of issues for the natural world. There is no one size fits all solution. Consequently, different solutions need to be financed in different ways. Governments have a toolbox with which to fix social and environmental issues but have thus far been reluctant to use all their tools. Government funding, private sector capital and philanthropy are all financing methods with their own benefits and limitations and will all be needed in the fight against climate change. The private sector will play a fundamental role in this fight, where for-profit businesses can provide solutions at a scale that is simply out of reach within a government or philanthropic budget. If there’s one thing that can be said about capitalism, it’s that it is very good at creating capital. That capital needs to be directed towards solving both climate change and the mounting social issues that continue to grow following COVID-19. Impact investing facilitates that need."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" Jack Isaacs is a graduate in Social Sciences from the University of Bath. He has done extensive research on the UK’s social impact investing sector and is especially interested in how alternative methods of funding and for-profit business models can be used to alleviate social and environmental challenges.","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594631179/anne-nygard-OtqaCE_SEMI-unsplash_hctuad.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Impact Investing

values.subtitle: A conversation with Peter Okwoko, the Ugandan eco-entrepreneur making face shields sustainable.
values.author: Eliza Scott
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In May, I "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feature?id=cka6gqrs9000r07827twog1qd","children":[{"text":"wrote something"}]},{"text":" for "},{"text":"Ours to Save ","italic":true},{"text":"about Takataka Plastics - a Ugandan organisation innovating with plastic waste and, during the COVID-19 pandemic, making recycled face shields. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In June, I sat down in front of my computer to talk to Peter Okwoko, the co-founder of Takataka and "},{"type":"link","url":"https://hashtaggulu.org/","children":[{"text":"Hashtag Gulu"}]},{"text":" and the founder of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/AfriGreenSustain/","children":[{"text":"AfriGreen Sustain"}]},{"text":". When we spoke, Peter and his team had just donated 180 face shields to the Lira Regional Hospital. I was keen to know more. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594806755/0_iuznvl.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of Peter Okwoko. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For those not yet in the know, could you describe what you do with Takataka Plastics?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I first met Paige [Balcom] two years ago when she was doing research and by then I was teaching ICT and computer science at the university. I had already founded AfriGreen Sustain. A year later, someone again connected us again. A friend in the US told me about a lady who was passionate about helping the environment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"When she came back [to Uganda] we started doing research and experimenting with different kinds of plastic waste. We founded Takataka Plastics with the main goal of recycling plastic waste. We started in Gulu, and our target is to recycle up to nine tons of plastic waste every month. We then turn the plastic into construction materials. When COVID-19 affected business in Uganda, we started making face shields."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Why did you feel that it was important to start your companies in Uganda?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I love my country and we have a lot of challenges. I liked that I could use the knowledge I obtained in Denmark to come back home to it. When I came back to Uganda, I thought we could figure out the plastic waste on a local level. The major thing that we were looking at was how to change mindsets. We reached out to different primary schools and started eco-clubs, where kids are taught how to up-cycle. They learned how to make briquettes to cook with. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"What has been your experience working within an eco-organisation in Uganda and what has the reception been like locally and from the government?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"From local government, they have been welcoming – their offices are always open. When we started our "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.takatakaplastics.com/blog/greening-gulu-through-monthly-community-clean-ups-makegulugreen","children":[{"text":"Make Gulu Green initiative"}]},{"text":", they vowed to take over following our first few months of work. There are also improvements nationally as the Environmental Act, which was super old, now has new articles geared towards promoting sustainability."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594806845/88236447_3416864021678340_837094237001482240_n_f3vmr0.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/AfriGreenSustain/photos/a.1872201882811236/3416864018345007/?type=3&theater","children":[{"text":"AfriGreen Sustain","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How have you personally witnessed the effects of climate change, and what is the public perception of it?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There is still a lack of knowledge about the value of plastic waste. In Gulu, as in most cities in developing countries, people just litter. There is also a lack of sorting mechanisms for different categories of waste. People are not aware of the fumes released. Because of that, in the beginning of this year we started ‘Make Gulu Green’ with schools. This involves monthly community clean-up activities. We teach them about the different categories of waste and how to sort it. We continue to reach out to schools and we show people alternatives to single use plastics. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Since COVID hit we were unable to go ahead with that [project]. We also have been trying to harness the power of the internet and use radios to promote awareness."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"You also work on plastic waste reduction with your company AfriGreen Sustain and work with people who live on the streets with Hashtag Gulu. Could you tell me about your path to creating these companies?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I started with Hashtag Gulu, a community-led organisation, which I began while studying in Denmark after a friend posted a photo of children on the streets. I thought that we could take action beyond social media. We reunited some children with their parents. I also gave three young people shelter for a year then reunited them with their families. We decided to go forward and create the organisation in 2018. This year we got some grants which will enable us to upskill 50 street-connected children and young adults. They will be taught carpentry, construction and tailoring. When COVID-19 hit, it was challenging but we managed to continue to shelter all of them and continue on with teaching. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"AfriGreen started in 2016 with the aim of changing [people’s] mindsets. We held workshops and started campaigns. However, changing mindsets was one thing, but creating job opportunities and transforming waste was another. With Takataka Plastics, we want to create 30 jobs in a year for street-connected kids. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The beauty was that we already had Hashtag Gulu, which was working well with the kids. We were able to offer some of them jobs and provide them with psycho-social support. So far, we have recruited seven. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Where do you see your work going in the next 5 years?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I see Takataka expanding to different municipalities in Uganda as well as other East African countries like Kenya, South Sudan and Tanzania. I can see the company employing over 100 people that would otherwise be on the street."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After the success of the face-shields, we want to create a unit that specifically makes plastic medical equipment; we have realised that a lot of medical equipment that can be made out of plastic. I also want to get involved in low-cost energy."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lastly, do you have any advice for our readers about how to make more sustainable choices?","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We should not use wasteful products when we can. In instances where they are essential, we should try to reduce our consumption. We need to carry through with our ideals – to walk the walk. We need the drops in the ocean, for example saying ‘I refuse to use one plastic bag today’. That is enough."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594806733/Screen_Shot_2020-07-15_at_10.51.56_ygl52w.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On 4th July, Takataka donated 150 face shields to Moyo District Local Government COVID-19 Taskforce. Image courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/takataka_plastics/","children":[{"text":"Takataka Plastics","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Eliza Scott is from London and works at ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.rapidinnovation.co.uk/","children":[{"text":"Rapid Innovation Group","italic":true}]},{"text":", commercialising sustainable technologies, and ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://thefelixproject.org/","children":[{"text":"The Felix Project","italic":true}]},{"text":", a charity fighting hunger and food waste.","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Innovation Station

values.subtitle: I quit my dream career in fashion at 25. I know recent allegations about Boohoo are just the tip of the iceberg.
values.author: Katie Brown
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"When we choose what to wear, we are choosing how we express ourselves. For many of us, our clothing gives insight into our personality, character and mood more than any other medium. Its transformative abilities are unparalleled. I studied Fashion Management at university and scraped through a year of unpaid internships in order to become a fashion buyer, and that’s what I did for four years. In March 2020, I quit. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The job took its toll both physically and mentally. I was chronically stressed, underweight, underpaid and anxious. The impact I knew my industry was having on both people and the planet created a real moral dichotomy. I found it grossly unfair that it was necessary for others to suffer in order to satisfy the whims and pressures of modern living. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In 2017, WRAP reported that in the UK, 38 million items of new clothing were bought each week, while 11 million were sent to landfill in that same time period. That is the equivalent value of around £140 million of clothing sent to landfill each year. I couldn’t justify the job to myself any longer. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595009862/fast-fashion-moda-a_wxb9b2.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The #BoycottBoohoo campaign sprung into action on Instagram in July 2020, as a reaction to an "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/boohoos-sweatshop-suppliers-they-only-exploit-us-they-make-huge-profits-and-pay-us-peanuts-lwj7d8fg2","children":[{"text":"undercover report by "},{"text":"The Sunday Times","italic":true}]},{"text":", which asserted that garment workers in Leicester - making clothes for Boohoo and associated brands - were forced to work through the COVID-19 pandemic. They were also reportedly paid as little as £3.50 per hour, significantly less than half national minimum wage. Many are drawing links between the high COVID-19 infection rates in pockets of the UK such as Leicester and the presence of fast fashion factories. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The #BoycottBoohoo campaign saw the brand berated by the online community. They were called out on their alleged practices, as well as their insipid response to "},{"text":"The Sunday Times","italic":true},{"text":"' allegations. Realistically, I'd anticipate that we are nowhere near the end of this saga – and that there are many more brands yet to be rumbled by the omnipotent online environmental army. Quiz, another brand with the same low-price strategy, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://internetretailing.net/strategy-and-innovation/strategy-and-innovation/quiz-is-latest-fast-fashion-retailer-to-review-its-supply-chain-amid-low-pay-allegations-21695","children":[{"text":"has already launched an investigation"}]},{"text":" into its supply chain for the same reasons. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Even accounting for economies of scale, it’s extremely unlikely that a garment can be made ethically while retailing for less than £10."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The rush to avoid the same fate as Boohoo is evident. But is cutting ties with these factories the correct way forward? Could brands not work alongside factories to improve the quality of the working environment, and ensure minimum wage is paid? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Where will these brands now move production to? If they choose another factory that can match the prices of their previous supplier, what’s to say the working conditions won’t be the same there? Is it the responsibility of the brand to monitor production standards? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Another hashtag gaining traction online - one that also responds to the fashion industry walking away from its obligations in the midst of a global pandemic - is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.supportgarmentworkers.org/payup-fashion","children":[{"text":"#PayUp"}]},{"text":". As Traidcraft "},{"type":"link","url":"https://action.traidcraft.org.uk/fast-fashion-crisis-take-action","children":[{"text":"puts it"}]},{"text":", ‘UK fashion brands are cancelling orders with no notice and devastating the lives of workers in poor countries’. The Business & Human Rights Resource Centre surveyed 35 global fashion brands on how they’re protecting their workers during COVID-19 and found that 40% - including "},{"type":"link","url":"https://covid19.business-humanrights.org/en/companies/arcadia-group/?issue=328","children":[{"text":"Arcadia Group"}]},{"text":" (who own Topshop, Topman, Miss Selfridge and others) - made ‘no public commitment to pay for all completed orders’. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595010042/Topshop_1_zj7gdx.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Clearly, the problem is bigger than one dodgy factory. The COVID-19 crisis is exposing the cracks in the intricate web which conceals the production lines of many fast fashion businesses. It’s no secret within the industry that in order to sell clothes cheaply, they need to be made cheaply. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In my experience, the profit margin of a fashion retail business is usually somewhere between 40% and 60%. The cost of making a garment would therefore need to be around half of the retail price. The ‘make price’ needs to include all elements of a finished garment, including: fabric, trims (buttons, zips, etc.), care labels, swing tags, transport and labour. Even accounting for economies of scale, it’s extremely unlikely that a garment can be made ethically while retailing for less than £10."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"The supply chains in these cases are so complicated and carefully woven that it is almost impossible to point the finger at any one culprit. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As an ex-buyer, I know that these margins are non-negotiable. They inform the profit and loss account of a business. They also dictate the performance forecast, which in turn informs investors and share price. When a brand like Boohoo is found to be exploiting garment workers, it shouldn’t cause them to be “shocked and appalled” or “saddened”. Their business is built on the very premise of low cost labour. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The supply chains in these cases are so complicated and carefully woven that it is almost impossible to point the finger at any one culprit. Brands can easily pass blame onto factory owners, or claim that consumer demand is fuelling the market for excessive production and consumption. The UK government has done its best to shirk involvement in legislation, quashing numerous progressive reforms in recent months. This seems to be the crux of the issue; "},{"text":"if no one is responsible, who can fix the problem? ","bold":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595009865/karina-tess-H14pfhlfr24-unsplash_vh0crp.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Truly, there are no simple fixes in fast fashion. Changes need to come from inside the industry, both from individual employees and from top level management. Governments must take action, and consumers also have a part to play. ‘Voting’ with your money is the strongest signal that can be sent to a profit-driven business. A shift of consumer mindset away from mass consumption and towards valuing quality would also have a seismic effect on the market itself. Investors have power, and are at last waking up to the long term damage the climate crisis will cause to their portfolios. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The fast fashion revolution has been well underway for some time, outrage bubbling away in many forms. To see brands responding - albeit out of fear - to these campaigns is a big step. If the events of the last week are anything to go by, I have hope that the pot might start to boil over, and that the reforms we so desperately need will begin to come into play – especially if the media continues to use its influence to inform positive change, and consumers continue to apply pressure. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"If you’re wondering what can be done on an individual level, I’d urge you to keep it simple. I swear by "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/membership/video/2014/oct/29/vivienne-westwood-capitalism-clothing-video","children":[{"text":"the wise words"}]},{"text":" of Vivienne Westwood, "},{"text":"“Buy less, choose well, make it last”. ","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Katie Brown is an environmental campaigner and ex-fashion buyer. She is doing her best to learn and share as much as she can about slow fashion. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/slowitdown_baby/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: 'No fashion on a dead planet'

values.subtitle: Bees keep our agricultural systems alive. India is at the forefront of efforts to keep bees themselves alive.
values.author: Bindu Gopal Rao
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Bees: can’t live with them, can’t live without them. We might spend a lot of time avoiding their sting, but these creatures - with their exquisite hives and imposing queens - are foundational to ecosystems everywhere. Three quarters of crops across the world "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.fao.org/3/i9527en/i9527en.pdf","children":[{"text":"depend on pollinators"}]},{"text":", and honeybees are the most important pollinators we have. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The role of bees in pollination cannot be overemphasised; a colony of about 10,000 bees can pollinate a hectare of land, resulting in high agricultural yields. Apart from honey, bees make nectar, beeswax, pollen, propolis and so on. However, bees are at great risk from changing weather patterns - "},{"type":"link","url":"https://thehoneybeeconservancy.org/bees-climate-change/","children":[{"text":"which affect when plants flower"}]},{"text":". If a plant flowers several weeks early, a bee may still be dormant; without the plant’s nectar, bees are less likely to reproduce. And so the cycle of deterioration continues. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In India, several organisations are cropping up to protect bees - helping to reestablish them in greater numbers. In the process, they are guaranteeing financial prosperity for small-scale farmers, and harnessing the properties of the substances bees make to minimise plastic use. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"India needs around 7 million bee colonies to pollinate its key crops. Current estimates of bee colonies are much lower at only 1.5 million, and dwindling – so much so that farmers are having to rent bee colonies from apiaries. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mumbai’s "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.utmt.in/","children":[{"text":"Under The Mango Tree"}]},{"text":" promotes beekeeping to increase agricultural productivity, combining for-profit and not-for-profit structures. Beekeeping support is offered by the organisation and its partners to around 4,000 farmers and their families. For UTMT, tackling poverty and ecological threats go hand in hand. The team help small farmers gain market access, at the same time as ensuring that unsustainable honey hunting practices - which often kill bees - cease. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Another organisation, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://hoopoeonahill.com/","children":[{"text":"Hoopoe on a Hill"}]},{"text":", is located in a village near Kodaikanal in Tamil Nadu. Hoopoe consists of a group of women who work together to bring wild honey gathered by the Paliyans, a tribal community of the Palani Hills to customers across the country. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sweet business","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Honey is a delicious byproduct of each organisation’s bee-preservation efforts. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We filter this honey (to remove bits of wax and parts of the combs) and bottle it in glass jars. Besides honey, we also specialise in making a range of products out of beeswax such as candles, balms as well as a unique product called a beeswax wrap”, says Priyashri Mani, Hoopoe on the Hill’s co-founder. “A beeswax wrap in a natural and biodegradable alternative to one time use plastic cling film. It is an excellent way to store food.”"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595235154/Hoopoe_on_a_Hill_1_ipnng9.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Making beeswax wraps. Image courtesy of Hoopoe on a Hill. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Under the Mango Tree honey is 100% pure; it is not heat-treated, so as to preserve its all-natural components and benefits. It is all single origin - meaning that it can be traced easily back to its source. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Two origins come into play here - geographical and nectar origins.”, says Sujana Krishmamoorthy, executive director of Under the Mango Tree Society. “Geographical origin is seen in our Wildforest Honey, which comes from Tadoba National Park; our Himalayan Flora comes from the foothills of the Himalayas; our Desert Bloom comes from the Rajasthan area. In these cases, bees work on multiple flowers so the honey would have a combination of flavours.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“In the case of the Nectar Origin, bees usually use single flora nectar sources. Bees only move two kilometres from their hive, so they will source nectar from nearby orchards, such as Litchi. Thus, we can say that single origin honeys are the 'single malt' of honey,” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The test for flora origin is carried out via tests that trace the pollen contained in the honey. Nuances in taste, colour and texture originate from the nectar of the flora and vary with geography, temperature, location and humidity. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595235137/Sujana_Krishnamurthy_meenpi.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sujana Krishmamoorthy, executive director of Under the Mango Tree Society. Image courtesy of Under the Mango Tree. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sustainability Matters","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Indian Council of Agricultural Research reports that India needs around 7 million bee colonies to pollinate its key crops. Current estimates of bee colonies in India are much lower at only 1.5 million, and dwindling – so much so that farmers are having to rent bee colonies from apiaries. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Bees preserve the ecological balance and biodiversity of nature. Bees are responsible for the production of several varieties of nuts, berries and fruit, which are a vital food source for wild animals. Honey produced by bees is used as food, not only by humans but also by birds, animals and insects”, says Vijaya Pastala, CEO at Under The Mango Tree."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Bees build elaborate hives; however, they also provide shelter to other insects and animals. If bees were to disappear from our Earth, many, many species of animals and plants which depend on them would vanish as well. Improved agricultural productivity is directly linked to beekeeping.” "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Given that over 75% of the Indian population is engaged in smallholder farming, any intervention in this space can have a far-reaching impact. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Government Impetus","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To help the beekeeping industry, the Government of India has set up the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.indiafilings.com/learn/national-beekeeping-honey-mission-nbhm/","children":[{"text":"National Beekeeping Honey Mission"}]},{"text":". Its aims include ‘implementing harmless apiculture technologies’ and ‘improving the cultivation of food products through cross-pollination’. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As part of this project, Lakshmi Rao - a senior scientist and assistant director at the Central Bee Research and Training Institute - has conceptualised and launched a floral calendar showing area-wide floral distribution. The calendar will help farmers and beekeepers across India plan their beekeeping cycles at optimal locations. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"My main work was to identify the honey by their floral sources, whether it is unifloral (one flower) or multi-floral (multiple flowers), so the source of the honey is known. In this study I found out which flowers have more nectar, when they release pollen and how the bees work,\" says Lakshmi. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After surveying agriculture, horticulture and forestry and identifying the flowers that had been pollinated, she was able to chart the migratory routes of the bees. The project took four years to complete and covers most of the country. It is expected to make pollination significantly more convenient for honeybees, and thus to boost India’s honey generation and its farmers’ income. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"The effort is to naturally route the honeybees to feed on their choicest flowers in the most favourable area,\" senior researchers at CBRTI "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.msn.com/en-in/news/other/pune-based-institute-publishes-e2-80-98floral-calendar-e2-80-99-to-aid-beekeepers/ar-BB10K9sS","children":[{"text":"said in March"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595235101/IMG_20150211_135622_zh7ynf.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of Under the Mango Tree. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Challenge Factor","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, challenges continue. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"Beekeepers in India lack technical knowhow and are trained for a very short duration to understand aspects like bee health\", says Lakshmi. \"People are unaware of how to maintain the health of European honeybees, and problems caused by varroa mites can kill the younger bees.\" Apart from labour issues due to low availability of skilled workers, there are also financial problems to contend with. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, given that over 75% of the Indian population is engaged in smallholder farming, any intervention in this space can have a far-reaching impact. And the benefits of bee pollination for farmers? A staggering 50-100% improvement in yields. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It seems like everyone’s a winner – especially with the help of Hoopoe on the Hill, Under the Mango Tree, and Indian government-sponsored initiatives. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.bindugopalrao.com/","children":[{"text":"Bindu Gopal Rao ","italic":true}]},{"text":"is a freelance writer and photographer based in Bengaluru. Her interests include bird watching and looking for local and unusual angles in any destination. Environment is a cause that is very close to her heart. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/bindugopalrao/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Featured image courtesy of Lakshmi Rao. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Saving the Bees

values.subtitle: Residents of the UK’s big cities know it’s time to face up to this invisible killer
values.author: Alex Mistlin
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In February 2013, a young girl named "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jul/07/in-the-days-around-ellas-death-there-were-big-spikes-in-air-pollution","children":[{"text":"Ella Kissi-Debrah"}]},{"text":" died aged nine after 27 visits to hospital for respiratory complaints. Her home was just 25 metres from the South Circular Road in Lewisham, London. In 2014, an inquest determined that Ella died due to acute acute respiratory failure and severe asthma. But after new evidence on local pollution levels came to light, that verdict was quashed and the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2019/may/02/ella-kissi-debrah-new-inquest-granted-into-air-pollution-death","children":[{"text":"High Court granted a new inquest"}]},{"text":", which will take place later this year."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"COVID-19 has already killed thousands in the United Kingdom. 45,318 at the time of writing to be precise. But people did not start dying of nasty respiratory illnesses in February 2020. People have been dying premature deaths - because of pollution - for decades. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The death of Ella Kissi-Debrah was a tragedy waiting to happen. This "},{"type":"link","url":"http://theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/aug/31/proof-air-pollution-killed-my-daughter-ella-new-inquest","children":[{"text":"view is shared by her mother"}]},{"text":", now a passionate campaigner for reform on the issue. Her case is clear; levels of NO² in most urban areas of the UK have been illegally high since 2010 and according to NHS Medical Director, Stephen Powis, air pollution contributes to around 40,000 premature deaths every year. Even before COVID-19, Britain’s toxic - "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/apr/01/air-pollution-falling-london-millions-still-exposed","children":[{"text":"and illegal"}]},{"text":" - levels of air pollution represented a permanent public health crisis. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595447147/TELEMMGLPICT000168315219_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqaHVqxy07MatZBwJp4oicTfQYXXuOqxbkqKzBIujJAkk_u9tsby.webp","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ella Kissi-Debrah.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"What’s more, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jul/13/compelling-evidence-air-pollution-worsens-coronavirus-study","children":[{"text":"evidence is building"}]},{"text":" to suggest that high levels of air pollution worsen the impact of respiratory diseases like COVID-19. This is because long-term exposure to toxic air eventually leads to the development of the same chronic heart and lung conditions that make people particularly susceptible to the onset of COVID-19 – while short-term exposure may irritate the lungs and increase the risk of infection. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The extraordinary lockdown measures enforced by the UK government in recent months provide the template for the policy response required to adequately lower toxicity levels. In this light, the nationwide shutdown can be seen as a significant, if unintended, stride towards reducing air pollution. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/mar/27/coronavirus-uk-lockdown-big-drop-air-pollution","children":[{"text":"Data analysis from the University of York"}]},{"text":" shows reduced levels of pollution - particularly at hotspots such as Marylebone in London - as a result of the imposed restrictions to non-essential travel and industrial activity."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"And indeed, the overall situation is so frustrating because the solutions are so obvious. Policy-makers aren’t struggling for bright ideas; they’ve been unwilling to expend political capital on the issue. This is simply inadequate where a public health emergency as universal as air pollution is concerned. What’s required is radical political action and wholesale legislative change. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595447192/GettyImages-1135759652_yaxpih.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"ULEZ needs to be expanded.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This means expanding London's low and ultra-low emission zones; it means increasing efforts to monitor existing levels of air pollution; and at the end of the day it means restructuring society and the economy to reflect a renewed focus on public health over the ‘growth at all costs’ attitude that has created this dire situation. Sure, these measures might not be the most popular but it’s important to recognise the urgency of this post-COVID moment. Public health will be a key focus for both national and local government for months, if not years, to come. Motorists have lungs, too. So do their kids."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For the time being at least, the air we breathe will be cleaner and the streets will be safer as a result. Indeed, some scientists have gone as far as to suggest that the number of premature deaths avoided due to cleaner air "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/mar/17/air-pollution-likely-to-increase-coronavirus-death-rate-warn-experts","children":[{"text":"might outstrip the number of people killed "}]},{"text":"by COVID-19 itself. But as restrictions continue to ease over the coming weeks it’s important that we don’t simply allow toxic air to return to our cities. The "},{"type":"link","url":"https://uk-air.defra.gov.uk/library/reports.php?report_id=1005","children":[{"text":"UK government’s own expert advisors"}]},{"text":" believe that further investigation of the link between dirty air and the pandemic is “urgently required” and may be relevant to how it is managed moving forward. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The impact of COVID-19 has already been devastating but the pandemic has the potential to be a catalyst for positive change. People have been dying painful and premature deaths for years but only now that a novel respiratory disease has brought the world to a standstill are people calling for radical action on air pollution. Without a green recovery, there will be many more preventable deaths from toxic air. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Alex Mistlin is a recipient of the Guardian's prestigious ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/the-guardian-foundation/2019/oct/01/meet-the-scott-trust-bursary-students-201920","children":[{"text":"Scott Trust Bursary","italic":true}]},{"text":" and has bylines in VICE, Huck and the New Statesman. You can follow him on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/amistlin","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: COVID-19 must lead to a radical rethink on air pollution

values.subtitle: In 1990, a group of surfers got together to protest the UK’s unclean beaches. Now they have a new enemy: plastic.
values.author: Sadia Nowshin
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Of all the experiences that would motivate you to clean up the oceans, surfing through seas of sewage is pretty high up the list. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A community with a dedication to protecting oceans, beaches and wildlife and a determination to persevere with their mission until the natural world is completely clean, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sas.org.uk/","children":[{"text":"Surfers Against Sewage "}]},{"text":"(SAS) has quickly become one of the UK’s most active and successful environmental charities.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The organisation began as a surfing community whose experience in polluted waters included often swimming through raw sewage. Having had enough of the unsafe environment in which they swam, they launched a campaign calling for UK beaches to be held to a higher hygiene standard. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595604634/Surfers_Against_Sewage_Beach_Clean_Perranporth_mmqwic.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Following years of determined campaigning, the community saw a great growth in numbers as more beach-lovers joined the fight. The UK now boasts some of the cleanest beaches in Europe; compared to the 27% of beaches that passed the Bathing Water Directive’s minimum standards in 1990 when the campaign began, in 2016 this rose to a massive 98.5% pass rate. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Through cultivating a community with a common mission to clean up the environment, Surfers Against Sewage have volunteer teams in every corner of the country, working to challenge threats to the natural world across the UK. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jessica Morris is one of the six volunteer regional reps based in the London team who “have all had very different backgrounds and relationships with the ocean” but are “all united in our love and passion to protect the ocean and to build a sustainable future”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"She shared the main aspirations of the initiative: “Net-Zero by 2030, End single-use plastic pollution on UK beaches by 2030, 30% of the ocean & all UK marine protected areas to be 'highly Protected' by 2030, and to end sewage discharge into UK bathing waters by 2030!”."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595604800/trash_on_the_beach_txroow.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, while SAS will always challenge threats to water quality and have since extended to consider issues of climate change and coastal development, there is a new threat to the seas that they have prioritised: plastic. An estimated 12 million tonnes of litter and plastic enter the world’s oceans every year and for SAS, throwaway plastic is the new sewage polluting the seas. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The collective boasts an impressive record of successes so far: “Over the past year or so we have made some really big leaps in building a community here in London. When I first began as a rep in 2018, we would be lucky to get 10 volunteers coming along to a beach clean. On our last Autumn Beach Clean event we had over 70 people arrive, and over 130 bags of pollution collected!”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A significant part of the problem faced tends to be the “'out of sight, out of mind' approach” that is common across society, particularly in the capital. With the rapid pace of modern life, people are “very disconnected from their impact on the ocean”. To approach this, SAS’ London team “are working hard to collaborate with as many people, schools, charities and businesses to help educate and invite everyone to make a difference”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Getting involved can be daunting, and not knowing where to start can hold people back from engaging with environmental activism. Jessica emphasised that unity is the key to successfully tackling the problem: “No matter how much or how little you can do, everyone can help. But the key to successfully saving our ocean is to stand together”. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595604920/skhbgt8x-1465301710_lk6xut.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Though the ecological outlook has become increasingly worrying as our impact on the Earth is revealed, SAS are determined that action can still be taken. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We need the Government to put the environment at the forefront of their policies. We need activists to unite. We need the manufacturers to take responsibility for the amount of pollution they produce. And finally, we need to educate the people. Scientists believe we have only 10 years to save our ocean - there has never been a more urgent time to educate, campaign, and demand change!”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Want to be part of making that change? Follow the team on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/surfersagainstsewage_london/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":", ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/sas_london_","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":" and ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/SurfersAgainstSewage","children":[{"text":"Facebook","italic":true}]},{"text":", join a cleanup, sign the #EndSewagePollution ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sas.org.uk/endsewagepollution/","children":[{"text":"petition","italic":true}]},{"text":", or become a ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sas.org.uk/donate/","children":[{"text":"member","italic":true}]},{"text":" to get involved.  ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sadia Nowshin is a Junior Reporter at #ThisMuchIKnow News. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/sadianowshin_","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Surfing through sewage

values.subtitle: Local-led initiatives are just a temporary salve when it comes to Nigeria’s hunger crisis.
values.author: Funmi Lijadu
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"According to the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.globalhungerindex.org/nigeria.html#:~:text=In%20the%202019%20Global%20Hunger,See%20overview%20of%20GHI%20calculation%5D.","children":[{"text":"Global Hunger Index"}]},{"text":", Nigeria is the 24th most hungry out of 114 qualifying countries. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted its existing food security crisis – with some organisations adapting quickly to provide short-term solutions. However, the work of charities like Lagos-based "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/feedikoyi/","children":[{"text":"FeedIkoyi"}]},{"text":" cannot be a substitute for the resolution of wider structural issues. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"FeedIkoyi"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/feedikoyi/","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":", founded by fashion designer Adeju Thompson at the beginning of the pandemic in response to the increased food shortages he anticipated in his local community, distributes packs of free food to the city’s most vulnerable. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" “People really rely on the meals”, said Adeju to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ASMWoa9BgRc","children":[{"text":"Arise News","italic":true}]},{"text":". “I met someone who said they hadn’t eaten for two days before [FeedIkoyi] came.”"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596013215/Screen_Shot_2020-07-29_at_09.59.53_uampeb.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Meals ready for distribution. Image courtesy of FeedIkoyi. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The initiative has grown from distributing 100 meals a day to feeding close to 1,000 people daily in Ikoyi and Lagos Island. Primarily distributed in the Obalende neighbourhood, these meals have become a lifeline for construction workers, hawkers, petty traders, and day labourers who are jobless during the lockdown. And the charity doesn’t just feed the community – it is also providing Lagosians with jobs, and granting an income to those who might otherwise be unemployed. In April this year, ex-convict Hyacinth Babatubo was employed as part of FeedIkoyi’s staff. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The initiative’s financial support to locals is a critical source of relief at the moment. However, numerous challenges to ensuring food sustainability in Nigeria persist. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At the heart of Nigeria’s food insecurity is the nation’s over-reliance on oil revenue. The discovery of crude oil in Nigeria, and the wealth that came from it, led to the agricultural sector being underdeveloped and underfunded. Subsequent rural-urban migration has led to a labour drain from the agricultural industry as young, able-bodied individuals seek opportunities in cities rather than the countryside."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596013369/4560583164_39440b8339_z_nuural.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Oil spills are a big problem. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nigeria has become "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.scirp.org/Journal/PaperInformation.aspx?PaperID=81175","children":[{"text":"‘a major food importing nation’"}]},{"text":" partially because of this. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nigerian agriculture would do better if nationals were doing most of the processing, packaging and distribution of the food consumed by the public, but this is not currently happening. 2018 saw Nigeria import almost four billion dollars worth of food and drink, perpetuating the underdevelopment of local agriculture. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Pollution is another critical factor. Urbanisation has encroached on land, air and water, and "},{"type":"link","url":"https://allafrica.com/stories/202006290296.html","children":[{"text":"there are on average five oil spills a day in the country "}]},{"text":"– destroying vegetation and agricultural land. A mixture of lack of education on sustainability and inefficient law enforcement means that unsustainable food production and urban waste is mismanaged. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In Northern states, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ft.com/content/02da0292-3268-11e8-b5bf-23cb17fd1498","children":[{"text":"clashes between herdsmen and farmers"}]},{"text":" further limit effective production. Farmers are left devastated and discouraged by frequent violence. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Feedikoyi is an encouraging boost to Nigeria’s food security. Through redistributing food resources to counteract hunger during the pandemic, the initiative is doing very important work - perhaps even saving lives. However, neighbourhood outreach is no substitute for adequate investment and infrastructure – and once things return to ‘normal’, the country’s government has work to do. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596013171/Screen_Shot_2020-07-29_at_09.58.45_ia2owv.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of FeedIkoyi. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Making food accessible to all and doing it sustainably poses a great challenge. As Nigeria’s population continues to rise, so will the severity of its food security challenges and considerations. Community efforts like FeedIkoyi provide much-needed solace and support in the meantime. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://funmi-lijadu.squarespace.com/","children":[{"text":"Funmi Lijadu","italic":true}]},{"text":" is a writer and collage artist highlighting the stories that are less told. She is invested in humanity, the histories that led to our present, and imagining better futures.","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Food security or oil supremacy?

values.subtitle: An in-depth look at Rishi Sunak's proposals.
values.author: Sharlene Gandhi
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As we slowly emerge from the pandemic, and move gingerly towards another, impending recession, Chancellor Rishi Sunak has announced that "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gov.uk/government/news/pm-a-new-deal-for-britain","children":[{"text":"£5 billion will be plugged back into the UK’s economy "}]},{"text":"to recover the damage from the coronavirus crisis. The New Deal - likened by Prime Minister Boris Johnson to Franklin D. Roosevelt’s New Deal for the USA following the Great Depression - is an infrastructure-centric recovery plan that will aim to enhance both public and private infrastructure projects, while injecting back into the British economy. The reforms, accompanied by the slogan ‘Build, Build, Build’, will see radical, fast-tracked funding released for ‘shovel-ready’ projects, which allows critical construction and infrastructure to be planned, approved and financed efficiently."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Government has emphasised its desire to “build back better, build back greener, [and] build back faster,” following pressure from "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.carbonbrief.org/coronavirus-tracking-how-the-worlds-green-recovery-plans-aim-to-cut-emissions","children":[{"text":"200 major firms calling for a green recovery"}]},{"text":", and widespread public consensus that COVID-19 presents us with an opportunity to pivot our economy and society towards an eco-centric system. Focus areas include the construction and improvement of public buildings, such as hospitals, schools and prisons, as well as planning for electric vehicle supply chains, charging networks, and ultra-low/zero emissions aircraft. A portion of the budget is also "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.edie.net/registration/regwall.asp?mid=145614&origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Eedie%2Enet%2Fnews%2F11%2FDefra%2Dunveils%2Dnatural%2Dcapital%2D%2Dassessment%2D%2Dfunding%2Das%2Dpost%2DBrexit%2Dgreen%2Drecovery%2Dshapes%2Dup%2F&title=Defra+unveils+natural+capital+%27assessment%27+funding+as+post%2DBrexit+green+recovery+shapes+up","children":[{"text":"dedicated to outdoors projects"}]},{"text":", such as reforestation and conservation, in an effort to both improve the UK’s natural environments and preserve jobs in the conservation and forestry sectors. £100 million has also been set aside for research and development into Direct Air Capture (DAC) technology, that aims to ‘suck’ carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere for reuse or permanent storage. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Given that the UK is the first major economy to commit to total decarbonisation/net zero emissions by 2050 in legislation, the economic recovery package aims to be in line with the UK’s 2008 Climate Change Act. Alok Sharma, the Secretary of State for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) has also been appointed as the President of COP26, and so the UK must continue to demonstrate both thought and industrial leadership in the realm of environmental sustainability. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192094/cover102_ncudgj.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Chancellor Rishi Sunak. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How does the economic recovery plan prioritise green growth?","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Heating currently constitutes "},{"type":"link","url":"https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201919/cmselect/cmsctech/287/28702.htm","children":[{"text":"a third of the UK’s emissions"}]},{"text":", making it a critical sector to decarbonise. In July, Rishi Sunak unveiled a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-53313640","children":[{"text":"£2 billion grant scheme"}]},{"text":" to encourage homeowners to invest in insulation and other energy-saving improvements as part of the COVID-19 recovery plan. The aim would be twofold: not only would homeowners see lowered energy bills, but local special suppliers and tradesmen would also see an uptake in business. The poorest homeowners in the UK will have access to additional funds to undertake this work, but campaigners have also argued that the omission of renters inevitably leaves the poorest out of this deal. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Professor Martin Freer is currently in the process of setting up the National Centre for Decarbonisation of Heat at the University of Birmingham, and believes that “£2 billion is nowhere near the scale required to deliver [low-carbon heat] for 25 to 28 million homes” in the UK. He also highlights the need for funding to be spread across different home energy efficiency solutions, questioning whether “the industry is ready to respond to funding rather than allowing it all to disappear into loft insulation.” Insulation needs to go hand-in-hand with heat delivery from renewables, he points out. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192433/8218016433_2c0eeac15d_b_peih3p.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" Insulation needs to go hand-in-hand with heat delivery from renewables.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Prioritisation of local growth projects - and thus local jobs - will allow for power and funding to be decentralised, improving ‘local comparative advantage’. Widespread localisation is not only critical to decarbonisation, but also allows for funds to be allocated where issues are most critical, such as in the case of flood defences. Strengthening local economies reduces their reliance on both exports and urban financial centres. Empty commercial properties will be rapidly repurposed in order to support the revival of the local high street, which will in turn reduce the need for new property development on green field lands."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://greennewdealgroup.org/the-green-new-deal-bill/","children":[{"text":"The Green New Deal Group"}]},{"text":" identifies "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/green-bond.asp","children":[{"text":"green bonds"}]},{"text":" as a means to facilitate this critical redistribution of power, whilst "},{"type":"link","url":"https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201919/cmselect/cmsctech/287/28702.htm","children":[{"text":"the Government’s report on Clean Growth"}]},{"text":" spotlights the need for clean energy partnerships between local authorities and private companies to provide affordable energy in local areas. Critical to providing local governments with more funding and resources is an overhaul of the ways in which local government functions, according to Professor Free. Decarbonisation “requires strong collaborations between local government, which either does not have enough funds or is under-resourced, and therefore does not have a chance to think about new and strategic infrastructure.” "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192611/1200px-Cudworth_-_shops_on_Barnsley_Road_dzdeej.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"High streets need to be regenerated. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How could the plan be improved from a climate perspective? ","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At present, although the pressing need for a green recovery has been addressed, the UK Government risks paying lip service and even edging into greenwashing territory. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Decarbonisation in certain areas needs to go hand-in-hand with complete divestment from some of the most polluting sectors – fossil fuels being the primary example. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.carbonbrief.org/coronavirus-tracking-how-the-worlds-green-recovery-plans-aim-to-cut-emissions","children":[{"text":"Nigeria and Germany"}]},{"text":", for instance, have outlined targeted COVID recovery plans that centre investment in renewable energy sources, despite the former being a major oil economy. This tension between decarbonisation and divestment is a symptom of a wider problem, whereby a ‘Build, Build, Build’ focus from the UK Government does not do enough to highlight what needs to be cut back. Observations of the UK’s emissions reduction since the 2008 Act have shown that sectors such as transport, heating and agriculture have made little progress thus far; investing heavily in the ‘net new’ or in techno-centric development risks undoing the little progress that has been made from an emissions angle. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Divestment requires relatively radical policy and infrastructural reforms. Alongside fossil fuels, another significant sector needing this reform is aviation. However, alongside oil and gas, the aviation industry has been "},{"type":"link","url":"https://neweconomics.org/2020/06/crisis-support-to-aviation-and-the-right-to-retrain","children":[{"text":"one of the largest recipients of bailout loans"}]},{"text":" from the Bank of England, with British Airways receiving £300 million and EasyJet £600 million. Perhaps even more shocking is the fact that emissions measurements as per the UK’s Climate Change Act currently "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/environmentalaccounts/articles/netzeroandthedifferentofficialmeasuresoftheuksgreenhousegasemissions/2019-07-24","children":[{"text":"does not account for emissions from international air travel"}]},{"text":". If we are already behind target, and still to account for this proportion of our emissions, the alarm is beginning to sound. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192711/unnamed_vhrivn.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Aviation needs reform. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The focus of both the Climate Change Act and subsequent amendments has been largely on heavy polluting industries, with clear "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.wsp.com/en-GB/projects/2050-industrial-decarbonisation-roadmaps","children":[{"text":"decarbonisation roadmaps "}]},{"text":"created for refining, chemicals, iron and steel, cement, ceramics, food and drink, pulp and paper and glass. Financial incentives to decarbonise are, at present, limited to heavy polluting industries. For example, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ec.europa.eu/clima/policies/ets_en","children":[{"text":"the Emissions Trading Scheme"}]},{"text":" allows each participating enterprise to hold a certain number of carbon credits, gradually decreasing those credits in the run up to 2050, as well as allowing companies to trade credits between themselves. However, other critical industries have been omitted from the decarbonisation journey in the new recovery plan, such as fisheries and agriculture. Agriculture could be shaped up into a solution to the climate crisis – but with farming and unsustainable land use still accounting for both carbon emissions and high water usage, targeted guidance to move British agriculture to a regenerative and innovative industry needs to be prioritised."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In addition, the Government has yet to acknowledge the concept of ‘embedded carbon’, which accounts for emissions over the whole production process of a particular good, primarily the raw materials that go into production. It could be argued, then, that every product produced has an element of embedded carbon, and according to Abbie Morris and James Omisakin of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://compareethics.com","children":[{"text":"Compare Ethics"}]},{"text":", the retail sector is the big elephant in the room. The pair co-run a platform that champions transparency in brands’ supply chains, and believe that “the retail sector is not innovating enough. It contributes to the problem of greenhouse gases, biodiversity loss, and species removal.” Fast fashion is a primary example of where retail slips under the emissions radar; while the products themselves do not emit, the production process is highly polluting and has dire impacts for human wellbeing and rights in garment production factories. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Abbie and James also stress that the service industry has been entirely ignored, despite making up over 80% of the UK’s economy. Services encompass a variety of people and organisations in sectors such as business and management, healthcare, education, consulting, administration, entertainment and property. While services in and of themselves might not be releasing carbon emissions, they either interface with industries that do have high emissions, or are part of supply chains that rely on other forms of environmental damage, such as land damage, water wastage or illegal dumping of toxic waste. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192978/8249606304_905ef84dd4_b_zh9ywf.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Fast fashion hides a host of human rights and environmental violations. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Shifting standards","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://neweconomics.org/2020/07/building-a-green-stimulus-for-covid19","children":[{"text":"The New Economics Foundation"}]},{"text":" reported that a rebound in carbon emissions has already been observed as the economy begins to ramp back up after widespread lockdowns. Professor Freer’s perspective is that the UK Government’s recovery plan “is a signal of intent [towards a green economy], but there is a need to do something more rapidly.” There is, then, a substantial risk that the Government’s recovery plans simply take us back to a pre-pandemic world, rather than taking introspective action to drive sustainable change for a long-term recovery. Industry’s over-reliance on policy to drive environmental action also shows that self-motivation and self-regulation are not reliable options, a sentiment which Abbie and James of Compare Ethics echo: “We need to build a business case for sustainability and raise standards”, they say. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This, firstly, requires a shift in mindset.
