The Green New Deal Group suggests starting by “ending the fixation on growth.” On a country level, we could follow the footsteps of China to temporarily abandon GDP targets while the economy recovers from the coronavirus, or take a leaf out of New Zealand’s book and abandon GDP targets altogether, in favour of measures that centre people and the environment. On a business level, the model of shareholders and investors expecting bigger and better returns every year also needs to change. The metrics of success need to centre human, social and environmental wellbeing through supply chains, and reinvesting into the business to ensure this is taking place. Similar to Compare Ethics, transparency must become a core value on which companies are judged."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This shift in mindset must, however, be supported by policy to ensure that all businesses in a particular sector, and thus the economy as a whole, are held accountable for their piece in the puzzle. This fundamentally challenges one of the core tenets of capitalism, which is the establishment of competitive markets, because climate change requires collaborative and complementary action. Abbie and James also highlight the inefficacy of auditing as a means of curbing climate emissions: “If [business owners] know when somebody is going to turn up to audit a factory, it leads to inefficient data,” they state. The short-term changes made for an audit or inspection need to be sustained. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596193084/1200px-Kate_Raworth_auditorium_jxyplh.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kate Raworth's 'doughnut model' for economics is a potential path forward. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In addition to sector-specific legislation, reporting requirements, taxation and fines, the Government should move towards incentivising new models of working that actively encourage participative action. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/bills/cbill/2017-2019/0365/190365.pdf","children":[{"text":"The Decarbonisation and Economic Strategy Bill"}]},{"text":", presented by former leader of the Green Party, Caroline Lucas, outlines the need for “public enterprises, municipal enterprises, worker-owned enterprises, co-operatives, community-owned enterprises, and local private ownership”; so, while the UK’s coronavirus recovery plan touches on localisation initiatives, true decarbonisation is likely to need bottom-up system change through radical democratic and community participation, ensuring adequate wealth redistribution."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Unfortunately, any government’s legislation or economic recovery plan pales against the monolith that is the multinational corporation. Similar to the conundrum of which country should account for the emissions from an international flight, the UK recognises in its climate legislation that it is part of a globalised economy over which it has relatively little control, but still must compete within. This, coupled with the looming threat of Brexit and the recession, means that the UK is unlikely to pass any truly radical legislation, for fear of driving away the international businesses that currently have a home in London - a move labelled "},{"type":"link","url":"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/889037/Government_Response_to_Consultation_on_Future_of_UK_Carbon_Pricing.pdf","children":[{"text":"carbon leakage"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"COVID-19 has brought the world together - although in crisis - and presents us with a rare opportunity to move forward collectively into a more efficient, just and clean world. The UK’s economic recovery plan is sowing the seeds for a long road to green recovery within the borders of the country, but much more has yet to be done by the international business and development worlds. The UK’s role, then, needs to extend to becoming thought leaders and industry leaders in this space, bringing the rest of the world on the journey to sustainability with them. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sharlene Gandhi is a reporter at ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://couriermedia.co/","children":[{"text":"Courier Media","italic":true}]},{"text":". Her writing focuses on the intersections between sustainability and climate, food/agricultural systems, and responsible corporate business. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: How green is the UK's new deal?

values.subtitle: A new school of farmers are regenerating and rewilding land, starting with the soil.
values.author: Al Howard
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Unless you are a biologist, a farmer or an avid gardener, the topic of soil health may seem uninspiring. With slug pellets and fertilisers available in any nearby garden centre, barren land feels like a problem from a long-lost Biblical past or a George Miller franchise. Yet, advocates of regenerative agriculture have begun to consider farming from the soil up, situating healthy "},{"text":"living","italic":true},{"text":" soil at the heart of all life, and providing a compelling solution to the greatest issues faced by our generation: species extinction and climate change."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The theory is, in principle, simple. By disposing of disruptive practices such as tilling (the digging and overturning of soil) and the use of synthetic fertilisers and pesticides, and by introducing a diverse range of cover crops to protect and nourish the soil, farmers are able to grow better quality food. Perhaps the most significant result of this method is that more carbon can be safely stored in topsoil, reducing the rising levels in the atmosphere. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"At the centre of these studies is a fundamental understanding that life fosters more life; meaning that healthy, living soil provides a natural foundation for a diverse and wholesome food chain. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In recent history we have become aware of the critical effect of consumer culture on the planet, but in even more recent history buzzwords such as ‘sustainability’ have taken a hold. They have been overused and subsequently devalued, leading author and farmer Gabe Brown to ask: “Why would we want to sustain a degraded ecosystem?”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Consequently, the challenge for many modern farmers is not to merely farm ‘sustainably’, but to rehabilitate their ecosystems and by extension, the soil. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596547025/8053614949_982fecf12d_k_1_ju4ivz.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Farmers are working from the ground up. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Rooted in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://savory.global/","children":[{"text":"Allan Savory’s investigation into holistic management"}]},{"text":" in the 1980s, this approach to farming situates man within the ecosystem, rather than above it. Holistic management aims to recognise the interrelation between man, plants, animals and the land; primarily through the water cycle, the mineral cycle (which includes the carbon cycle), energy flow and community dynamics. Over the past five years, Savory’s "},{"text":"Holistic Management ","italic":true},{"text":"has been developed by Gabe Brown’s book "},{"text":"Dirt to Soil ","italic":true},{"text":"(2018), David Montgomery’s "},{"text":"Growing a Revolution","italic":true},{"text":" (2017) and Graham Harvey’s "},{"text":"Grass Fed Nation","italic":true},{"text":" (2017). "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At the centre of these studies is a fundamental understanding that life fosters more life; meaning that healthy, living soil provides a natural foundation for a diverse and wholesome food chain. Larger insects return as natural predators to eliminate smaller pests; herds of frequently moving animals fertilise the soil; and this in turn resurrects formerly degraded land, allowing wildlife to return."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The founding fathers of regenerative agriculture are so optimistic of its potential for stalling and even reversing the effects of climate change, that you have to wonder – why isn’t everyone doing it?"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596547778/Screen_Shot_2020-08-04_at_14.29.14_ybji4x.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lowther Castle, part of the Lowther Estate. Image courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/p/B31jtZrJJ5V/","children":[{"text":"Lowther Castle","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"According to Jim Lowther, who runs "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.lowther.co.uk/","children":[{"text":"the Lowther Estate"}]},{"text":" in Cumbria, farmers in the UK have been held back by the scarcity of published results by early practitioners (specifically in terms of soil tests). A second and arguably more pressing issue is the economic risk. As discussed by Gabe Brown, who transitioned to regenerative methods on his North Dakota ranch, soil has often grown reliant on synthetic fertilisers and must undergo a process of weaning, which can be unprofitable and time-consuming. Equally, these new methods are often at odds with those taught by agricultural colleges and practised by past generations of farming families."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jim explains that putting regenerative agriculture into practice is achievable, even on a smaller scale, adding that struggling farmers often attempt to counter a poor turnover with more livestock. “It’s a vicious circle that’s difficult to get out of, particularly if there are too many family mouths to feed, all trying to earn a living off a small farm.  In short, they are stuck on a destructive treadmill.” However, with the few who dare to experiment boasting of higher quality harvests and food, more farmers are beginning to convert."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Whilst the risking of a few years of poor yields will be a bold venture in this fragile economy, the eventual payoff of higher quality food, carbon storage and a lifeline to endangered wildlife is invaluable. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The return of wildlife as a direct result of sustainable farming and conservation has been brought into the limelight by Isabella Tree’s "},{"text":"Wilding: The Return of Nature to a British Farm","italic":true},{"text":". The "},{"type":"link","url":"https://knepp.co.uk/home","children":[{"text":"‘Knepp Experiment’"}]},{"text":" saw the return of doves, nightingales, lesser spotted woodpeckers, purple emperor butterflies, and peregrine falcons to a 3,500 acre estate in West-Sussex. This re-emergence is best understood through the model of the ‘trophic cascade’, whereby the removal of a top predator has a domino effect which reverberates throughout the ecosystem. This theory was demonstrated most strikingly in the reintroduction of wolves at Yellowstone National Park, which restored countless species of flora and fauna, ultimately reshaping the land itself.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jim has witnessed changes to his estate after only 18 months. “The simple act of getting rid of the sheep flock and lots of the cattle and stopping farming intensively has allowed the wildlife to come back at a rapid pace”. He adds that the decision to remove their ewes, which was partially driven by economic factors, has also provided ample opportunity to rest the land and enable the growth of trees, shrubs and woodland pasture."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jim’s aim is to tackle biodiversity loss and carbon emissions, through planting trees on a grand scale and using electric cars alongside regenerative farming of dairy, beef and crops. ‘Biodiversity’, where a greater variety of plant and animal species co-exist, is fundamental to regenerative agriculture, seeking to rebalance ecosystems which have been dominated by monocropping - where one crop is farmed extensively, reducing the quality of the soil. At Lowther they have started intercropping spring barley and white clover, with the aim of adding in spring beans and peas which “fix nitrogen and provide a good source of protein to milking cows”."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596547979/KneppBurrellweb_3452881b_s6eatl.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Isabella Tree and her husband Charles at the Knepp Estate. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"From North Dakota hailstorms to tropical rains in Ghana, farmers have had to find ways to adapt to extreme weather. At Lowther, they have responded creatively to Cumbria’s past decade of catastrophic flooding. “We’ve done one pond restoration, one floodplain restoration and one beaver release programme.  All of these are designed to slow the flow of water in flood events”. This scheme has also provided a habitat for waders, water voles, otters and a host of wetland plants. However, Jim has found that it is the beavers who are “a keystone species that help to kick start the processes of landscape renewal.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jim operates within a private trust which allows for fast and efficient decision making. However, he acknowledges that Lowther’s food production programmes would not currently be tenable without government subsidy. He has hopes that the transition to regenerative methods will enable the farmland to sustain itself in the future."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The success of regenerative agriculture lies in the commitment of future generations and long-term plans. In a food market which is dominated by low quality corn-fed meat, from overstretched and undernourished farmland, the time has come to make a change. Whilst the risking of a few years of poor yields will be a bold venture in this fragile economy, the eventual payoff of higher quality food, carbon storage and a lifeline to endangered wildlife is invaluable. At its core, regenerative agriculture is a movement which aims to work alongside nature, rather than against it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Originally from Cumbria, Al Howard is a poet and investigative journalist, who studies Art History and English at the University of Glasgow. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Life fosters more life

values.subtitle: Plant-based eating is having a moment. But is vegan food really more eco-friendly?
values.author: Chas Newkey-Burden
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Meat-eating environmental activists hate being reminded of the connection between agriculture and climate change – but vegans can be just as defensive when the environmental impact of our lifestyle is pointed out to us."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Everyone knows that "},{"type":"link","url":"https://metro.co.uk/2018/07/18/meat-isnt-just-murder-its-armageddon-why-you-should-become-vegan-now-7732198/","children":[{"text":"switching to a plant-based diet "}]},{"text":"is a good way of reducing your impact on the environment, so the growing popularity of veganism is generally seen as a blessing for the climate change movement. But could it also become a curse?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Vegan life has changed a lot from its fringe days of lentils, nut cutlets and furrow-browed earnestness. It has hit the mainstream. Supermarket shelves are bulging with plant-based imitations of every food type you can name, from doner kebabs to squirty cream. Restaurant chains, fast-food giants and gastropubs all offer plant-based menus. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The tills are ringing as vegans line up to proudly splash their cash on these options. They believe that by doing so they’re proving demand for plant-based food, and thus encouraging suppliers to change their offering to something a little more ethical.Vegan consumerism has succeeded vegan activism and many plant-chompers feel validated and rather pleased as they get to choose from more and more delicious options, while saving animals and the planet."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596818593/neonbrand-SvhXD3kPSTY-unsplash_rusovy.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Shelves are filled with vegan options. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But how many vegan consumers are asking where all these fake meats come from? How did they make these ingredients we can’t even pronounce and how many miles did they travel before they landed on the shelves of our local supermarket? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Is buying locally-produced meat from a small, independent farm less damaging to the environment than buying mass-produced plant-based ‘meat’ that has been wrapped in plastic and flown halfway around the world? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many vegans, myself included, went vegan for the animals rather than for the environment, so the meat option is always off the table regardless of its degree of environmental impact. But that doesn’t mean we can’t dig deeper and ask questions about our choices. We shouldn’t be played by vegan consumerism: stamping a green ‘V’ on a product’s packaging doesn’t mean it was produced angelically. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many of us cheered when Burger King, McDonald’s and KFC started offering vegan burgers, but the profits from these are being plunged back into propping up these chains’ core business: the industrial slaughter of animals and the cheap commodification of their flesh. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Another inconvenient truth is that some vegan staples cause enormous impact. It takes 1,611 US gallons (6,098 litres) "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/food/2018/sep/05/ditch-the-almond-milk-why-everything-you-know-about-sustainable-eating-is-probably-wrong","children":[{"text":"to produce one litre of almond milk"}]},{"text":". Avocados are"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/avocados-banned-environment-damage-sustainable-cafe-food-cooking-a8663526.html","children":[{"text":" grown on intensive farms "}]},{"text":"that have replaced forests, and are flown in from Central and South America."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many vegans consume palm oil despite the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://academy.plantbasednews.org/blog/palm-oil-vegan","children":[{"text":"harm that harvesting it has on animals "}]},{"text":"and the huge areas of the rainforest destroyed to make way for the plantations that produce it. If vegans are going to tell people that giving up meat and dairy are simple and obvious steps, shouldn’t we also aim for a more climate-friendly vegan diet? "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596818527/hitoshi-namura-ePsIKxISjNU-unsplash_lc5lqk.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Avocados: hero or villain? ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Thanks to social media, we find ourselves in an age of increasing vanity. People want to feel they have ticked all the ethical boxes so they can tell the world and themselves that they are good people. However, it would be a tragedy if this online plant-based revolution distracted us from impending climate disaster. The idea that vegans are ‘the saviours of the planet’ - that there is no more we can do to help - is damaging. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The connection between the meat industry and environmental destruction is clear. The United Nations says that the animal agriculture industry is"},{"type":"link","url":"https://news.un.org/en/story/2006/11/201222-rearing-cattle-produces-more-greenhouse-gases-driving-cars-un-report-warns","children":[{"text":" responsible for more greenhouse gas emissions "}]},{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://news.un.org/en/story/2006/11/201222-rearing-cattle-produces-more-greenhouse-gases-driving-cars-un-report-warns","children":[{"text":"than the combined exhaust from transportation."}]},{"text":" Methane is 86 times more destructive than CO² and a single cow produces up to 500 litres of methane per day."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Researchers who studied the 35 largest meat and dairy companies found that "},{"type":"link","url":"https://metro.co.uk/2018/07/18/meat-isnt-just-murder-its-armageddon-why-you-should-become-vegan-now-7732198/","children":[{"text":"the top five alone"}]},{"text":" were responsible for more emissions than ExxonMobil, Shell or BP. A separate study concluded that adopting a vegan diet is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://science.sciencemag.org/content/360/6392/987","children":[{"text":"“probably the single biggest way to reduce your impact on planet Earth”"}]},{"text":"."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596818700/3438077857_cd71665bbf_b_yobgi2.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"So yes, if you care about climate change, it's best to stop consuming meat "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/mar/30/dairy-scary-public-farming-calves-pens-alternatives","children":[{"text":"and dairy"}]},{"text":". But - provided you have the time and money to radically change your diet - that should be the beginning, not the end, of your personal revolution. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We also need to move our attention beyond the personal sphere. We can make other personal changes such as stopping flying, driving less, boycotting fast fashion, and turning down our central heating. But, crucially, these are all individual choices whereas - at the end of the day - climate change requires systemic solutions. We’d be better off demanding those solutions, rather than preening ourselves over our meat-free diets. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Vegans are having our day in the sun but it seems like all that sunshine has gone to some of our heads. We get touchy when people point out the imperfections of our diets. Perhaps that touchiness is telling us something? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/allthatchas","children":[{"text":"Chas Newkey-Burden ","italic":true}]},{"text":"is a writer, nada yogi and animal liberationist. He writes about vegan issues for the Guardian, Independent, Metro, Huffington Post and Attitude. He’s the author of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.waterstones.com/book/running-cheaper-than-therapy/chas-newkey-burden/9781472948830","children":[{"text":"Running: Cheaper Than Therapy","italic":true}]},{"text":".","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Eating for the planet

values.subtitle: Addressing racial and economic injustice in California with solar cooperatives.
values.author: Maggie Gallagher
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Oakland, California is a microcosm of the San Francisco Bay Area’s diversity and divisions. It’s a historic centre of Black culture and progressive activism, but "},{"type":"link","url":"https://datausa.io/profile/geo/oakland-ca/","children":[{"text":"remains deeply segregated along racial and economic lines"}]},{"text":". The mostly-white hills are studded with million dollar homes, while Black and Latino residents are "},{"type":"link","url":"http://m.acphd.org/media/401560/cumulative-health-impacts-east-west-oakland.pdf","children":[{"text":"concentrated in high-poverty neighbourhoods in the flatlands."}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These communities also bear the brunt of the environmental impacts of the Bay Area’s economic prosperity. In East and West Oakland, two neighbourhoods that skirt the edge of the industrial Port of Oakland and are delineated by a maze of eight-lane highways, emergency department visits for asthma attacks are"},{"type":"link","url":"http://m.acphd.org/media/401560/cumulative-health-impacts-east-west-oakland.pdf","children":[{"text":" twice as frequent as in the rest of Alameda County. "}]},{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"http://m.acphd.org/media/401560/cumulative-health-impacts-east-west-oakland.pdf","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Crystal Huang, 32, co-founded "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.peoplepowersolar.org/","children":[{"text":"People Power Solar"}]},{"text":" to address these intertwined problems of environmental degradation, racial discrimination and economic exclusion. Her solution is to empower communities to own clean sources of energy by forming cooperatives that invest in solar installation."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597156792/Screen_Shot_2020-08-11_at_15.39.29_tazhcx.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Crystal Huang.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Crystal has been working in the clean energy industry for over a decade. She says she and others in the field often asked themselves one question: “How do you get low income communities to care about climate change?” But after deepening her engagement with community organisations in the Bay Area, she came to see this as “a question that reflects a lot of ignorance.” “There’s an assumption that they don’t care, and an assumption that it’s their responsibility.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This realisation brought on a paradigm shift in her approach to climate action. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“The biggest shift is understanding that, as long as we’re treating the community as consumers, we’re not going to solve the problem,” Crystal says. Instead, People Power Solar approaches people as partners, and as experts in finding solutions to the problems their communities face. The organisation offers legal advice to anyone trying to start a solar cooperative and conducts outreach to community leaders. Ultimately, the power belongs to the people who produce it."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“When communities have control over their source of energy, what they’re doing is investing into their communities,” says Crystal. “Clean energy is about more than decarbonisation. It’s a wealth-building opportunity.” "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597156909/50190372183_673222e1ca_o_t1posa.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"People Power Solar Cooperative member-owners gathering to set intention for the new year.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In California, the energy generated by privately owned rooftop solar panels is sent back out to the power grid, and the owners are paid for the electricity their panels generate each month instead of receiving an electric bill. As tax incentives for solar installation proliferate and their cost decreases, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.solarreviews.com/blog/how-to-calculate-your-solar-payback-period","children":[{"text":"rooftop solar panels are paying for themselves "}]},{"text":"more and more rapidly, and becoming a source of profit for their owners."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But before "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.peoplepowersolar.org/projects","children":[{"text":"People Power Solar’s ‘Commons Model’"}]},{"text":", only property owners could reap the financial and environmental benefits of solar power in California."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“Ultimately the DNA of energy democracy is about people having power literally, financially, and politically.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We disconnect the ownership of land from the ownership of power,” says Crystal. People Power Solar Cooperatives approach local property owners and offer to invest in the installation of solar panels on their rooftops. Once the panels are installed, the owner of the property pays the cooperative for the value of the electricity produced every month and the cooperative distributes the profits to the community members who invested in it initially."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In Oakland, where "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.governing.com/gov-data/census/city-renter-population-housing-statistics.html","children":[{"text":"almost 60% of residents live in rental properties"}]},{"text":", the Commons Model has big implications for the accessibility of solar’s financial benefits. It also offers frontline communities that have been heavily impacted by industrial pollution the opportunity to build their own transition away from fossil fuels. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The movement to expand access to solar is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.cesa.org/projects/solar-with-justice/","children":[{"text":"gaining traction across the United States"}]},{"text":", with potential effects beyond decarbonisation. Advocates see the solar transition as an opportunity to end dependence on utilities with regional monopolies by putting sources of energy under local control, and to strengthen democratic institutions and political participation in the process. Crystal and other activists call this “energy democracy.” "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597157050/48793899968_733af25c39_o_v85ig2.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Found Anchor Owner, Jessica Tovar, voting at an Annual Member-Owner Meeting.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Ultimately the DNA of energy democracy is about people having power literally, financially, and politically,” says Crystal. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"People Power Solar completed its first project in late 2019, installing panels on the home of Lora Jo Foo, a local activist prominent in the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://nocoalinoakland.info/","children":[{"text":"‘No Coal in Oakland’"}]},{"text":" movement. This pilot project serves as a ‘proof of concept’ that the Commons Model works legally and financially; more than 50 cooperative members are now receiving payments from the project. Through an expansion of this model, according to Crystal, communities can regain control not just over their environmental health but also over their social and economic conditions."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As Crystal says, “The clean energy transition is not about technology alone. Technology is just a tool. Ultimately it’s actually about people.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Maggie Gallagher is based in Berkeley, CA. She graduated in 2018 from UCLA where she was a Lemelson Anthropological Honors Scholar, and spent the past year living and working in Santiago de Chile. She writes about environmental and social issues.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"All images courtesy of People Power Solar.","italic":true}]}]
values.title: “Clean energy is about more than decarbonisation”

values.subtitle: The division of Jammu and Kashmir is damaging an ecosystem that already hangs in the balance.
values.author: Safina Nabi
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Kashmir region lies at the crossroads of three major human influences – the Persians, the Indus, and the Chinese civilizations; it is nestled at the confluence of the northwestern end of the mighty Himalayas, the Hindu-Kush, and the Karakorum mountain ranges. Known to many as “paradise on Earth”, its location and climate also make it incredibly hazard-exposed – something that has been recently exacerbated by political change in India."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On 5th August 2019, the Indian government unilaterally scrapped Articles 370 and 35-A, dividing the state of Jammu and Kashmir into two union territories – Jammu Kashmir and Ladakh. A complete communication blockade and curfew was implemented in the area, and troops were deployed. Articles 370 and 35-A had granted semi-autonomous status to the Muslim majority state of J&K after the partition of the subcontinent in 1947. The state had been given authority to establish a separate constitution and state flag; legislate in all matters except finance, defence, foreign affairs and communications; and guarantee property rights to its residents."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Most of the former state falls under a seismic zone V (the highest earthquake prone zone). Ladakh has always been a sensitive Himalayan ecosystem and has experienced natural hazards and disasters of varying scales over the decades. It is also situated on a fault-line of ongoing border disagreements between India, China and Pakistan. Since the scrapping of the articles, there have been signs of further manmade environmental damage."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597565790/Jammu_kashmir_t3mhpd.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After abolishing semi-autonomous status, the union government passed the Jammu and Kashmir Reorganisation Act in parliament, which came to effect on 31st October 2019. Soon, the UT administration identified over 57,000 acres of land for setting up industrial estates. The imminent land-use changes in the region have caused dismay among common people and environmental activists."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Environmental expert and hydraulic engineer Aijaz Rasool said that “by implementing new laws and diluting the previous environmental laws, the Indian government has made it easy for business houses to get permits for projects that were either rejected or stuck due to non clarification.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“All this is happening in the name of development, without considering the fragile ecosystem of the area.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"India has recently drafted new rules of Environment Impact Assessment and is facing criticism from environmentalists throughout the country. Aijaz believes that this assessment rule - if passed and implemented in Kashmir - could spell disaster in the entire area. Kashmir is the most fragile zone in the Himalayas, much more than any other place in India. Its ecology is already under threat due to the region’s complicated history, tourism, and illegal construction."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As for the residents of Kashmir themselves – their ways of life and agricultural practices have evolved in tandem with the natural landscape. The garment industry relies on organic farming and vegetable dyes, and boats are built at high altitude from sustainable forest cedar wood. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597513243/10434880854_12a8dcc064_b_jhk86t.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Boats are made with sustainable forest wood. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There are concerns that India – home to some of the most polluted cities on Earth – will import artificial and manmade mechanisms into the clean and untouched environs of Kashmir. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There is also a risk that – because of a new domicile law that has made residency rights significantly easier to attain – a large number of new people will purchase land in Kashmir. For Aijaz, this signals impending geographic and demographic change and thus a threat to the natural environment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Even during British rule, British people were not allowed to acquire land in Kashmir and hence, they started living in houseboats. Brits were ruling India but had no land rights,” he says - emphasising the magnitude of the situation. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We will not allow them to pollute our environment. We will contest this in court and at every level.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Safina Nabi is a full-time independent journalist living in Indian Administered Kashmir. She writes about gender, health, human rights, development and culture for publications like Women Under Siege, The New Humanitarian, Himal and BBC Urdu. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Fault lines

values.subtitle: The women of colour making waves in the UK’s environmental justice community.
values.author: Solidaritree team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/solidaritree_/","children":[{"text":"Solidaritree","italic":true}]},{"text":" was founded this year by science policy researcher ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/charisejeanine_/","children":[{"text":"Charise Johnson","italic":true}]},{"text":", content creator Lois Donegal","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/loisdonegal/","children":[{"text":"","italic":true}]},{"text":", and recent-graduate graphic designer ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/hye_jpg/","children":[{"text":"Naz Hye","italic":true}]},{"text":". The team describe themselves as a collective working to create an accessible space for, and amplify the work of, BIPOC individuals and organisations in the environmental sector. Ours to Save got in touch with them to find out a bit more about their aims and what they feel is missing amongst environmentalists at the moment. Here’s what they said: ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As a team we are here to fill in the gaps – environmental justice platforms on social media are typically centred on US issues and activism, and tend to speak to a white audience in hopes of educating a predominately white environmental sector. Ultimately, our intention is to join the larger discussion on environmental justice that has gained a stronger foothold in the UK more recently, with a deliberate focus on BIPOC and other groups in the UK that have been historically underrepresented or ignored within the mainstream environmental movement. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As people who have been pushed to the margins by inequitable and unjust societies and policies, we recognise the inherent value of our unique connections to the environment, and aim to create a community where we can share our stories and work within our own networks and spaces."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It all began when Lois was doing her final project for her MA, focusing on the lack of diversity in the environmental sector in the UK. She reached out to the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/groups/pocinnature/","children":[{"text":"PoC in Nature page on Facebook "}]},{"text":"and Charise replied. She’d just moved to London from Washington DC and was feeling uninspired by environmental discourse in the UK. Lois travelled to London to film with her, they got to talking passionately about environmental justice, and in their first ever meeting together, the idea was born. Lois already knew Naz, as they had lived together and were close friends. She seemed like the obvious choice for a graphic designer to help Solidaritree stand out among an expanding sea of social media infographics. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The reality is that environmental discussions and decisions impact us all - some more than others - but it always seems to be the same people dictating the conversation and solutions. Many of us as BIPOC have connections to countries all around the world, where large environmental organisations launch climate offsetting schemes without liaising with the communities that would be impacted. This leads to (as an example) land grabbing and then community displacement. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597868215/Untitled_design_76_yu6dhy.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One of Solidaritree's infographics tackles urban greenery. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Back here in the UK, many BIPOC and other underrepresented groups do not have equivalent access to green spaces as compared to their white counterparts, and this does not sit well with us. This is not equity; this is not justice. We have some very big ideas to tackle these issues, from targeted campaigns and community nurturing, to carrying out our own large scale research of environmental organisations in the UK, continuing the work many have done before us, often with few resources and little to no accolades."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Our mission is to raise awareness of the barriers BIPOC, people from low income backgrounds, LGBTQ+, the disabled and the elderly face with regards to accessing the natural environment here in the UK. To help those who work in these spaces trade knowledge on how best to leverage our collective power in order to make real, lasting change. We want to normalise diversity within the outdoors in the UK and shed light on our own personal experiences."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The dream is to host networking events, workshops, webinars and town halls, to meaningfully engage youth, and to empower those who might not typically enter the environmental sector, by providing them with the skills, knowledge and connections to access this area. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Follow Solidaritree on","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/solidaritree_/","children":[{"text":" Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Environmentalism for everyone

values.subtitle: The government of Bolivia's La Paz Department now focuses on ‘responsible mining’, considering personal and environmental health.
values.author: Mette Mølgaard
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mining is deeply embedded in the national identity of Bolivia. In colonial times, so much silver from mines in the southern region of Potosí was shipped to Europe that people said a bridge of silver could be built from the top of Cerro Rico to the royal palace’s entrance in Spain. Since then, Bolivia has been an epicentre for the exploitation of non-renewable natural resources extracted from mines – such as silver, copper, tin, zinc, and gold. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The country’s mining boom has come at an extremely high cost; between 1500 and 1800, around eight million slaves died in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.britannica.com/place/Potosi-Bolivia","children":[{"text":"Potosí"}]},{"text":". Still today, miners risk their lives to provide for their families. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nowadays, mining is also criticised for its environmental impact – as a cause of biodiversity loss in one of the most biodiverse countries in the world. The practice leads to soil erosion and the contamination of surface water, groundwater, soil and air. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598095288/IMG_8660-1_lotwcy.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One of Bolivia's many mines. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To counteract this, the government of the La Paz Department recently started a programme for responsible mining, which aims to change the mentality of the miners - in terms of environmental and social issues, work safety and appropriate economic management - and to support miners that show a willingness to improve the way they view and use natural resources. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In charge of the program is María de los Ángeles Bejarano, an engineer in environment and natural resources."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I had never imagined I would be engaged in the mining industry. It is not only a challenging job as a woman, but also because I care about the environment. However, Bolivia is a traditional mining country, and the mining industry is so important for many Bolivian families. Bolivians are miners,” 29 year old María de los Ángeles says. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“It is regrettable that many miners do not have the technical knowledge and the adequate technology to develop the mining activity in harmony with the environment”, she adds. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“But this is what we are working for now.”"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598094645/HGNW2769_gwammv.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Teaching best practice to the miners. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Mining belongs in La Paz”","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Since the government programme was initiated in 2019, María de los Ángeles has visited several mining cooperatives in the La Paz Department to better understand the daily life of the miners. She has felt the extreme temperatures they work under; she has stayed in mining camps for several days; and she has shared food and a place to sleep with the miners. The mines are often in very remote areas of the "},{"text":"altiplano","italic":true},{"text":", around 3,900 metres above sea level, and can take up to ten hours by car on some of country’s most dangerous roads to reach. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Visiting the cooperatives has allowed me to see the reality of the miners; understanding their needs, mainly the economic, but also the technical, so they will be able to work without causing considerable negative impacts to both the environment in which they live, but also to their own health.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“After visiting the cooperatives, I became aware that these people need mining. As a Bolivian, this is something I cannot ignore. Mining belongs in La Paz,” she explains."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the La Paz Department, there are around 1,500 cooperatives. The Department has the country’s largest mining workforce, with 51,770 "},{"text":"socios","italic":true},{"text":" (partners), who together with their families represent around 200,000 people dependent on mining."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“My hope with this new project is to plant a seed. Establish a model for responsible mining for the cooperatives, respecting the rights of Mother Earth, the culture and the customs, while also promoting gender equality.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“When mining is already happening, then what we can do is to make sure that the miners work in a way that affects the environment as little as possible,” says María de los Ángeles."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Some miners do not know enough about the effects of their industry on their surroundings and mainly think about economical benefits, yes. But they are dependent on mining and it is out of necessity they work in this industry. Many miners do simply not have any other option.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As a professional, María de los Angeles organises workshops, where she offers technical support and teaches good practice to the miners to help them reduce the impacts on the environment. In particular, her team of four aims to raise awareness about the negative effects of using mercury. 15% of Bolivian gold mining still relies on traditional techniques that involve the inappropriate use of mercury, which contaminates the surrounding environment and damages the health of the miners and neighbouring communities. María de los Angeles’ objective is full compliance with the "},{"type":"link","url":"http://mercuryconvention.org/","children":[{"text":"Minimata Convention on Mercury"}]},{"text":", a global treaty to protect human health and the environment from the adverse effects of mercury."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598094656/2_o2b7qr.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mining is still male-dominated, but women are more present than ever before. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Machismo in mining","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It’s not just the environment that is at risk from extraction in Bolivia. So too is the health of the miners themselves, many of whom remain unaware of the risk of illness. Many miners die from accidents, from falling or using the machines, but others suffer from respiratory and stomach diseases. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Traditional mining involves many risks, and there will always be accidents. I have seen how miners work, how they risk their lives, and I want to help them take better care of themselves. The La Paz Department covers many ecosystems, and people work in different kinds of weather, but working at 3,900 metres above sea level is rough. It is very cold, so it is surprising that people can even work at this height, right?”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Bolivian mines are undoubtedly a tough place to earn a living, especially for women, who are more present now than ever before. According to the country’s national mining corporation (COMIBOL), there are 3,000 female miners – 600 of whom work inside the mines as "},{"text":"palliris","italic":true},{"text":". This is a Quechua term meaning ‘to harvest’ or ‘to collect’; it is used only for the female miners who sort the minerals extracted from the mines. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sometimes women enter the mining industry when their miner husbands die and they suddenly have to support their families. Not only is mining an extremely physical demanding job, women also have to fight discrimination and risk becoming victims of violence. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machismo","children":[{"text":"Machismo","italic":true}]},{"text":" ","italic":true},{"text":"still dominates Bolivian society, and mining is not considered an appropriate domain for women. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Many end up in mining by coincidence. But as there are not many jobs in Bolivia, where 70 percent work in the informal sector (i.e. selling food on the streets), many prefer working in the mining industry. For women in particular it is a very hard job. They work many hours, and sometimes they leave their kids for up to 15 days, and then they also have to fight against "},{"text":"machismo","italic":true},{"text":" in mining, because most of the miners are still men. I respect that a lot.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As a woman herself in a male-dominated industry and society, María de los Ángeles feels it is especially important that she engages with the women in the mining cooperatives she oversees. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“My hope with this new project is to plant a seed. Establish a model for responsible mining for the cooperatives, respecting the rights of Mother Earth, the culture and the customs, while also promoting gender equality,” she says."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mette Mølgaard is a freelance journalist with an MSc in Development and International Relations/ Latin American Studies. Now based in Copenhagen, she previously lived in Bolivia for a year working at the Danish Embassy and UN Women in La Paz. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: What does an environmentalist do in the mining industry?

values.subtitle: How do you go about removing 1,000 gigatons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere?
values.author: Robert Ludke
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"If there is one analogy that best describes the state of the world’s atmosphere today it is that of a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://cleantechnica.com/2020/08/08/drawdown-review-2020-how-to-address-global-warming-in-a-responsible-manner/","children":[{"text":"bathtub with the tap running"}]},{"text":" at maximum capacity, a clogged drain, and water spilling all over the floor. Through carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions of all kinds created by human activity – automobiles, power plants, manufacturing facilities, and so on – the tap is pumping out unprecedented levels of CO2 into our atmosphere. Unchecked emissions are, in turn, triggering a rise in the planet’s temperature."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The willingness of society to close the tap and open our drain to lessen the impact of those emissions is, at best, limited. The destruction of ecosystems naturally able to absorb CO2 is rampant; there is a lack of viable national and international policy frameworks to encourage society-wide solutions (such as markets to trade carbon credits); and most consumers are unwilling or unable to change purchasing habits to achieve a less carbon-intensive lifestyle. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While there are glimmers of hope that society is rising to meet these challenges, the pace of transformation must occur at an accelerating rate because – putting it mildly – our overflowing tub has created a mess. To be in with a chance of meeting the aggressive goal of limiting the Earth’s temperature increase to 1.5°C by the end of this century, we must find a way to both turn off the tap (eliminating the use of fossil fuels that produce carbon dioxide) while unclogging the drain (achieving 'negative emissions' whereby carbon dioxide already in the atmosphere is removed)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The most effective solution is to turn off the tap. Unfortunately, we have put so much CO2 in the atmosphere that simply stopping all emissions is not enough to arrest the rising temperature of the planet. If we are to limit the rise in the Earth’s temperature we also must remove carbon dioxide already in the atmosphere – to the tune of 1,000 gigatons according to the United Nations' "},{"type":"link","url":"https://report.ipcc.ch/sr15/pdf/sr15_spm_final.pdf","children":[{"text":"Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change"}]},{"text":". To put the magnitude of that amount in context – a single gigaton is equal to the weight of 200 million adult elephants, enough to stretch trunk to tail from Earth to the Moon."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carbon capture and removal: the emerging solution","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mother Nature is the most effective tool at our disposal when it comes to removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. However, now that we’ve overwhelmed the Earth's natural capacity to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, it’s time to turn to technology as a supplement."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A technology quickly growing in prominence is known as ‘carbon capture and removal’. Umair Irfan, a science and climate change reporter for "},{"text":"Vox","italic":true},{"text":", "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.vox.com/energy-and-environment/2018/10/24/18001538/climate-change-co2-removal-negative-emissions-cdr-carbon-dioxide","children":[{"text":"provides a helpful distinction"}]},{"text":": carbon capture is the grabbing of carbon dioxide at its source – such as the smokestack of a power plant – before it goes into the atmosphere. Carbon removal is grabbing CO2 already in the atmosphere. In both cases the CO2 is diverted and stored underground."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598438002/what_is_ccs_qd6175.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The process of carbon capture. Image courtesy of Piyush Choudhary, ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"http://ccspfinalreport.fi/print","children":[{"text":"Carbon Capture and Storage Program (CCSP)","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Despite its promise, carbon capture and removal technology has a long way to go before it scales to the level needed to remove 1,000 gigatons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Furthermore, prominent projects in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-25/norway-warned-2-6-billion-carbon-capture-plan-may-be-too-costly","children":[{"text":"Norway"}]},{"text":" and the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://news.yahoo.com/problems-plagued-u-co2-capture-234115357.html","children":[{"text":"United States "}]},{"text":"have been plagued by cost overruns and a failure to meet projected targets of CO2 removal."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The network of actors scaling carbon capture and removal technology","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In my work "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ludkeconsulting.com/transformative-markets","children":[{"text":"studying the formation of markets "}]},{"text":"for sustainable goods and services, I found that such markets come together much more quickly when four sets of actors collaborate:"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Public sector ","bold":true},{"text":"– policy makers at all levels of government, from city councils to national governments, to the United Nations"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Private sector","bold":true},{"text":" – corporations, both privately-held and publicly-traded"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Cause sector ","bold":true},{"text":"– NGOs, academics, and foundations"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Finance sector","bold":true},{"text":" – banks, pension funds, asset managers, and institutions such as the World Bank"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In markets such as wind power and battery electric vehicles we see these actors working together to establish the policy frameworks to allow companies and investors to enter the market with certainty - thus bringing in innovation and capital - and cause sector experts lending their expertise and credibility."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The United States has quickly emerged as a ‘hotspot’ for the development of carbon capture and storage technology. This is significant for two reasons. First, the United States is the world’s second largest emitter of CO2 (behind China) and thus it must play an outsized role in reducing both CO2 emissions and CO2 already in the atmosphere. Second, the United States is home to arguably the world’s most contentious debate around the causes of climate change and the importance of reducing CO2 emissions to address it. Thus, it is a positive when parts of the conversation shift to being focused on solutions."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In studying the public conversation taking place across the news media over the last 12 months about carbon capture and storage technology, I found two important trends emerging. First, there is significant private sector engagement with the topic, with the corporations involved having significant size and reach – and thus able to play a significant role in creating and sustaining a market for the technology. Additionally, one of the most influential investment firms in the world – JPMorgan Chase – has committed to investing in carbon capture and removal technology."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598437516/Screen_Shot_2020-08-26_at_11.24.14_zqozn3.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Private and finance sector engagement. Research performed by the author using Quid, an AI-powered data visualisation platform, which analysed 799 stories about the topic of carbon capture and removal from August 2019 to August 2020.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Second, the primary institutions involved in the conversations cut across the public and cause sectors – and the conversations are oriented towards enabling the development of the technology, not inhibiting it."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598437516/Screen_Shot_2020-08-26_at_11.24.43_p9ppn8.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Key public and cause sector actors. Research performed by the author using Quid, an AI-powered data visualisation platform, which analysed 799 stories about the topic of carbon capture and removal from August 2019 to August 2020.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Keep in mind that no technology has ever scaled to something transformative without successes and failures. Carbon capture and removal is no different. Despite the setbacks and challenges, the technology has shown promise. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"More important, the critical ingredient already is in place: a network of diverse actors committed to making it a reality, particularly in the United States. What remains to be seen is if these actors can collaborate at the pace and intensity needed to create a truly global solution in order to remove 1,000 gigatons of CO2 in the coming years, not decades or centuries."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/bobludke","children":[{"text":"Robert Ludke ","italic":true}]},{"text":"is an ESG and sustainability expert and the author of Transformative Markets: Harnessing the Power of Markets for a More Sustainable Future. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: The promise of carbon capture and storage technology

values.subtitle: Environmental activism in Russia’s distant regions.
values.author: Sam Currie
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nestled deep in the forest, 775km from the regional capital of Arkhangelsk, Shiyes train station is just another unremarkable node of Russia’s vast railway network; an ex-Soviet logging camp lying uninhabited since 2002, seemingly forgotten. This was, at least, the case until two local hunters stumbled across an undisclosed, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/odr/moscow-is-solving-its-waste-problem-by-sending-it-to-regions/","children":[{"text":"300-hectare construction site in July 2018"}]},{"text":". They had discovered the foundations of a processing plant set to import 500,000 tons of Moscow’s household waste annually."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598641004/Shies_Station_by_Varlamov_1_hhinqk.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Shiyes train station","italic":true},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Once locals from surrounding villages began to discover the true extent of this project, grassroots protests erupted across the region, with residents and activists uniting behind a common environmental cause."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the two years since, protesters have continued to pressure the authorities to stall the site’s development, with organisers calling for locals to take part in rallies, as well as more radical forms of civil disobedience, akin to those used by UK-based Extinction Rebellion. Notably, one group of protesters refused to leave the site for the duration of the protests, with a rota of activists living year-round in log cabins and tents, braving near arctic temperatures to block a pivotal access point."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Citizens protesting the construction of a landfill site may seem inconsequential, especially in a country reliant on extractive industries such as oil and mining for much of its prosperity. Moreover, the disregard shown towards the environment by local and federal authorities is not unique to Shiyes by any means. Why then, have these protests garnered such a reaction both within Russia and abroad?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To start, the location of this proposed landfill was particularly inflammatory, with the site sitting on an expanse of marshy highland, which through a delta, known as the ‘gateway to the Arctic’, feeds into the White Sea. Looking deeper, the peaty foundations of the area are notably unstable and susceptible to climate change, with the subsidence of arctic tundra just recently being responsible for an environmental emergency in Norilsk."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598640212/White_Sea__%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B5_%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5_cjqhwr.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The crucial ‘gateway to the Arctic’ feeds into the White Sea.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Knowing this, and with an existing Gazprom pipeline situated less than 800 metres from the site, the decision to develop such a facility at Shiyes becomes extremely questionable. Government officials have found it difficult to stand behind. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Aside from the strength of the argument against Shiyes’ location, the size and makeup of the movement against the site’s construction, and their public appeal to Putin as the ‘Guarantor of the Russian Constitution’, finally forced the local government’s hand on the matter. The digital appeal directly to Putin’s office, in the form of recorded personal messages, brought the movement into the national spotlight with the protesters calling for the president to take the people’s side."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By siding with the establishment, and pleading for help from Putin’s executive, the protesters delicately constructed the narrative of their movement to avoid wider issues of democracy or human rights. By avoiding the label of being liberal, West-backed naysayers with metropolitan backgrounds, a stereotype that has consistently accompanied civil environmental movements in Russia, they have been protected from criticism by the conservative majority."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"With many of the Shiyes locals now able to add their voices to a cause 1,400km away, will the digital activism of groups such as FFF and Movement 42 pave the way for unified environmental activism spanning Russia’s vast regions?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Their simple demand of protection from an exploitative private development, and the unconstitutional abuse of power from local authorities, represented the situation for many living in Russia’s neglected regions. This was a demand that Putin couldn’t justifiably meet with simple force."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In a country with limited genuine civil engagement, flashpoints such as Shiyes provide a vital platform for civil society groups to get their message heard. In normal circumstances, any form of protest or march must be sanctioned in advance by local authorities, with unsanctioned pickets of more than one person often met with fines or arrest. Another law prohibits protest organisers from encouraging minors to engage in political activity, with the punishment being on par with inciting extremism amongst children."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To get around these draconian laws, grassroots environmental groups such as "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/fridaysforfuture.russia/","children":[{"text":"Fridays for Future (FFF) "}]},{"text":"Russia and "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/42_arh/","children":[{"text":"Movement 42"}]},{"text":" have encouraged activists to take part in mass solitary pickets, digital activism and small local workshops. In terms of engagement, however, these organisations have merely a slither of the support their Western counterparts receive, with FFF’s largest protest attracting just over 700 people from 35 cities for the 2019 Strike for Climate. Their role in digitally connecting these disparate issue-based protests, however, will become ever more important."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598640458/russia-protests-report_zlwmlk.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Protest is very difficult in Russia. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In contrast, Shiyes has become a fascinating backdrop for more radical forms of Russian environmental activism, with its remote location saving the protestors from the full force of the government’s riot police and OMON (national guard). At its peak, a small tent village of 600 people had amassed to blockade entry to the site, outnumbering the 200 construction and security personnel present."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"With neither private nor government forces able to easily dispel the opposition, authorities have now conceded to the protesters’ demands, a rare victory for Russia’s environmental activists."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In early June, the newly elected governor of Arkhangelsk, Alexander Tybulsky, called for the contract to develop the site be terminated immediately. This is a far cry from the stance taken by his predecessor Igor Orlov, who called the environmental protesters “riffraff” during his tenure, showing that Shiyes has helped shift the political opinion markedly on such issues."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Shiyes may be a story of direct, grassroots action leading to a positive environmental outcome, but the problem of ecological exploitation in Russia’s regions remains. National focus has now shifted to the Far East; Kushtau, in the Republic of Bashkortostan, is the site of a new wave of environmental protests. Once again, residents have called for their local environment to be protected against exploitative private projects. The Kushtau range - what remains of an ancient inland coral reef - is currently a target for Russia’s largest limestone extractor. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"With many of the Shiyes locals now able to add their voices to a cause 1,400km away, will the digital activism of groups such as FFF and Movement 42 pave the way for unified environmental activism spanning Russia’s vast regions?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sam Currie is a UCL graduate with a BA in Politics and Eastern European Studies (with an exchange year in St. Petersburg). This piece is based on extensive research done for his dissertation on youth environmentalism in Russia, focussing on the Fridays for Future movement. ","italic":true}]}]

values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Lockdown ignited a national appreciation for nature… We were talking about, using and appreciating green spaces more than ever: park visits were "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-53181112","children":[{"text":"up 67% "}]},{"text":"in the UK (when they were open) and over half of people said they "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/independentpremium/uk-news/coronavirus-parks-green-spaces-lockdown-a9501711.html","children":[{"text":"appreciated green spaces"}]},{"text":" and their benefits for wellbeing more than ever.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I’m talking with Ellen Miles, founder of "},{"type":"link","url":"http://natureisahumanright.earth","children":[{"text":"Nature is a Human Right"}]},{"text":". Ellen is working to (you guessed it) make nature a human right – via international lobbying, policy consulting and grassroots support. If "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.change.org/p/united-nations-make-access-to-nature-a-human-right-f5a27411-7c7b-45e0-98d6-c39e8204c089?utm_source=share_petition&utm_medium=custom_url&recruited_by_id=377695d0-7904-11ea-a836-6dfb398fa1df","children":[{"text":"her petition"}]},{"text":" succeeds, governments will have to ensure nature is easily reachable when developing new urban environments and architecture, and ‘rewild’ the built environment as it exists already. We’re discussing how the COVID-19 pandemic has affected attitudes to nature – how it’s revealed the haves and have nots when it comes to accessing green spaces. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"The comparison between peoples’ experiences of being stuck at home was stark – illuminating something we might call ‘environmental inequality’. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Incentivised by lockdown in the United Kingdom, the ONS commissioned "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/environmentalaccounts/datasets/accesstogardensandpublicgreenspaceingreatbritain","children":[{"text":"a study"}]},{"text":" into who can most easily access greenery on a casual basis. While parks are within easy reach for most, the study revealed that 1 in 5 London households have no access to a garden and that, in England, Black people are nearly four times as likely as white people to have no access to outdoor space at home."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I was actually most surprised at the finding that access to public parks is more evenly distributed, with people from minority ethnic groups almost as likely as white people to say their local green spaces are ‘within easy walking distance’”, says Ellen. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In lockdown, we felt the need for private green space more than ever before. For those households “without access to a garden during lockdown, especially during the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2020/apr/10/coronavirus-park-closures-hit-bame-and-poor-londoners-most#_=_","children":[{"text":"periods of park closures"}]},{"text":", life felt more like ‘"},{"type":"link","url":"https://inews.co.uk/opinion/coronavirus-lockdown-families-stuck-temporary-accomodation-london-415130","children":[{"text":"prison"}]},{"text":"’”. The comparison between peoples’ experiences of being stuck at home was stark – illuminating something we might call ‘environmental inequality’. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598954542/victor-garcia-0NJ9urGXrIg-unsplash_y6cpgg.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Green urban planning will be the norm in the cities of the future. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Why does this matter? Being able to access nature has been shown to have hugely beneficial physical and psychological effects. And with recent developments in technology and science, we are becoming more and more capable of understanding just what those effects mean to us as human beings and exactly, to quote Ellen, “how essential green space is to the health of our minds, bodies and communities.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“From acting as a powerful antidepressant, to reducing the risk of premature death, to lowering crime rates,” there isn’t a single aspect of being human that isn’t bolstered by the inclusion of nature. In truth being able to directly access even the smallest amount of nature has been proven to result in people who are not only happier, but also "},{"type":"link","url":"https://greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/how_nature_makes_you_kinder_happier_more_creative#:~:text=Scientists%20are%20beginning%20to%20find,to%20connect%20with%20other%20people.","children":[{"text":"kinder and more creative."}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“On top of lockdown exposing the disparities in access to green space,” Ellen continues, “the pandemic [also] highlighted the devastating health impacts of nature deprivation. Respiratory problems, cardiovascular disease, impaired immune systems and type 2 diabetes - all COVID-19 comorbidities - have been linked to a lack of local greenery, meaning that nature deprivation was likely a contributing factor to COVID cases and fatalities.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While Ellen’s campaign ticks along, there are small ways we can all help out when it comes to ‘greening’ the urban environment - from planting wildflower seeds in tree beds to arguing for the ‘depaving’ of unnecessarily or unused paved locations. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"All in all, we should keep in mind that every opportunity we get to go outside and experience the refreshing sense of self that comes with nature - whether that be spending time reading in a small spot in the garden, or walking alongside a river - there are so many others who have had to live with so much less. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1598954722/Screen_Shot_2020-09-01_at_13.04.41_zbfpe1.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of Nature is a Human Right.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To find out more about the work that Nature is a Human Right is doing, visit the website and look into a","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.natureisahumanright.earth/get-involved","children":[{"text":"ll the different ways that you too can help ","italic":true}]},{"text":"create opportunities for others to experience all the wonders the natural world has to offer us.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Max Sharp is an Ancient History and Archaeology graduate from the University of Cardiff. They run the Instagram page ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/ecoparentlife/","children":[{"text":"Eco Parent Life ","italic":true}]},{"text":"for planet-friendly parents. ","italic":true}]}]
