values.author: Clara Meyer-Horn
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"shado","italic":true},{"text":" (See. Hear. Act. Do.), a multimedia platform situated at the nexus of arts, activism and academia, is launching its 3rd print issue, titled: "},{"text":"Climate Justice","italic":true},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"shado","italic":true},{"text":"’s mission is to amplify those voices at the frontline of political, social and cultural change that often go unheard or ignored in mainstream media outlets – Black voices, women’s voices, the voices of people with disabilities, the voices of young people. The initiative was born out of a frustration with the current lack of space available for multidisciplinary conversation and the wish to create a network of creatives, scientists and activists to drive culture-led system change. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"With this issue "},{"text":"shado ","italic":true},{"text":"elegantly achieves their desired dovetailing of journalism, art, activism and storytelling. The fresh momentum COVID-19 is currently bringing to the climate movement is used constructively: to educate readers and to awaken an activist spirit within them. Central to this issue is the framing of the current climate crisis as being inextricably linked to social justice issues surrounding race, gender and disability, to name only a few. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Across 15 articles,"},{"text":" Climate Justice","italic":true},{"text":" covers an impressive range of topics, from considering the interconnections between BLM and COVID-19, indigenous activism in Brazil and the media’s whitewashing of activist movements, to discussing the gendered nature of Israel’s environmental violations in Gaza."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1599199340/Shado_Issue-3_Climate-Justice_Front_Blue-1_lpmj1s.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of shado. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This issue is fed by an impressive slew of freelance contributors, together providing a fresh take on current issues in the climate sphere and their downstream societal effects, paving the way for new narratives to be formed. Notably, amongst the contributors are prominent actors in the climate space – such as Ugandan FFF climate activist Vanessa Nakate, known for founding Youth for Future Africa and the Rise Up Movement, 18-year old Xiye Bastida, dubbed by the media as ‘America’s Greta Thunberg’ and the Chilean poet and artist Cecilia Vicuna, whose career spans over 50 years and whose art helped shape ecofeminism."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The articles are kept short and neat. Big ideas are made accessible, condensed into concentrated, palatable nuggets of information. Don’t be fooled by my use of the word ‘palatable’, though. I use it to describe the format, not the content. The content is often the exact opposite. It is, in parts, uncomfortable, shocking and upsetting. You are encouraged to sit in your discomfort, to reflect. Realising your ignorance of issues unfolding right in front of your nose is never pleasant – but it is necessary for change. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On the whole, though, "},{"text":"Climate Justice ","italic":true},{"text":"is not a depressing read, as topics surrounding climate change so often are. Instead, it is angry and passionate, full of indomitable activist spirit. It is hopeful and pragmatic – acting as a springboard for discussions to be had and solutions to be implemented. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Often people are deterred from the climate movement because they are overwhelmed and don’t know where to start, what to look for. I would recommend that anyone in this position grabs a copy of "},{"text":"shado","italic":true},{"text":"’s "},{"text":"Climate Justice","italic":true},{"text":". It would make a great (though unconventional) crash course for anyone struggling to see all the different ways in which climate change and social issues connect up."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"You can preorder "},{"text":"Climate Justice","italic":true},{"text":" "},{"type":"link","url":"https://shado-mag.com/shop/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":". "}]}]

Big ideas are made accessible, condensed into concentrated, palatable nuggets of information. Don’t be fooled by my use of the word ‘palatable’, though. I use it to describe the format, not the content. The content is often the exact opposite. It is, in parts, uncomfortable, shocking and upsetting. You are encouraged to sit in your discomfort, to reflect. Realising your ignorance of issues unfolding right in front of your nose is never pleasant – but it is necessary for change. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On the whole, though, "},{"text":"Climate Justice ","italic":true},{"text":"is not a depressing read, as topics surrounding climate change so often are. Instead, it is angry and passionate, full of indomitable activist spirit. It is hopeful and pragmatic – acting as a springboard for discussions to be had and solutions to be implemented. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Often people are deterred from the climate movement because they are overwhelmed and don’t know where to start, what to look for. I would recommend that anyone in this position grabs a copy of "},{"text":"shado","italic":true},{"text":"’s "},{"text":"Climate Justice","italic":true},{"text":". It would make a great (though unconventional) crash course for anyone struggling to see all the different ways in which climate change and social issues connect up."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"You can preorder "},{"text":"Climate Justice","italic":true},{"text":" "},{"type":"link","url":"https://shado-mag.com/shop/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":". "}]}]
values.title: A crash course in climate justice

values.subtitle: Fehinti Balogun on being Black in Extinction Rebellion and his upcoming climate change stage show.
values.author: Molly Lipson
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In 2017, actor and writer Fehinti Balogun was in a play about the climate crisis. To prepare for his role he was asked to read "},{"text":"This Changes Everything","italic":true},{"text":" by Naomi Klein. For Fehinti, it did just that."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Over the next few years, as he started to read and learn more about the environmental emergency, he spiralled into a pit of anxiety and grief. He altered his diet and tried to speak to the theatres he was performing in about reducing their plastic, but he knew it wasn’t really having an impact. One weekend on his only day off, he went to a talk by Extinction Rebellion (XR), a social movement that uses civil disobedience to take action on the climate crisis. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After so much time spent feeling isolated in his climate panic, “for the first time I found people that felt like me,” he says. “It was healing, really healing and solidified the idea that something has to happen, something has to change.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"He wanted to start being more vocal, but was embroiled in an ongoing argument with his mum about it. She was scared for him: a young Black man at the beginning stages of his acting career, who wanted to start speaking out against the government. On one occasion, Fehinti secretly recorded the conversation, and after listening back to it, realised his mum might have made some quite good points after all. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“I don’t know where this fallacy comes from where the only thing that can legitimise a movement against oppression is pain. I think that’s what XR understands and other movements throughout history have understood, especially if you look at African movements against oppression.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Instead of dropping activism, however, he started doing more. Based on that conversation he wrote a lecture about the climate crisis. It was also partly inspired by the Extinction Rebellion talk he’d attended, but his intended audience was the Black community and communities of colour."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I wrote it in order to reach and represent people that looked and felt like myself and my mum, that came from a background that [meant they were] scared of getting involved and felt powerless – [people who] knew there was something wrong but didn’t know what to do,” he explains.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In his talk, he lays out the facts using examples and case studies from countries in Africa and Asia. He holds a frank discussion on how the climate crisis already disproportionately affects low-income, Black, brown and Indigenous people, women and people from other marginalised groups. He also discourages the idea of individual responsibility in both causing and tackling the crisis, instead highlighting the systemic causes and encouraging his audience to join or form communities to work together and rise up in action. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1599631725/49822623313_5c0d833ff4_b_nxwilm.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Presenting 'How the Climate Crisis affects me' at the Lyric Theatre. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Fehinti delivered this talk around the country for about a year, and took up invites to speak on panel events at cultural institutions like the National Theatre, as well as political establishments like the French Embassy. Then, he started thinking about how he could share this information with more people. He wanted to create something that would attract a different audience to those who might attend a formal speaking event and decided to incorporate his own passions – acting, music, rap, spoken word and performance – into a theatrical version of the talk. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"He presented his idea to the Complicité Theatre Company and was brought on as a creative. He is currently coming to the end of the writing stage of his musical show about the climate crisis, which he will be starring in when the time comes to tour the show around the UK (pandemic-dependent)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It’s really important to Fehinti that movements tackling the climate crisis incorporate more than just the hard facts into their work: “I don’t know where this fallacy comes from where the only thing that can legitimise a movement against oppression is pain. I think that’s what XR understands and other movements throughout history have understood, especially if you look at African movements against oppression. As well as love there’s joy, there is music, there is culture to be developed, had, written. All of these things are innate in us and to deny that feels like white supremacy.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"You can stay up to date with Fehinti’s activism on his ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/FehintiBalogun","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". He stars in the upcoming drama Viewpoint for ITV out next year. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Molly Lipson is a writer, organiser and activist working on all issues that align with an abolitionist and liberation world view. Find her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/molly_lipson1/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":" and ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/molly_lipson","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Activism as Joy

values.subtitle: Mestiza de Indias is reviving ancient farming techniques in Valladolid.
values.author: Angelika Pokovba
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mexico is one of the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://themazatlanpost.com/2019/08/06/mexico-enters-the-top-10-world-agri-food-exporters/","children":[{"text":"world’s top ten"}]},{"text":" agri-food exporters. Last year, the country made a reported $309 million in profit from "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.producebluebook.com/2020/05/12/mexico-increases-lettuce-exports-by-33-percent-in-2019/#","children":[{"text":"just lettuce"}]},{"text":" – a 30% increase from the previous year. However, according to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.tulumartclub.com/mestiza-de-indias","children":[{"text":"Mestiza de Indias"}]},{"text":" founder Gonzalo Samaranch Granados, most native children have never even seen a head of lettuce. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Gonzalo is a  travel journalist and gallery owner, who now sees the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/mestizadeindiass/","children":[{"text":"‘silent revolution’"}]},{"text":" of regenerative agriculture as his goal. Located in the middle of the Yucatecan jungle amongst one of the region’s poorest Mayan communities, the Mestiza de Indias biofarm - founded in 2015 - is easily one-of-a-kind. Gonzalo conceived of the project to counteract the harmful effects of Mexico’s agrochemical industry; its central principles include not practising deforestation, regenerating soils, and rescuing ancestral fruits and vegetables. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Those familiar with the azure seaside of Tulum and the surrounding regions know that there is hell in paradise and, here, it is food. You can find decent restaurant cuisine, but there always seems to be a shortage of vegetables in the shops. Mexico makes close to"},{"type":"link","url":"https://migration.ucdavis.edu/farm-labor/data/2018/05/09/major-mexican-fruit-vegetable-exports/","children":[{"text":" two billion in profit "}]},{"text":"from its piece de resistance, the avocado, and yet it is difficult to find - to say the least - in Tulum. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1599815211/37900885_239467223544496_3411360955479621632_o_hhvfu7.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Papaya on the farm. Image courtesy of MDI. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Most farming is done in the north of Mexico where it usually makes its way straight Stateside, Mexico being the second largest food importer to the US under the NAFTA act. Regions like Quintana Roo and the Yucatan produce close to absolutely zero food (bar individual farms) and do not have factories, mines, or much other business besides tourism. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Gonzalo is working to localise the Yucatan’s agriculture, recalling a time where almost all indigenous people produced their own food on their own property. His farm is a circular economy; the organisation’s work teaches about healthy eating, supports the women of the region, and distributes food amongst the community. It also delivers food to Tulum’s swanky restaurants and individual homes as part of its business model. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I went down to the farm to speak with Gonzalo about protecting Yucatan’s flora and fauna and reviving traditional techniques. Here's what he said. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1599814798/Mestiza_de_Indias_lqp2rm.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On the farm. Image courtesy of MDI. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Could you tell me about the origins of your project Mestiza de Indias and why you saw the niche (and need) for regenerative agriculture in the region? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mestiza de Indias is a project that was born in 2015 and whose first phase is linked to regenerative agriculture of social impact with the idea of responding to a growing demand for organic products in the Riviera Maya, one of the most important regions in the Americas. We wanted to show that we can create an agro-ecological business that responds to social and environmental problems. The second phase of the project is linked to agritourism."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Tell me a bit about agriculture in the Yucatan, or the absence of thereof. How did it happen that the process of agriculture was entirely devalorised?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The climate and soil type of the Yucatan Peninsula are not favourable to agriculture in general, and less to organic. The absence of seasons limits the varieties that can be planted and the soil, mostly rocky, is deficient in nutrients and minerals that affect the development and especially the taste of products. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Industrialisation and globalisation have ravaged the indigenous Mayan communities even though their ancestors created one of the most important food production systems in history. In the Mayan Solar, each family produced what was necessary to survive in behind their houses. Today those spaces are full of garbage and plastic that comes from the stores of packaged and processed products that are the cause of many of the diseases the people suffer from."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Globalisation also has an effect on the tourism businesses and especially on food. If we analyse the menus of the hotels, they are practically the same and they handle the same ingredients since the food industry is dominated by large transnational consortiums. The Riviera Maya is a clear example of this. The demand for food from large hotels is so great that they are forced to bring tons of products from other states."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How did you decide to go back to the roots, to the actual soil? How does one choose to become a farmer today? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After an experience in an indigenous community in the Amazon, where I learned food production techniques and living in harmony with nature, I decided to sell my business and my house in Barcelona and embark on a journey through Latin America from farm to farm. Upon arriving in Mexico, I visited several states but Yucatan won my heart and I decided to settle down."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1599814977/56670198_395647601259790_727647857435213824_o_k2gyw7.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Gender equality in farming is a key principle. Image courtesy of MDI. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"What are the main values of Mestiza de Indias? What makes the company sustainable? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mestiza de Indias is a farm to table project based on three ethical principles: 1. Take care of the planet 2. Take care of the people and 3. Equitable and fair distribution of the resources that are generated. At Mestiza de Indias we promote gender equality, education, food, and the empowerment of our community. The sustainability of our project is directly related to our independence and the fact of working in harmony with nature, not against it. In turn, we have established a horizontal organisational structure where each member of the project is highly important. We pay salaries well above the average and take care of the medical expenses of our collaborators and their families."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"What are the foods that you grow? Where do you get your seeds from? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At Mestiza de Indias we have done work to recover local species in danger of extinction and in turn we sow seeds of tropical species that we obtain in seed banks or other agro-ecological projects."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Who do you produce food for?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We work directly, without intermediaries, with hotels and Tulum restaurants. We establish a mutual commitment and sow on demand in order to plan our sowings. We had the luck to work hand in hand with chefs like"},{"type":"link","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Redzepi","children":[{"text":" Rene Redzepi"}]},{"text":" or "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/mikebagale/","children":[{"text":"Mike Bagale"}]},{"text":". We distribute twice a week in our own vehicle. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How do you value ancient Mayan agricultural techniques in your farming? How were these designed to be sustainable from the get-go?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Teamwork with our Mayan collaborators has been essential to combine ancient techniques with methods of last generation organic agriculture. Their knowledge of the environment is the basis for the development of our project."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1599815371/40135102_271005440390674_3331082308705845248_o_ndii1q.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"More organic produce. Image courtesy of MDI. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How do you include locals in your project? What are your plans to further include women in your project? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"All our team comes from the Maya community of San Pedro Chenchela, which is located a few kilometres from our land. An equal number of men and women work with us and receive the same salary."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"What is the Yucatan missing when it comes to more farming? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Most agricultural projects in the Yucatan Peninsula fail because they try to apply methods and techniques conventional that do not work in this region."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How do you give back to your community? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There is much to do, and not just charity, which is what has been done so far with the communities. We have started with fundamentals: that people return to eat healthy with a food education. And part of our production is dedicated to the community. This year our goal is to be able to serve food at primary school."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"You can follow Mestiza de Indias on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/mestizadeindiass/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/angelika_pokovba/","children":[{"text":"Angelika Pokovba","italic":true}]},{"text":" is an environmental journalist based in Tulum, Mexico. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: The only farm in the Yucatan

values.subtitle: Reusable products signal a revolution in global menstrual hygiene.
values.author: Riddhi Kanetkar
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Period poverty is not just a public health issue – it is closely related to sustainability, too. As such, new innovations such as menstrual cups and cloth pads have been instrumental in reducing menstrual waste across the world. Luckily, the most eco-conscious options are also the most cost-effective. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sanitary products are a significant contributor to landfill waste. In India, for example, up to 6% of all landfill waste is composed of non-biodegradable sanitary items, and these products can take between 500-800 years to decompose. Often, soiled products are "},{"type":"link","url":"https://theconversation.com/the-future-of-periods-can-now-be-sustainable-and-cheap-133025","children":[{"text":"discarded into rivers or oceans"}]},{"text":", releasing toxins into the water as they slowly decompose. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At the same time, many from lower socioeconomic backgrounds cannot afford tampons, pads, and the menstrual hygiene these (environmentally-unfriendly) products guarantee. In itself, this is a huge issue, and one that has worsened over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic. Thanks to a government menstrual hygiene scheme, schools in India have been "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-52718434?at_custom4=349B1CDC-9C36-11EA-8D63-D3033A982C1E&at_custom3=BBC+News&at_custom2=facebook_page&at_custom1=%5Bpost+type%5D&at_campaign=64&at_medium=custom7&fbclid=IwAR37a7HHUWou3pHCZ_HDiKE7jXGnWPXWladNoZ_gB4P-oB9ku3U1LacRPHg","children":[{"text":"important local suppliers of pads"}]},{"text":". But with recent school closures, there has been a cut in supply. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-52718434?at_custom4=349B1CDC-9C36-11EA-8D63-D3033A982C1E&at_custom3=BBC+News&at_custom2=facebook_page&at_custom1=%5Bpost+type%5D&at_campaign=64&at_medium=custom7&fbclid=IwAR37a7HHUWou3pHCZ_HDiKE7jXGnWPXWladNoZ_gB4P-oB9ku3U1LacRPHg","children":[{"text":"As few as 15% "}]},{"text":"of girls in India had access to sanitary pads during lockdown. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The silver lining: a rise in campaigns - sensitively - promoting sustainable menstruation. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Despite the scale of the issue, discussions about period poverty in India have always been nebulous due to the cultural stigma surrounding menstruation. This is something those advocating for it have to bear in mind in order to be successful. Take the 2019 campaign by the Alappuzha municipality in Kerala – ‘Project Thinkal’. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1600506031/strip-3655836_1280_mmmmx9.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sanitary pads are bad for the environment and also not easily available.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This aimed to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://edtimes.in/kerala-leads-by-example-a-municipality-distributes-5000-free-menstrual-cups/","children":[{"text":"distribute 5,000 menstrual cups for free"}]},{"text":" in an attempt to encourage a shift to reusable sanitary products. With the cups carrying a life cycle of 5-10 years, the municipality hoped to save "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.mynation.com/india-news/kerala-project-thinkal-distribute-5-000-menstrual-cups-for-free-ptc4jl","children":[{"text":"3.9 million pads"}]},{"text":" in the future, as a result of 5,000 women switching to the cups. A challenge to this initiative, however, was convincing the civic body to move from using more traditional sanitary pads to menstrual cups. To familiarise the women with this fairly alien concept, which also carried the stigma of vaginal insertion, the municipality opened up a centre to raise awareness about using menstrual cups, and to encourage a wider use of biodegradable and reusable menstrual products. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While ‘Project Thinkal’ distributed products on a smaller scale, organisations such as "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.greenthered.in/about","children":[{"text":"‘Green the Red’"}]},{"text":" have aimed to shift the menstrual hygiene landscape by engaging and educating communities and also influencing policy figures."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"In bringing together the personal and the political, sustainable menstruation will be a catalyst for safeguarding the health of those who menstruate, as well as the health of the planet. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Aside from menstrual cups, the campaign has promoted products such as cloth pads and period panties, both of which are reusable alternatives that resemble the existing sanitary pads more closely. According to gynaecologist "},{"type":"link","url":"https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/green-the-red-bengaluru-women-moving-towards-sustainable-menstruation-practices/articleshow/58005418.cms","children":[{"text":"Meenakshi Bharath"}]},{"text":",  cloth pads also ‘have no toxic chemicals, unlike bleached disposable pads, and do not cause rashes’. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In amalgamating education with action, ‘Green the Red’ have focused on eradicating the taboo around menstruation, making it easier to tackle period poverty in a sustainable and systematic way. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It is especially important that both these campaigns have approached the issue of period poverty from an intersectional perspective, by elucidating the environmental, social and economic drawbacks of non-reusable products. Sure – there are still barriers to overcome. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://centreforfeministforeignpolicy.org/journal/2020/3/9/the-case-for-menstruation-the-path-towards-equality-sustainability-and-social-change","children":[{"text":"Running water "}]},{"text":"is needed to hygienically use menstrual cups and cloth pads, for instance, and not everyone has access to this. But with COVID-19 exacerbating period poverty in many developing countries, innovation is more necessary than ever. In bringing together the personal and the political, sustainable menstruation will be a catalyst for safeguarding the health of those who menstruate, as well as the health of the planet. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Riddhi Kanetkar is a final-year student studying Comparative Literature at UCL. She is particularly interested in environmentalism, gender, and South Asian politics. ","italic":true}]}]
values.title: Solving period poverty, sustainably

values.subtitle: Our resident photographer documents a protest against land commercialisation on Hampstead Heath.
values.author: Finley Kamen
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Lockdown ignited a national appreciation for nature… We were talking about, using and appreciating green spaces more than ever: park visits were up 67% in the UK (when they were open) and over half of people said they appreciated green spaces and their benefits for wellbeing more than ever,” said Ellen Miles, founder of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.natureisahumanright.earth/","children":[{"text":"Nature is a Human Right"}]},{"text":", to Max Sharp in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feature?id=ckejsdpzp002z073800jhshbh","children":[{"text":"a recent "},{"text":"Ours to Save","italic":true},{"text":" piece"}]},{"text":" on environmental inequality and the human need to be in nature. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Perhaps it was unsurprising, then, that swimmers met with a surprise price hike at London's iconic Hampstead Heath bathing ponds were not going to go down without a fight. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://saveourponds.org/","children":[{"text":"Forum '71's Save Our Ponds campaign"}]},{"text":" was launched in July 2020 when the ponds re-opened after lockdown, ft. a 100% rise in price of entry. In direct contravention of the common law right of free access to all parts of the Heath, Forum '71 say, the City of London Corporation has raised the price of entry from a voluntary £2 to a compulsory £4. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ours to Save","italic":true},{"text":"'s resident photographer Finley Kamen went down to Hampstead Heath to document the protestors' 'LOCKED OUT' demo last Sunday 20th September. The following pictures capture this encroachment on London's public natural space in microcosm – with placards, bicycles, fences and warning tape clashing with blue skies and deep green water. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1600883179/Finley_7_ojkjea.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1600883175/Finley_5_hhdskd.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1600883172/Finley_6_t8ntjv.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1600883171/Finley_3_qfblwd.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1600883162/Finley_1_w84ugs.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1600883168/Finley_4_kub3bv.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"See more of Finley's photography ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.finleykamen.co.uk/","children":[{"text":"here","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sign the Save Our Ponds petition ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/save-our-ponds","children":[{"text":"here","italic":true}]},{"text":". values.subtitle: Everything you need to know about Trump, Biden, and climate policy.
values.author: Emily Thampoe
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While there is quite a bit happening in the world right now, what with the coronavirus pandemic and protests surrounding police brutality and violence against Black people, national elections are still taking place. The 2020 United States presidential election is fast approaching – with 37 days and counting left to go. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This year’s election comes at a crucial time; as Manhattan’s "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.plantbasednews.org/news/giant-clock-new-york-climate-crisis-irreversible","children":[{"text":"new Climate Clock "}]},{"text":"reminds us, we have just over seven years before the climate crisis becomes totally irreversible. We’re running out of damage-limitation time. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The two candidates, current president Donald Trump (Republican) and former vice president Joe Biden (Democrat) have contrasting views in general – but particularly when it comes to the environment and climate change. "},{"text":"Ours to Save","italic":true},{"text":" has "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feature?id=ck8w5q10w004y07424aaatqxs","children":[{"text":"previously documented"}]},{"text":" his fast-tracking of the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines. “This is the start of a new era in American energy production and job creation. His administration has actively rolled back policies that would provide necessary protections for the environment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One of the first actions that the administration took against environmental protections was stating its intention to get out of the Paris Agreement – a 195 nation-strong commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, signed in 2017. While this withdrawal cannot formally occur until the election passes in November, the United States is among the top emitters of greenhouse gas in the world. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Furthermore, the current administration does not prioritise climate change and air and water quality as areas that require more legislative and protections. In fact, many of the pieces of the environmental legislation that the Trump administration has been introducing has undone acts that the Obama administration put into place during the former president’s eight years in office. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One such piece of legislation is the Clean Air Act, which President Obama established within the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://archive.epa.gov/epa/cleanpowerplan/fact-sheet-overview-clean-power-plan.html","children":[{"text":"Clean Power Plan "}]},{"text":"in 2015. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This regulation was ultimately replaced by the Trump administration with The Affordable Clean Energy Rule in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/epa-finalizes-affordable-clean-energy-rule-ensuring-reliable-diversified-energy","children":[{"text":"2019"}]},{"text":", which has been seen as less effective than that of the preceding legislation. According to the US Environmental Protection Agency, the newer legislation will only elicit a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2018-08/documents/ace_trends.pdf","children":[{"text":"two percent reduction "}]},{"text":"in co-pollutant emissions. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This tendency to edge away from the reality of climate change has been reflected by Trump’s recent remarks in relation to the wildfires in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://apnews.com/bd152cd786b58e45c61bebf2457f9930","children":[{"text":"California"}]},{"text":". During a briefing with local and federal officials, President Trump remarked, “I don’t think science knows actually,” when the topic of his views on climate change was raised. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1601110097/49259750172_6d46c7bf8c_o_wxpzw2.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"President Trump signs the 2020 NDAA. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Biden’s stance on environmental issues could not be more different than that of the sitting president. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The former vice president has been noted as being a long time supporter of environmental initiatives, going as far back as his days as a senator in the 1980s. This was adapted into an act called the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/95/hr12598/text","children":[{"text":"Foreign Relations Authorisation Act "}]},{"text":"and signed by President Ronald Reagan in 1987. values.subtitle: The last two decades have revealed another dimension of the threat of climate change. Certain events have sparked fears that it contributes directly to the rise of terrorism and insurgency.
values.author: Anoushay Okhai
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Climate insecurity "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14650045.2014.903393","children":[{"text":"happens when "}]},{"text":"climate change or variability threatens a climate-impacted group. Its results are fascinating, unjust, and perilously under-discussed in environmental discourse. The field is comparatively unexplored, and typically locked within the world of academia. Scholars and politicians hold mixed opinions about whether climate change has been a direct cause of terrorism; however, scientific and historical evidence showcase direct examples of how it threatens security."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This stems largely from climate change’s impact on the availability of vital natural resources. Pollution or evaporation of water sources, and changing weather patterns impacting land fertility and crop development, are two examples of many. Elizabeth Chalecki "},{"type":"link","url":"https://pacinst.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/21/2013/02/environmental_terrorism_final.pdf","children":[{"text":"notes"}]},{"text":" that the more reliable a country’s access to resources, the lower the risk of environment-spurred terrorism. There is less risk of your primary supplies being attacked, less tension over resource distribution, and less political unrest as a result."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Accordingly, the hardest-hit nations are those with weaker infrastructure and harsher environments to begin with – nations whose resource scarcities are exacerbated, instead of created, by climate change. African countries are a prime example. At a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.jstor.org/stable/4541915?seq=3#metadata_info_tab_contents","children":[{"text":"2007 African Union summit"}]},{"text":", President Musevini of Uganda called climate change an ‘act of aggression’ against LEDCs by MEDCs. The high output of greenhouse gases from the West disrupts Africa’s ecology and security to the point of, in the words of Namibian UN representative Kaire Mbuende, constituting ‘low intensity biological or chemical warfare’. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1601539165/ella-ivanescu-JbfhNrpQ_dw-unsplash_dyxf78.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of Ella Ivanescu.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Instigating causes and permissive factors","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It’s easier to understand how much (or little) climate change contributes to terrorism with a wider understanding of how terrorism happens in the first place. In "},{"text":"Science Direct","italic":true},{"text":", Andrew Telford employs a "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.thomasrenard.eu/uploads/6/3/5/8/6358199/cdr9_heated_terror.pdf","children":[{"text":"theory"}]},{"text":" that terrorism’s likelihood depends on two overarching factors. ‘Instigating causes’, such as poverty or injustice, set the stage for radicalism, and lead to civilians turning to terrorist organisations for aid; ‘permissive factors’ involve the use of violence, particularly via the groups harmed by the above."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Somalia’s 2011 droughts led jihadist insurgents Al-Shabaab to switch from guerrilla warfare to blocking freed cities from accessing water, to exert their influence. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Generally speaking, academics don’t see environmental issues as ‘permissive factors’ – they don’t appear to directly drive terrorist violence. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ideas.repec.org/a/sae/joupea/v55y2018i3p336-350.html","children":[{"text":"Some research even shows"}]},{"text":" these issues actively working against insurgents – they, too, are likely to suffer from climate shocks as organisations, and often must shun government aid. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, resource diminishment has opened new avenues for terrorist tactics. One example is water weaponisation; as communities face more difficulties obtaining water under climate change, terrorist organisations manipulate the situation to further negotiation and violence. Somalia’s 2011 droughts led jihadist insurgents Al-Shabaab to switch from guerrilla warfare to blocking freed cities from accessing water, to exert their influence. This, combined with resultant conflict and stunted food security, induced over 250,000 deaths and huge rates of displacement. Climate change played a clear role here, and there is a possibility of similar instances as it continues to hinder water security."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In 2015, President Obama "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0962629819300095?via%3Dihub#bib61","children":[{"text":"made controversial links "}]},{"text":"between climate change and the hostilities of the period. He stated that “climate change did not cause the conflicts we see around the world”, which is true to a certain extent. Global warming is not the sole cause of corruption, colonial damage, and political unrest. Obama also, however, cited Boko Haram, and the relationship between its rise to power and harsh Nigerian droughts. He referred to the drought-induced crop failures and resultant raised food costs that ultimately disrupted peace in Syria. These examples show climate change’s effect as an ‘instigating cause’, or catalyst, of terrorism. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1601539528/29952473877_ab60ac9775_o_si8saj.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Boko Haram. Image courtesy of Think Defence. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As aforementioned, instigating causes include economic hardship and political grievances. As Andrew Telford comments, climate change directly contributes to these. Temperature variations can "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/40027398_Warming_Increases_the_Risk_of_Civil_War_in_Africa","children":[{"text":"displace crop yields"}]},{"text":", upon which over half of Africa’s GDP and up to 90% of its employment depends. More water is required in higher temperatures and there’s a higher risk of accelerated crop development. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.researchgate.net/journal/1091-6490_Proceedings_of_the_National_Academy_of_Sciences","children":[{"text":"PNAS findings show"}]},{"text":" that 'this often reduces African staple crop yields by 10-30% per °c of warming', undoubtedly having an impact on the economic security of individuals and communities. Telford also notes that diminishing resources could invoke a sense of inequality, as privileged or enemy actors seize what is left – another instigating cause of terrorism."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Climate change can, therefore, be termed a "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.thomasrenard.eu/uploads/6/3/5/8/6358199/cdr9_heated_terror.pdf","children":[{"text":"‘threat multiplier’"}]},{"text":"; it creates an environment where terrorist groups are more likely to be successful. In communities and nations where vital supplies are drained or damaged, the general public struggles and becomes more desperate. Insurgent groups provide an alternative – improved financial security, safety, a fight back against the current flawed system."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Boko Haram ","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"If we look deeper at Boko Haram, we find a clear example of how terrorist organisations thrive by harnessing resource scarcity. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Much of Nigeria’s terrain is pretty unforgiving, which, when combined with its "},{"type":"link","url":"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s40677-018-0111-7","children":[{"text":"heavy economic dependency on agriculture"}]},{"text":", contributes to a high poverty rate. Climate change exacerbates these issues further; "},{"type":"link","url":"https://lup.lub.lu.se/student-papers/search/publication/9011380","children":[{"text":"a Lund University study notes "}]},{"text":"that the prominent Lake Chad fell from 25,000 to 500 square kilometres in 50 years. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1601539329/14214066919_bb6df6ae43_o_xwcihl.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Once serving as part of the floor for a much larger Lake Chad, the area now known as the Bodele Depression, located at the southern edge of the Sahara Desert in north central Africa, is slowly being transformed into a desert landscape. Image courtesy of NASA. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In harsher landscapes like the northern Sahel, which already gets under ten inches of rain a year (already a 25% decrease from the rainfall 30 years prior), drought is a potential matter of life or death. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many Boko Haram soldiers are "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/earth-insight/2014/may/09/behind-rise-nigeria-boko-haram-climate-disaster-peak-oil-depletion","children":[{"text":"men who were displaced"}]},{"text":" by drought or food shortages, and a resultant loss of work. Though Boko Haram is now an extremist terrorist group, it began as an initiative to provide for poor communities, and continues to market itself as such. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nigeria struggles massively with distribution of clean water. Amidst Boko Haram’s brutal tactics, one of its "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.newsecuritybeat.org/2017/08/water-stress-instability-violent-extremism-nigeria/","children":[{"text":"demands"}]},{"text":" was that the government provide safe drinking water. The Lund University study points out that prolonged drought has affected food security to the point where recruits cannot find employment elsewhere. It cites an argument that here, “religion is merely a smokescreen for underlying ‘real’ motivations, such as socio-economic grievances”. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Where the West faces one manifestation of climate change, vulnerable nations face many more – which pressure the global community, whether they are discussed or not. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The study does raise important opposing points; northern Nigeria has always been less economically developed, and widespread poverty in the area is hardly novel. However, this reiterates the point that already struggling areas will suffer the most from climate change; it is not the only factor of poverty, but it grows ever more prominent and pressing. It also notes another external factor: that the most recruits were groups that faced political exclusion. Yet, climate change contributes to this too. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There are also signs of drastically increased desertification in northern Nigeria. As fertile land turns to desert and rainfall patterns change, conflict over land has turned vicious and rampant. Muslim Fuhlani herders’ loss of land lead them to move to predominantly Christian farmland; "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.newsecuritybeat.org/2017/08/water-stress-instability-violent-extremism-nigeria/","children":[{"text":"resultant conflict in 2016 led to more deaths"}]},{"text":" than the actions of Boko Haram. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Boko Haram "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2014/06/nigeria-environment-climate-change-boko-haram/","children":[{"text":"capitalises ruthlessly"}]},{"text":" on this discord. It uses it as propaganda for its cause and justification for its Islamist fundamentalist violence. In 2014, the Guardian "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/earth-insight/2014/may/09/behind-rise-nigeria-boko-haram-climate-disaster-peak-oil-depletion","children":[{"text":"identified"}]},{"text":" Boko Haram’s ‘hotbeds’ as being the Yobe, Borno, and Kasina states – the exact states that were listed as being at high risk of desertification in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.usip.org/publications/2018/11/nigerias-worst-violence-not-boko-haram","children":[{"text":"a report three years prior"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Climate change’s destruction of livelihoods goes beyond the environment; it fuels violence, persecution, and fundamentalist organisations. Where the West faces one manifestation, vulnerable nations face many more – which pressure the global community, whether they are discussed or not. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Anoushay studies History and War Studies at King's College London. values.author: wEarthwhie
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"wEarthWhile seeks to reconnect humanity back to Earth by addressing the issues facing the environment and, consequently, those in it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Work in the humanities is a real path for change because political marketing doesn’t appeal to people’s emotions the way that art and stories do. And it seems like getting people to connect to their own humanity and feelings is essential to our ability to connect and have compassion for others. We don’t want to distract, overwhelm, or create burden by adding more to social media with the endless stories surrounding the social sphere; the intention is to replace the focus back on the faces of the change. We don’t expect to approach society as what we think we want them to think, but instead what we want them to do and let them form what they should do. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is an intergenerational fight. We don’t want to have reform that will end climate change and environmental struggles by 80%. We want 100% improvement. To humanize the lives of climate change. To put a face to its impacts. To shine a light on the mostly unseen. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Social photography … let there be light. WearthWhile embodies social photography to shine a light on stories that aren’t accessible to the public. Our aim is to create a tool that primes for a social reform or even a revolutionary movement. To be a part of that transition to fundamentally change how society views climate change and what is being done about it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The photoblog platform establishes positive and progressive discussion; at the heart of that is to include and recognize that people have feelings, experiences, beliefs and inner conflicts that influence the way they perceive and assimilate information. The internet offers opportunities for greater transparency and public participation into our changing climate. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WearthWhile is a photoblog [story platform] that gives back the voice to the people. The commitment through this organization is to put emphasis on the opinions, impacts and experiences of people dealing with climate change and environmental problems. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Narrative offers a powerful means to engage an audience and convey complex concepts. Stories employ the elements of successful narratives, including personalizing their story, drawing on emotions and expressing their opinions. Dialogue rather than a debate offers the means to identify common purpose and foster constructive, evidence-based discourse."}]}]
values.title: Climate Change Social Photography

values.author: Kevin Cumming
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"LANGHOLM MOOR: COMMUNITY BUYOUT"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Supporting the south of Scotlands largest community land purchase. To manage Langholm Moor for ecological restoration and community regeneration."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Langholm Initiative have launched their crowdfunding campaign as they attempt the largest community buyout in the south of Scotland, hoping to bring 10,500 acres (about 5,600 football pitches) into community ownership. To be successful we need to raise the full purchase price by the end of October 2020."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout","children":[{"text":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout"}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The project has received a great boost today (07/05/2020)  as the John Muir Trust has pledged £100,000 towards the purchase."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This project has the potential to act as a blueprint for other communities to place the environment at the heart of the decisions they make."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The project has received widespread support from organisations such as the John Muir Trust, RSPB Scotland, The Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust and The Revive Coalition. In addition to this we have cross party political support for our plans, due to the positive goals relating to climate change, ecological restoration and community regeneration."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Locally over 20 organisations have written letters of support for the buyout."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kevin Cumming, the Langholm Initiative’s project leader said: “Our community plans here have international significance. At a time of climate emergency we are committing to undertake direct climate action including peatland restoration, ancient woodland restoration, the creation of new native woodlands and increasing the diversity of wildlife here”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“At this critical stage we are asking for the help of the public. We know it is a lot to ask at a time like this but if people can support us by donating to this project we will be demonstrating a more positive future for our children.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These ambitious plans will be taken forward with the creation of the new Tarras Valley Nature Reserve."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Our plans"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Over the past six months, a thorough feasibility study has been conducted by community land specialists Duncan MacPherson, Faye McLeod  & Willie McGhee, (a huge thank you to previous crowdfunding supporters for making this possible)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This has given us a vision for a bright future for Langholm moor,  a sustainable business plan for the  Langholm Initiative, and demonstrated real community and environmental benefits.  Our plans centre around creating the Tarras Valley Nature Reserve on the vast majority of the land. Here we will carry out positive climate action and provide a new focus for wildlife tourism and recreation in the south of Scotland.  On a smaller area of land nearest the town itself we will investigate appropriate small scale renewable energy (a single small turbine and a single small solar farm) and the development of a small eco-campsite. We will also investigate repurposing disused and dilapidated steadings for either small scale housing or modern business units, both of which are badly needed in Langholm (there have only been 6 new houses built in Langholm in the past 30 years)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This land also holds huge historical and cultural significance to local people who care passionately about its future. For over 250 years the community have marked the boundaries of the common land and this tradition still goes on today with the annual Common Riding celebration."}]}]
values.title: Langholm Moor Community Buyout

values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Plastic Rain Is the New Acid Rain"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These are unspoiled lands, collectively a great American conservation story. Yet an invisible menace is actually blowing through the air and falling via raindrops: Microplastic particles, tiny chunks (by definition, less than 5 millimeters long) of fragmented plastic bottles and microfibers that fray from clothes, all pollutants that get caught up in Earth’s atmospheric systems and deposited in the wilderness."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Writing today in the journal Science, researchers report a startling discovery: After collecting rainwater and air samples for 14 months, they calculated that over 1,000 metric tons of microplastic particles fall into 11 protected areas in the western US each year. That’s the equivalent of over 120 million plastic water bottles. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It further confirms an increasingly hellish scenario: Microplastics are blowing all over the world, landing in supposedly pure habitats, like the Arctic and the remote French Pyrenees. They’re flowing into the oceans via wastewater and tainting deep-sea ecosystems, and they’re even ejecting out of the water and blowing onto land in sea breezes."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This new research comes with another troubling surprise: 30 percent of the sample particles were microbeads, tiny synthetic spheres that the United States banned from beauty products in 2015. The microbeads in the samples, though, were generally smaller than the ones you’d find in those products."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Scientists have been trying to figure out what happens to the world’s plastic pollution, nearly all of which seems to “disappear” in the environment. But studies like this one are showing that the stuff never truly goes away, it just gets shredded into smaller bits that disperse all over the world, perhaps spending many years cycling through different systems—air, land, and sea."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There’s still much that science has to learn about this microplastic cycle, but this much is clear: There’ll be no putting the plastic back in the bottle."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Researchers find that 1,000 metric tons of Microplastics fall on 11 protected areas in the US annually, equivalent to over 120 million plastic water bottles

values.author: Penguin Productions
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Why do people seek out trails? What is our relationship to wild places, and to ourselves in these wild places? Do you forge your own trail or follow someone else's?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Penguin Productions, a community-based theater is Seattle, WA, commissioned 4 local award-winning playwrights to explore the joys (and discomforts!) of moving down trails, and the feeling of being both small and large in majestic spaces. By celebrating public lands through theater and connecting theater to public lands, we build a more resilient and joyful citizenry. By commissioning plays that speak specifically to the complex emotions we experience on trails, and the roles trails, wild spaces, and public lands play in our lives, we hope to help develop a richer theatrical vocabulary that can articulate the importance, relevance, and threat to these spaces. By centering diverse stories, centering human stories within the landscape, we center ourselves in the natural world and create stronger relationships and dialogues that will help us work towards positive solutions in the face of complex threats. values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carbon emissions from Britain’s electricity system could turn negative by as early as 2033 if the UK uses carbon capture technology alongside more renewable energy to reach its climate targets, according to a report from National Grid."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"National Grid expects a boom in renewable energy projects, including at least 3GW of new windpower capacity and 1.4GW of solar generation every year from now until 2050, alongside a widespread rollout of electric vehicles, which will effectively act as smart-charging “batteries” to help balance the electricity grid."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, the report warned that the UK will not meet its legally binding ambition to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2050 without “immediate action” from the government on key energy policies."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read the full story "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/jul/27/uk-electricity-grids-carbon-emissions-could-turn-negative-by-2033-says-national-grid","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"!"}]}]
values.title: UK electricity grid's carbon emissions could turn negative by 2033, says National Grid

values.author: BBC News
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"France's government has announced new environmental measures, including a ban on heated terraces and outdoor air conditioning for cafes and bars. All heated or air-conditioned buildings open to the public will also have to keep their doors closed to avoid wasting energy."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The ban will not come into force until after the winter as restaurants have been hard hit by Covid-19."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ecology Minister Barbara Pompili told reporters it was wrong for shops to \"air-condition the streets\" in summer by keeping their doors open just to spare customers from having to open them."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"Neither should terraces be heated in winter so people can feel warm as they drink coffee,\" she said."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read the full story "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-53552526","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"!"}]}]
values.title: France to ban heated terraces in cafes and bars

values.author: Helen Briggs, BBC Environment Correspondent
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sharks are rarely seen at almost one in five of the world's coral reefs, a major study has found."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The crash in shark numbers, caused largely by over-fishing, could have dire consequences for corals struggling to survive in a changing climate, researchers have said."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Species such as grey reef sharks, blacktip reef sharks, and Caribbean reef sharks were often missing from reefs where they would historically have been found."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Almost no sharks were detected on any of the 69 reefs of six nations: the Dominican Republic, the French West Indies, Kenya, Vietnam, the Windward Dutch Antilles and Qatar."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read the full story "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-53514945","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"!"}]}]
values.title: Reef sharks are in major decline worldwide due to overfishing

values.author: Victoria Gill, BBC News
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"An estimated 1.3 billion tonnes of plastic is destined for our environment - both on land and in the ocean - by 2040, unless worldwide action is taken."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To turn this complex problem into numbers, researchers tracked the production, use and disposal of plastic around the world. values.title: Plastic pollution to weigh 1.3 billion tonnes by 2040

values.author: Harry Cockburn, The Independent
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"Falling cost of renewable energy production could mean lower bills, researchers say.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Renewable energy could soon be the cheapest form of power in the UK, and, with any luck, those savings will be passed on to the consumers."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Due to technological developments, wind farms are now incredibly cheap to build and install - not to mention the ability to build them further out to sea. values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Michigan Launch Initiative, spearheaded by the Michigan Aerospace Manufacturers Association (MAMA), has located two sites near Marquette on the shores of Lake Superior for a vertical launch site and autonomous vehicle testing grounds. values.author: The OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, commercial shipping and other boat traffic has dramatically decreased. One positive impact of this has been the decrease in underwater noise pollution. Marine life, especially whales and other cetaceans, are highly sensitive to noise. These marine mammals can transmit their own calls over vast distances, which is creating the opportunity for scientists to better understand how communication between individuals may change in a quieter environment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.npr.org/2020/07/20/891854646/whales-get-a-break-as-pandemic-creates-quieter-oceans","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":"Read more at "}]}]
values.title: Pandemic Creates Temporary Noise Reprieve for Marine Life

values.author: The OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Farmland is increasingly coming under the ownership of investors who often live hundreds if not thousands of miles away from the property itself. As farmland increases in price, upwards of tens of millions of dollars in many cases, land is being bought by those seeking to cash in at a later date as prices inevitably continue their upward trend. This has created many situations of poor land management. Farmers who are forced to lease their land rather than own it often will not invest in soil or water protection measures, such as cover crops, because they cannot be sure they will see the long term benefit of doing so. In addition, the investors who own the land have only a monetary attachment to the land and investing in these measures cuts into their profits from leasing the land. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Smarter land owners must realize that land managed in a more environmentally friendly way will be healthier land overall, and will be worth more as higher quality land than that which has been poorly managed."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is also linked to a push towards large scale corporate farms, some of which can own tens of thousands of acres of land irrigated with miles of pipelines. Farming operations on this scale are unobtainable for family owned farms and the pressure to sell to these corporations can often be a difficult but financially necessary choice for farmers struggling to compete in an ever technologically advancing time. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.npr.org/2020/07/30/892366385/big-money-investors-gear-up-for-a-trillion-dollar-bet-on-farm-land","children":[{"text":"https://www.npr.org/2020/07/30/892366385/big-money-investors-gear-up-for-a-trillion-dollar-bet-on-farm-land"}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: American Farmland Increasingly Owned by Investors

values.author: The OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Science write Zach St. George's new book, \"The Journeys of Trees\", illustrates how forests have exhibited a painstakingly slow migration for eons. As old trees die, new ones take root and thrive in more hospitable directions, slowly moving the forests. As temperatures near the equator increase, forests are moving slowly North, but too slowly to escape the devastating impacts of climate change at its current accelerated pace. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In places like California, Joshua trees may no longer be able to survive in Joshua Tree National Park - it will be too hot and dry. Ancient, giant Sequoia trees may no longer be found in Sequoia National Park. This begs the question - do we lose these species forever, or do we find new habitats and plant new groves? What of the species that already exist in these new areas? Many factors will come into play as scientists and environmentalists grapple with saving our iconic, widely cherished forests. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.npr.org/2020/07/28/896030567/believe-it-or-not-forests-migrate-but-not-fast-enough-for-climate-change","children":[{"text":"https://www.npr.org/2020/07/28/896030567/believe-it-or-not-forests-migrate-but-not-fast-enough-for-climate-change"}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Forests Naturally Migrate, But Not Fast Enough to Escape Human-Accelerated Climate Change

values.author: Rappler, The Philippine Star
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At least 212 environmental campaigners worldwide were murdered in 2019, making last year the deadliest on record for frontline activists battling the destruction of nature, watchdog group Global Witness reported. However, it has also been reported that the total number of deaths is probably higher since it doesn’t include the “unreported of misrepresented cases,” added the report. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The degradation of our ancestral lands has been an undisclosed issue for decades, often backed-up and funded by corrupted national governments. Among the 141, more than 50 were campaigners against legal or illegal mining operations, while 20% of the 212 killings were environmental activists defenders from the Philippines. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“It is alarming that Filipino environmental defenders confronting these existential planetary crises are still increasingly criminalized and murdered under the administration of President Rodrigo Duterte,” Leon Dulce, national coordinator of Kalikasan People’s Network for the Environment, said in a statement."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Philippines is now the second most dangerous nation in the world (behind Colombia) and the first in Asia. values.author: Agence France-Presse
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Did you know that meat-loving nations contribute the most to carbon emissions? So if we do calculate our carbon footprint, why are we not calculating food-print?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Group of Twenty (G20) nations reported that we would need an extra 5 planets to feed the world if everyone alive ate steaks and dairy the way Brazilians and Americans do. Producing food for 7.7 billion people is responsible for a quarter of the global carbon emissions that drive climate change. Around 40% of that comes from livestock production and food waste."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"Individuals in a handful of countries are eating way too much of the wrong foods at the expense of the rest of the world,\" said Brent Loken, global food lead at WWF and lead author of the report, told AFP. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The countries with climate-friendly dietary guidelines are Indonesia, India, South Korea, China, and Japan."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/g20-carbon-food-print-highest-in-meat-loving-nations-report/ar-BB16MKa4?li=BBnbcA1&srcref=rss","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]

values.author: Tom Ough, The Telegraph
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"[Wood] performs comparably well to steel despite being five times lighter.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As there is less and less of a call for office space - which has only be exasperated by COVID-19 - architects and environmentalists are looking to creating more sustainable skyscrapers that can lead us into a new age of tall buildings."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Construction is said to be responsible for about 40% of the world's energy use - meaning that although many skyscrapers claim to be classified as net-zero (produce power equal to that they consume), this does not factor in the building process. This is because the main materials used in essentially all tall buildings are concrete and steel, both of which require a lot of energy to produce."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Norway finished erecting a mixed-use, wooden building in Spring, and whilst it isn't anywhere near tall enough to be classed as a skyscraper, it is still the tallest wooden building in the world - by quite the margin. Wood is seen as the most likely material to replace its less environmentally conscious counterparts since new technologies and developments have caused it to become a much more versatile construction material than previously. There is evidence to show that being around wood and nature is inherently good for us - so by building our cities out of it we will be improving both the welfare of the world and our own."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education-and-careers/2020/07/30/future-skyscrapers-mile-high-slimmer-ever-made-wood/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: The future of skyscrapers: a mile high, slimmer than ever and made from wood

values.author: Max Bearak, Independent
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"...travel restrictions mean the humans have suddenly vanished, and along with them a billion-dollar tourism industry that employs millions and underpins a symbiotic human-wildlife ecosystem...\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Conservancies make up roughly 11% of Kenya's land - more than all its national parks. The way it works is that cattle herders (for the most part) are offered subsidies, funded by the money bought in by tourism, to make up for the loss of grazing land. As a result of the lack of tourism, many workers are furloughed and so what money is available is going to them; instead of being offered up as the subsidies. Therefore, numerous cattle herders are considering returning to grazing on the land - which would undo decades of work done to maintain the country's grasslands."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The relationship between people and wildlife is usually beneficially balanced here. But it was also precariously balanced, and now the scales have shifted drastically. The aim has always been to help the local communities and the local wildlife live in harmony, and what will be detrimental for one, will be detrimental for both."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read the full story "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/maasai-mara-kenya-wildlife-tourism-unemployment-coronavirus-a9628416.html","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: The crash in tourism has jeopardised decades of wildlife conservation efforts in Kenya

"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"South Africa has been battling rhino poaching for years, fighting relentless demand for rhino horns in parts of Asia, where they are used in traditional medicine, as an aphrodisiac or simply as a status symbol."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/aug/01/south-african-rhino-poaching-halves-in-six-months-thanks-to-covid-19-lockdown","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":", and find out more about rhino poaching in South Africa and what you can do to help "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.savetherhino.org/rhino-info/poaching-stats/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":".
