values.author: OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While most of the world is only just waking up to the importance of trees in battling the climate emergency, Costa Rica is years ahead. In the 1970s and 1980s Costa Rica had one of the highest deforestation rates in Latin America, but it managed to turn that around in a relatively short period of time, becoming the first tropical country to have stopped, subsequently reversing deforestation. Here's how they did it."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the 1940s, 75% of Costa Rica was cloaked in lush rainforests, but by 1987, between half and a third of this forest cover was gone. In an unprecedented move around this time, the Costa Rican government took a series of radical steps to regrow the country's lost forest. In 1996, chopping down forests without approval from authorities was made illegal, and a year later, PES a scheme run by the Costa Rican government that rewards farmers who carry out "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.fonafifo.go.cr/en/servicios/pago-de-servicios-ambientales/","children":[{"text":"sustainable forestry and environmental protection"}]},{"text":", was introduced. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Today, 60% of the land is forest again, and the region is home to more than half a million plant and animal species. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more about this "},{"type":"link","url":"https://edition.cnn.com/2020/07/27/americas/reforestation-costa-rica-c2e-spc/index.html","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":". "}]}]
values.title: Costa Rica becomes one of the first tropical countries to stop and reverse deforestation

values.author: OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As floods sweep across Assam, in north-east India, killing 73 and affecting 400,000 people across the state, 85% of the Kaziranga National Park and Tiger Reserve (KNPTR) remains submerged. So far, 125 animals have been rescued and 86 have died, including rhinos, deer and wild boar, in the sixth worst flood since 1988."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Yet, the annual floods are essential for the survival of this UNESCO World Heritage Site. Here are some of the reasons why."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It is a riverine ecosystem, not a solid landmass-based ecosystem,” says P Sivakumar, Director, KNPTR, “The system won’t survive without water.” The entire area of Kaziranga—formed by alluvial deposits from the Brahmaputra and its tributaries—is centred around the river. The regenerative nature of floods helps replenish water bodies and maintain th landscape, a mix of wetlands, grasslands and semi-evergreen deciduous forests. The floodwaters also function as a breeding ground for fish. In a herbivore-dominated area like Kaziranga, it is important to maintain its grassland status. If it were not for the annual floods, the area would become a woodland. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But climate change and impractical infrastructure is beginning to spell disaster for the region, as more the damage done begins to outweigh the benefits. Many animals in the area are endangered, and are forced to seek refuge from areas that are deeper underwater than ever before due to unprecedented glacial melt, crossing the busy National Highway 37 that cuts through the park in the process. Every year an increasing number of animals are killed by vehicles or poachers. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read about this "},{"type":"link","url":"https://indianexpress.com/article/explained/kaziranga-national-park-assam-floods-6510034/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":". "}]}]
values.address: Kaziranga National Park and Tiger Reserve, Assam, India
values.title: Floods are necessary for the survival of the Kaziranga National Park- but they could destroy the region's biodiversity.

values.author: Himanshu N, DownToEarth India
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Climate change has brought monumental shifts in weather patterns, fishing zones and migration of fish population to different areas. impacting the  source of livelihood for many in coastal India — pushing them to turn to technological assistance to practice sustainability."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Numer8 Analytics Pvt Ltd, a data science firm, analysed changes in the cyclical pattern of potential fishing zones in 2018. It found that nearshore fishing zones had drifted away further into the deeper seas. It also analysed the coastal vulnerability index for Kerala and Odisha post-2018 Kerala cyclone and Cyclone Fani in 2019. Following this, it developed an app, which provides fishermen with weather updates, helps them identify fishing zones and ensure that government guidelines on fishing are practiced."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The technology helps fishermen on the sea as well as on the coast. The high-precision marine and ocean data helps them to venture in safer areas of the sea.  It also enables marine and port authorities in India and Sri Lanka to monitor overfishing and unregulated fishing in the Indian coasts. It is currently working with fishermen in Maharashtra and Kerala in India."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read the full article "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.downtoearth.org.in/news/climate-change/how-technology-is-helping-indian-sri-lankan-fishermen-amid-climate-change-patterns-72322","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":". "}]}]
values.title: How technology is helping Indian, Sri Lankan fishermen amid climate change patterns

values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Fragile per-glacial ecosystems have seen a depletion in several species, says a Botanical Survey of India study. Several flowering plants, such as the  the Blue poppy, Meconopis acculette, found at very high altitudes, are facing a “climb higher or die” situation due to climate change. A recent  study of  the species in alpine moraines at different elevations indicated that abundance of plants is slowly depleting at lower altitudes and rocky moraines."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Plants belonging to the group Saussurea, such as the endangered Himkamal, including Saussurea Obvallata and Saussurea gnaphaloides, have been proved to be vulnerable to habitat loss. Dash, a senior BSI scientist who contributed to the publication, added that the upward movement of some of these species and the expansion of other invasive species not only demontrates their adaptability but also highlights a worrying change in the microclimatic situation in the region."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/energy-and-environment/climb-or-die-himalayan-plants-on-steep-trek-to-survive-climate-change/article32206679.ece","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Emperor penguins rely on sea ice to feed and breed, so tend to live in very remote, difficult to access areas. This is why it has been so difficult for them to be found and studied prior to now."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As climates increase and change, the homes of these colonies are put at risk. Many of the newly discovered colonies live towards the outer regions of the Emperor penguin breeding areas, meaning they are most at risk of losing their homes and breeding grounds as temperatures rise."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/emperor-penguin-colonies-satellite-antarctica-guano-a9655051.html","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Harry Cockburn, Independent"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Photo Credit: "},{"type":"link","url":"https://pixabay.com/users/bdougherty-4513390/?utm_source=link-attribution&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=image&utm_content=2821897","children":[{"text":"Barbara Dougherty"}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Penguin poo seen by satellites leads to discovery of previously unknown emperor colonies in Antarctica

values.author: Max Sharp
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"[Tesco] says the UK should introduce due diligence across supply chains to monitor for deforestation.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A campaign from Greenpeace has called on the supermarket to cut ties with Brazilian meat company JBS after allegations that their meat farms are directly linked to further deforestation of the Amazon rainforest. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A YouGov poll has revealed that more than 50% of Britons would be willing to give up meat that has been linked to deforestation."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Timing in with Germany's proposed supply chain laws and changes now would be a good time for the UK government to back its major supermarkets, made clear by the words of the Tesco group chief executive, DaveLewis: \"We are making tangible process but we can't solve this on our own.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/aug/05/tesco-urged-to-ditch-meat-company-over-alleged-links-to-amazon-deforestation","children":[{"text":"here "}]},{"text":"to find out more!"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Dom Phillips, The Guardian"}]}]
values.title: Tesco urged to ditch meat company over alleged links to Amazon deforestation

values.author: Jess - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The first full inventory of plants on the world's largest tropical island reveals a treasure trove of flora."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"More than 13,000 species can be found on New Guinea, ranging from tiny orchids to giant tree ferns, two-thirds of which do not exist elsewhere.The findings, published in Nature, will be used to protect \"one of the last unknowns for science\". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Identifying and naming plants is the first step towards conserving and protecting the plants of New Guinea, said Dr Tim Utteridge of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"If we lose them, there's no way we can restore them from anywhere else, because they're just not found outside the island,\" he said. \"We have a real responsibility to conserve this unique plant life.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-53668124","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: New Guinea has the highest plant diversity of any island in the world

values.author: Jess - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Fifteen families of beavers have been given the permanent \"right to remain\" on the River Otter in East Devon."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The decision was made by the government following a five-year study by the Devon Wildlife Trust into beavers' impact on the local environment.The Trust called it \"the most ground-breaking government decision for England's wildlife for a generation\". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It's the first time an extinct native mammal has been given government backing to be reintroduced in England.Environment minister Rebecca Pow said that in the future they could be considered a \"public good\" and farmers and landowners would pay to have them on their land. Beavers have the power to change entire landscapes. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"They feel safer in deep water, so have become master makers of dams and pools. They build complex homes - known as lodges or burrows - with underwater entrances."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-53658375","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Beaver families win legal 'right to remain'

values.author: Jess - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Rats and bats that host pandemic pathogens like Covid-19 increase in damaged ecosystems, analysis shows."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The human destruction of natural ecosystems increases the numbers of rats, bats and other animals that harbour diseases that can lead to pandemics such as Covid-19, a comprehensive analysis has found."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The research assessed nearly 7,000 animal communities on six continents and found that the conversion of wild places into farmland or settlements often wipes out larger species. It found that the damage benefits smaller, more adaptable creatures that also carry the most pathogens that can pass to humans."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The assessment found that the populations of animals hosting what are known as zoonotic diseases were up to 2.5 times bigger in degraded places, and that the proportion of species that carry these pathogens increased by up to 70% compared with in undamaged ecosystems."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/aug/05/deadly-diseases-from-wildlife-thrive-when-nature-is-destroyed-study-finds","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Deadly diseases from wildlife thrive when nature is destroyed

values.author: Jess - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Tougher limits on levels of air pollution are proposed to tackle a problem thought to contribute to as many as 1,400 deaths a year in Wales."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It is one of a range of actions set out in the Clean Air Plan, including that buses and taxis should be electric or hydrogen powered by 2028.Environment Minister Lesley Griffiths said \"very radical\" change was needed."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Clean air campaigners welcomed the announcement but called for swift implementation of the plan's proposals.\"This is a first step, we need to focus on delivery and urgent action now,\" said Haf Elgar, director of Friends of the Earth Cymru, adding that levels of air pollution in Wales were a \"disgrace\"."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-53669919?intlink_from_url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science_and_environment&link_location=live-reporting-story","children":[{"text":" here."}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Clean Air Plan proposes tougher limits on Welsh air pollution

values.author: Jess - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The government’s proposed reforms of the planning system will cost Britain decades in the fight against climate change and resign nature to “isolated fragments of land”, environmentalists have warned. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Countryside charities said plans to make new homes carbon neutral by as late as 2050 – beyond what scientists say will be a tipping point for climate change – as “pitiful” and dramatically less ambitious than previous ambitions scrapped by ministers. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The government says the framework spelled out in its new planning white paper would “cut red tape” and create a “major boost” for construction firms while delivering more homes."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Under the plans, unveiled by housing secretary Robert Jenrick, land would be categorised as either suitable for development, a “renewal” area, or protected. On the first two categories, building projects could be fast-tracked without going through the current planning permission process if they meet certain standards."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/climate-change-uk-government-planning-reforms-robert-jenrick-a9656161.html","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: New British planning reforms could seriously impact fight against climate change

values.author: Jess - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Japan’s powerful business lobby Keidanren is dominated by energy-intensive sectors that represent less than 10% of the economy, resulting in national policies that favour coal and hindering attempts to combat climate change, a new study said."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The influence of the country’s electricity, steel, cement, car and fossil fuel sectors undermines Japan’s attempts to meet its Paris Agreement commitments, according to the report by London-based data analysis company InfluenceMap. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Keidanren, which has close ties with the trade and industry ministry as well as other government bodies, sits on expert panels and other forums where government policies are debated. It has acted as a ‘central negotiating point’ on climate policy for two decades, the report said. While it claims to represent all of Japanese business, the claim “clearly should be questioned on climate/energy policy,” InfluenceMap said. It added the most powerful industries within Keidanren only employ about 2.7 million, while those with little influence employ 10 times that number. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lobbying and consultation by business groups will be critical next year when the government reviews its strategic energy plan."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-climate-change-japan-coal/japans-climate-change-efforts-hindered-by-biased-business-lobby-study-idUKKCN2511G4","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Japan's climate change efforts hindered by biased business lobby

The document is a collaboration between the USDA, Colorado State University, and the National Center for Atmospheric Research and aims to equip farmers and land managers with tools for decision making in the face of climate change."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read a story on the report "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.cpr.org/2020/08/04/20-ways-colorado-farmers-ranchers-agriculture-experience-climate-change/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]

values.author: Persis Flores - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Have you ever wondered if we can live without electricity? No, right? How can you, when you can't imagine life without it? Our essential needs like cooking, sleeping, and even working are in one way or another reliant on electricity."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Regardless of the kind, whether renewable or fossil-fueled, all power plants impact our environment. Even building a power plant itself contributes to pollution because it requires underground construction that creates waste and debris."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"According to Melissa Low of Channel News Asia, nearly all combustion by-products have negative-effects on the environment and human health. values.author: Persis Flores - OTS Team; story from Mongabay
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Around 1.2 million hectares (3 million acres) in the Brazilian Pantanal region have been burned so far. It is the world’s largest natural wetland and is home to a rich variety of plants and animals. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"According to sources, the underground fires were started by human activity and are difficult to control due to inaccessibility. Access is the limitation as the areas affected by fires can only be reached by helicopter and is impossible via land travel."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“In recent days, we have noticed a really strong intensification of the fires. But the truth is that the fires have been happening in Pantanal since the beginning of the year, the situation has been critical for months. The Pantanal is going through a period of exponential rise in fires. We are facing a scenario now that is catastrophic,\" said Júlio César Sampaio, World Wildlife Fund’s (WWF) Pantanal Program Coordinator."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"More about this "},{"type":"link","url":"https://news.mongabay.com/2020/08/fires-in-the-pantanal-we-are-facing-a-scenario-now-that-is-catastrophic/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: Pantanal: World's largest natural wetland, now catastrophic

values.author: Persis Flores - OTS Team; story from Yonhap News Agency
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"Our ability to reduce disaster risk relies on the full engagement of local governments. When national and local governments work together, they can be a formidable alliance for risk reduction. This article reports on the Republic of Korea’s experience and examines the role of city governments in reducing disaster risk and applying climate information.\" —"},{"type":"link","url":"https://public.wmo.int/en/bulletin/reducing-disaster-risk-cities-%E2%80%94-republic-korea%E2%80%99s-experience","children":[{"text":" Reducing Disaster Risk in Cities"}]},{"text":" by Glenn Dolcemascolo, Yongkyun Kim and Teh-Lan Linda Mu"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"South Korea has been enduring torrential rain for 44 days that caused floods and landslides, the longest monsoon since 2013. At least 16 people have been killed and 1,500 have been displaced, while almost half of Seoul is at risk of flooding. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"According to the Yonhap news agency, the flooding has reachedhighways and bridges in Seoul that prompted the government to mobilize more than 25,000 police officers and volunteers to tackle the damage."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"More about this "},{"type":"link","url":"https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20200807009951315","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":" and "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/floods-and-landslides-kill-at-least-16-displace-thousands-in-12997104","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: South Korea: Mudslides killed 16 and displaced 1,500

values.author: Persis Flores - OTS Team; story from NBC News
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The app named O-FISH (Officer Fishery Information Sharing Hub) is for the marine rangers who enforce restrictions in protected areas when they are in remote spots. It was the first of its kind to be widely available and linked to a massive database of past fishing violations."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The maritime officers who patrol the most vulnerable parts of the ocean haven't always operated with the most advanced technology, often relying on pen and paper, according to David Ingram of NBC News."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"It makes it more time-efficient. The rangers can rapidly gather the information they need and just download it. And you're not spending a whole other day when you get back to port entering information,\" said Meaghan Brosnan, the marine program director for WildAid."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"According to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/articles/2020/07/07/how-much-of-the-ocean-is-really-protected","children":[{"text":"The Pew"}]},{"text":", only a fraction of the 15,000 marine protected areas around the globe has active conservation efforts. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"More about this "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/tracking-illegal-fishing-there-s-finally-app-n1235857","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: Track illegal fishing via the O-FISH app

values.author: Vidita Govindachari- OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The environmental ministry of Mauritius released a statement announcing that oil had been leaking from the bulk carrier M V Wakashio that had run aground in the south east of the island, requesting the public to avoid venturing into the area, which is a popular tourist destination. The ship, which ran aground at Pointe d'Esny (which is listed under the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands of International Importance) on 25th July 2020 was empty, though carrying 200 tonnes of diesel and 3,800 tonnes of bunker fuel. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On Friday, Prime Minister Pravind Jugnauth declared a state of environmental emergency. Happy Khambule of Greenpeace Africa said \"thousands\" of animal species were \"at risk of drowning in a sea of pollution, with dire consequences for Mauritius' economy, food security and health\". This could prove devastating to the island nation, whose economy is heavily reliant on the ocean for food, as well as tourism."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53702877","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: Oil Leak Plunges Mauritius into an Environmental Crisis.

values.author: Vidita Govindachari- OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Delhi government recently launched the Delhi Electric Vehicle (EV) Policy, 2020 -- in an effort to reduce air pollution in one of the world's most polluted cities. Aiming to kickstart the economy by spurring demand by  offering subsidies,and road tax and registration free waivers for electric vehicles bought in the Capital"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53702877","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":", the government is targeting the registration of 500,000 new E.Vs in the next 5 years. In their lifetime, these vehicles are estimated to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 4.8 million tonnes. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Hoping to address the high cost of purchase, and the lack of sufficient charging infrastructure, this policy is focused on making EVS more affordable and accessible, in a region where only 83,000 out of 11 million registered vehicles are electric.  \"This policy will give the Capital a much needed push towards a cleaner and greener Delhi\", said Chief Minister, Arvind Kejriwal."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Find out more about this policy and its aims "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.hindustantimes.com/cities/big-push-for-electric-vehicles-to-boost-demand-cut-air-pollution/story-AEmIqU6B5zcYZhpP1goVnN.html","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: Delhi Government Launches Policy to Boost Demand for Electric Vehicles

values.author: Vidita Govindachari- OTS Team (Sourced from Emanuela Barbiroglio, Forbes)
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Eight authors and illustrators at Studio Rebigo based in Genoa, Italy, selected 23 stories and set them in ruined ecosystems, to help next generations develop critical thinking. The group explored deforestation, plastic pollution, global warming and urbanization, through the drawings of dystopian environmental disasters. These retellings feature folktales like Little Red Riding Hood and Jack and the Beanstalk, and classics like Jules Verne’s \"Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea\", Hans Christian Andersen’s \"The Little Mermaid\", Grimms’ \"Hansel and Gretel\", Italo Calvino’s \"The baron in the trees\" and Frances Eliza Hodgson Burnett’s \"The Secret Garden\"."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“At a time when everyone was talking about the future, about aware youth, and about the kind of world they will inherit from us, it seemed fair to think about our target audience, so the generations to come and their parents who are currently our peers,” illustrator Alessandro Parodi explains. “Hence the question: what world and what stories will we leave them?” The book was designed for children, and all those who deal with them, from parents to teachers. “We don't want to teach anything, since we are still studying ourselves, but we hope the book can help readers develop critical thinking about these topics and eventually make them consider their little daily gestures.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read the full article "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.forbes.com/sites/emanuelabarbiroglio/2020/08/05/what-is-climate-change-explained-by-italian-illustrators-in-23-fairy-tales/#61b701b697e1","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":", and check out "},{"type":"link","url":"https://studiorebigo.myportfolio.com/casa","children":[{"text":"Studio Rebigo's website"}]},{"text":" while you're at it!"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"(Picture: Studio Rebigo)"}]}]
values.title: Italian Illustrators Reimagine Fairy Tales to Help Children Understand Climate Change

values.author: Vidita Govindachari- OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Almost 40 years after India’s first mass mobilisation for an environmental cause transformed Silent Valley into one of the best-protected forest regions in the country, the Kerala government has decided to declare its buffer zone as a wildlife sanctuary to augment protection measures, in a move that local tribes hope will further strengthen conservation efforts in the Valley. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The proposed Bhavani Wildlife Sanctuary will be Kerala’s 25th protected area. Spread across 148 square kilometres, Bhavani will encompass parts of Mannarkkad and Nilambur  forest divisions, which are continuations of the Silent Valley National Park.This proposal is a major step in the direction of establishing a National Rainforest Biosphere Reserve. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Silent Valley remains as one of the last tracts of undisturbed tropical evergreen rainforests across the world, thanks to decades of sustained campaigning by environmentalists, the media, students and activists in India. In 1984, the area became a national park and received protected status, after national outrage in response to the proposed building of a hydroelectric dam in the 1970s. The region is home to over 1000 species of plants and animals, many of which are protected. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read about this "},{"type":"link","url":"https://india.mongabay.com/2020/08/silent-valley-to-soon-get-a-conservation-ring-around-it/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":", and find out more about Silent Valley National Park "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.silentvalley.gov.in/Home/Index","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: Kerala Government ramps up conservation efforts of biodiversity hotspot

values.author: Vidita Govindachari- OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plan for a \"self-reliant India\" in a post-Covid-19 economy could come at a grave cost to some of the country's most vulnerable forests. 40 new coalfields in some of India's most biodiverse regions are to be opened up for commercial mining, in a shift which marks the beginning of the Indian coal sector's concerning transition from a state-owned industry into private hands, as industrial giants, including $14 billion Adani Group, bid for rights to mine on the land. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Among the regions at risk is the Hasdeo Arand forest, home to indigenous communities and dense forests, which sits on top of a whopping 5 billion tonnes of coal. The project will destroy five villages, displace over 6000 people and wipe out thousands of acres of trees, causing the loss of livelihoods of the indigenous people of the area. Many environmentalists and locals also believe that the biodiversity of the region will never be replaced if the forest disappears. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Four state governments – West Bengal, Maharashtra, Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh – have written to Modi in opposition or raised legal objections to the auction, and one coal block, which overlapped with the Tadoba tiger reserve in Maharashtra, has already been removed. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read about this project and the repercussions it could have "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/08/india-prime-minister-narendra-modi-plans-to-fell-ancient-forest-to-create-40-new-coal-fields","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":". "}]}]
values.title: Creation of Coalfields Threatens India's Ancient Forests

values.author: Emily Lewis - OTS Map Team

values.author: Clarissa Guy, originally found via ProPublica
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A new climate map reveals how the human climate niche will change in North America. Showcasing moderate and extreme warming projections, the map displays where this niche will shift to as the climate becomes too hot or dry for humans in places that have been habitable for over 6,000 years. The map details challenges of heat and humidity, large wildfires, sea level rise, crop damages, and economic damages. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Find the maps "},{"type":"link","url":"https://projects.propublica.org/climate-migration/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read about the future of the \"human climate niche\" "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.pnas.org/content/pnas/117/21/11350.full.pdf","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":"."}]}]
values.title: New climate map shows how North America will be impacted by climate change

values.author: Jess McDonald - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Coastal salt marshes - once seen as \"wasteland\" to be reclaimed for farming and industry - have been found to play a vital role in offsetting emissions."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It estimated Wales' marine environment annually locks away as much carbon dioxide as is produced by 64,800 cars.Natural Resources Wales (NRW), which commissioned the study, said it was working to restore the sites."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There are more than three million hectares of so-called blue carbon habitat in Wales."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-54175790?intlink_from_url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science_and_environment&link_location=live-reporting-story","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: Welsh Salt Marshes Vital for Offsetting Emissions, study finds

values.author: Jess McDonald - OTS Team
values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In 2010, more than 150 countries set out the 20 Aichi biodiversity targets to prevent more species from vanishing and to safeguard ecosystems."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But a new UN report shows these nations have mostly failed to reach these targets. Six of the 20 goals were “partially achieved,” and the rest were not."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It is the second consecutive decade that countries have fallen short of the goals, and fragile habitats like coral reefs and tropical forests are in greater peril than even before."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/nature-biodiversity-collapse-un-world-collapse-climate-change-b447652.html","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]
values.title: UN Report shows global failure to reach biodiversity targets

values.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As everyone tries to follow all the COVID-19 protocols to help flatten the curve, greenhouse gas emissions from the energy and transport industries plummeted.
